DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (FBT COST OF COMPLIANCE) BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 28 June.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear The Hon G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Taxation Laws Amendment (FBT Cost of Compliance) Bill 1995 will amend the fringe benefits tax and income tax laws to give effect to the government's fringe benefits tax cost of compliance statement of 24 February 1995. It will also make changes to the fringe benefits tax substantiation rules which were announced on 29 March 1995.

PARA.TAB: In line with this government's desire to minimise taxpayers' costs in complying with the tax laws, the amendments in this bill will substantially reduce compliance costs for employers liable to fringe benefits tax. In addition, a number of benefits provided by employers will no longer be subject to fringe benefits tax.

Most of the measures in this bill will apply from 1 April 1995, the start of the current fringe benefits tax year. However, measures dealing with living away from home allowances will take effect from 1 July 1995.

The bill will exempt from fringe benefits tax a range of benefits that are primarily used for business purposes. These benefits include employment related protective clothing, briefcases, calculators and electronic diaries, tools of trade, employment related software and portable computers. Mobile and car phones will also be exempt where their use is primarily for employment purposes.

In recognition of the safety and health issues involved, taxis provided by employers to employees for travel to and from home between the hours of 8.00 p.m. and 6.00 a.m. will be exempt, as will taxi travel for sick employees to home or to another place of care.
The exemption of taxi travel is estimated to cost $45 million in 1995-96 and $30 million in each later year. The other exemptions have a small but unquantifiable cost to revenue.

The bill will also reduce the number of declarations required by the fringe benefits tax law. Where a series of identical benefits is provided, an employee declaration is generally required each time a benefit is provided so that the private portion of the benefit can be determined. This requirement for multiple declarations will be replaced by a single employee declaration which can be used for up to five years.
Further, a single employer declaration will also be available in certain situations. This declaration can also be used for up to five years.
The bill will reduce the compliance costs associated with the calculation of FBT on meal entertainment by providing two further options for determining the value of a benefit.

The simplest of these methods is to accept that 50 per cent of expenditure on meal entertainment in a year is subject to fringe benefits tax, with the balance being non-deductible to the employer. This method will also be available for use with the lease or hire costs of corporate boxes and other entertainment facilities.

The other method requires the employee to keep a 12-week register. This register is then applied over the whole year to determine the amount of meal entertainment which is subject to fringe benefits tax and the amount which is deductible for income tax purposes. The register will remain effective for up to five years.
Amendments in the bill will also reduce the compliance costs associated with the taxation of car parking benefits.

First, fringe benefits tax will no longer apply to car parking on employers' premises unless there is a commercial car parking station within a one kilometre radius that charges more than $5 a day at the beginning of the fringe benefits tax year. This will ensure that fringe benefits tax will only apply to car parking in areas where such benefits have significant values, such as in CBD areas.

Secondly, employers will be able to adopt a simplified method of valuing car parking benefits. This new method will enable an employer to determine the value of a benefit by reference to the average of the lowest commercial car park fees at the start and end of the FBT year.

Also, a further two optional methods for calculating the total taxable value of car parking fringe benefits will be available. One of these methods uses a statutory formula and the other allows an employer to keep a 12-week record of car park usage.

Comparable changes will be made to the income tax law relating to the deductibility of car parking expenditure incurred by self-employed taxpayers. These amendments are estimated to cost $76 million in 1995-96 and $62 million in each later year.

The government will also take the opportunity in this bill to make a technical correction to ensure that, as originally intended, car parking benefits provided by Commonwealth, state or territory government educational institutions will be exempt from fringe benefits tax. This amendment, which will have no effect on revenue, will be retrospective to 1 April 1993.

The bill will also modify the fringe benefits tax treatment of living away from home allowance benefits and other food and accommodation benefits provided to employees who are required to live away from their usual place of residence. These modifications will provide a greater degree of certainty in determining whether the benefits will be subject to concessional treatment.

These benefits will be subject to concessional treatment for up to four years for benefits provided to expatriates working in Australia or for benefits provided to Australian residents working overseas, for up to two years for employees working in remote areas—unlimited time for employees working on a `fly-in fly-out' basis—and for up to one year for benefits provided for all other employees. The date of effect of these measures has been moved to 1 July 1995.

The bill will also amend the fringe benefits tax substantiation provisions to make them generally consistent with the revised income tax substantiation rules, including reducing the period for which records are required to be retained from seven to five years.

In order to maintain the revenue neutrality of this package of compliance cost reduction measures, the bill will increase the statutory fractions used in the statutory formula for car benefits by approximately 10 per cent. Even with these increases in the statutory fractions, the statutory formula will remain significantly concessional under a wide range of circumstances.This amendment is estimated to raise $121 million in 1995-96 and $91 million in each later year.

The bill will also extend the rebate of fringe benefits tax presently allowed to certain non-profit, non-government bodies to certain medical research bodies which, while established under a Commonwealth, state or territory law, are not conducted by or on behalf of a government. The amendment will be effective from 1 April 1994. Full details of the amendments in the bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum circulated to honourable members.

I also foreshadow that the government will be moving some minor amendments to the bill in the House. Copies of those amendments and a supplementary explanatory memorandum have been circulated to members. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Costello Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

SPEECH.PARA: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:
(1)condemns the Government for its delay in concluding the Fringe Benefits Tax cost of compliance review;

PARA.TAB: (2)notes the continued complexity and high compliance costs of the Fringe Benefits Tax; and
(3)calls on the Government to bring before the House further measures to simplify and streamline the operation of the Fringe Benefits Tax".

SPEECH.PARA: The Taxation Laws Amendment (FBT Cost of Compliance) Bill amends the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act in order to implement the results of a review on FBT compliance costs. The results were announced by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) in February of 1995. But there was a sting in the package. The sting in the package was an increase in the fringe benefits tax payable in respect of cars. From the outset the review was hamstrung by the fact that it was stipulated that the review had to be revenue neutral. That being the case, those reductions which were warranted on the grounds of reducing compliance costs could only be purchased at the price of paying additional tax, in this case additional tax falling in relation to motor vehicles.

PARA.TAB: The conduct of the review itself will give some indication as to what priority this government gives to reforming the monster it has created in respect of compliance costs under the fringe benefits tax. The Treasurer initially anticipated that the review would be completed in July of 1994 but it was not until seven months later, in February of 1995, that it was reported. The bill was not produced until June of 1995, over a year after the review was announced and three months after the new rules were due to take effect in April. Even then the results were not final. The changes have been made to the package in the bill itself. It is now September, and the legislation to implement the changes—changes which were supposed to be commenced in April of this year—is only now coming on for debate in this House.
In other words, five months after the changes were due to take effect, we have got around to debating the legislation to achieve it.

The government's position on the review is indeed indicative of its position on the tax generally. It has no real interest in the burden of compliance costs that its fringe benefits tax nightmare has put on business and particularly small business.

While we welcome some changes in the bill, it does not ameliorate the government's abysmal track record on the issue. The fringe benefits tax was introduced in 1986, some nine years ago, and since then its claws have stretched wider and wider—to car parking, to entertainment and, if Mr Dawkins had had his way, to business travel.

With every change to the FBT rules, estimates of the revenue that it brings in balloon further and further. The estimate for 1995-96 is $2.8 billion. Each time the rules change, the legislation becomes more complex, the compliance costs rise, but from the government's point of view the revenue increases.

Business is labouring under an unwieldy burden, an administrative nightmare. The Australian Tax Research Foundation report released in 1993 entitled, `The compliance costs of employment related taxation in Australia' estimated total compliance costs of the fringe benefits tax in 1989-90 at $128 million or 10.9 per cent of the tax revenue raised.

A report by Geoff Pope entitled, `Policy implications arising from compliance costs of taxation', Curtin University, estimated compliance costs of the FBT in 1990-91 at $134 million or 10.6 per cent of FBT revenue.

If we extrapolate to today's figures compliance costs of 10.9 per cent of the estimated revenue, in 1995-96 the compliance costs would be around $300 million. That is just more than the amount that it was estimated the whole tax would have raised in its first year of operation.

But what is more important is that the Pope analysis shows that FBT compliance costs hit small business very hard indeed. In 1990-91 compliance costs were 42.1 per cent of the FBT paid by these businesses.

It is small business that does not have the accountants and the lawyers, the shielding professions, that bears the brunt of the complex and complicated arrangements that the government has put in place.
These studies do not even take into account the onerous compliance costs associated with car parking and entertainment benefits dragged into the FBT net subsequent to those studies.

Employers and their advisers have made it abundantly clear to the government that the rules are complex and the compliance costs severe, but the government has taken very little notice, blinded by the revenue gains.
So it was in February of 1995 that the Treasurer announced the results of his review, claiming with his customary public relations verve:

SPEECH.PARA: The measures I am announcing today will dramatically reduce compliance costs for employers liable for FBT.
But `dramatically reduce' was, of course, a gross overestimation. The explanatory memorandum itself admits that certain measures will increase compliance costs.

PARA.TAB: A survey of the top 100 companies revealed there would be minimal savings as a result. Even as the Canberra Times reported in March of 1995:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . employers will now have no less than three options on how to calculate FBT on employee entertainment costs. Take your pick, it will only take a week per year to calculate the most favourable method of ascertaining FBT on entertainment costs.
The Treasurer's message was clear—that as the price for such changes as he introduced, revenue would remain neutral by increasing the fringe benefits tax on cars.

PARA.TAB: The results were not widely embraced by professional and business communities. Many saw the review for what it truly was. Bob Jeffery, the national president of the Australian Society of CPAs, said this:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the so-called review of FBT has turned out to be just a thinly veiled exercise to appease genuine business concerns while still slugging business to raise the same amount of money.
Mr Bob Bryant, the executive director of the Corporate Tax Association, said:
What he handed down in our view was not a serious attempt to come to grips with the inadequacies of the FBT regime. He has really let us down.
And indeed he did. Mr David Taylor, the chief executive of the New South Wales Chamber of Commerce, said:

. . . no business, small or big, will benefit from this. All the Government has done is admit it has made hideous errors with FBT. Small business may have a few less forms to fill in, but the underlying problems with FBT and the difficulties caused are still there.
A Business Review Weekly article said:
The new rules exempt a few trinkets from the tax net, but lift the rate on the big-ticket items. The result of this supposed generosity? A windfall for the Government.

Like business, the accounting professions and those who actually deal with the fringe benefits tax, the coalition is extremely dissatisfied with this outcome. After months of discussions and submissions, the government laboured so long for so little. What was most intriguing was that the estimates of loss of revenue from car parking and after-hours taxi travel changes matched, to the dollar, the estimated revenue gained from increasing the statutory fractions on cars where employers used the statutory formula. This is particularly interesting, given that it is so simple to estimate the gain in revenue from increasing the FBT on cars. How was it that they were so precise in estimating the loss of revenue in relation to changes on car parking and after-hours taxi travel?

PARA.TAB: It is, of course, a happy coincidence for the government that the estimates of revenue gains and losses are identical. It is a happy coincidence for the government, but of course an assessment not shared by independent valuations. A survey of the top 100 companies, for example, came to a very different conclusion. They said that the so-called improvements to the FBT, taking the package as a whole, would in fact cost their companies FBT in addition of $28.7 million annually.

What business wants is lower compliance costs so that they do not spend all their time trying to work out what they have to pay to the Taxation Office. It is not so much what has to be paid but the additional cost of trying to work out how it actually has to be paid and how it has to be assessed.

It is the government imposed time involved which takes them away from their real business, which produces goods and services and jobs, that people are complaining about. It is about understanding the predicament that small business and business generally is in. The government shows a lack of understanding as to the difficulties of people who are not tax accountants and lawyers. It may be shopkeepers or service providers who are brought into this net and instructed, as a result of the complexity, that they may have to sit down on a Sunday afternoon and do this or take a week off management time and try to assess it. It is they who, at the end of the day, just feel that it is a burden and a drag on the business. In the end, of course, it is anti-employment.

Employers are complaining about the way in which the government shows little or no understanding of the predicament in which they find themselves. Even the Treasurer, when he was questioned about this in the parliament, said this in justification of the increase in the statutory formula in relation to cars:

SPEECH.PARA: Those opposite think it is fine for there to be this kind of loophole for people in well-paid positions to be able to get these large fringe benefits in a way which is only very lightly taxed under the present arrangements . . . It pays for the other very worthwhile changes.

The Treasurer's justification for all of this was that his previous regime, the regime which is currently operating in relation to cars, was what—a loophole? Has he been operating a loophole with lightly taxed statutory formula hitherto? In fact, does he really believe that he is justified in putting up the statutory formula to close that loophole? Of course he does not believe that.

PARA.TAB: It is poor justification to try to rip out extra revenue to offset losses in relation to changes which should never have been implemented in the first place. That is the reality. When the government took off measures which should never have been implemented in the first place, it took the opportunity to compensate itself with measures which were totally unwarranted. The Treasurer's justification in relation to this, like so many of his justifications, shows no real appreciation of the real world or of the impact on the business community.

To him it is just a question of getting as much money as he can. There is no conception in his mind of harmonising a tax policy to economic policy generally; no conception in his mind that tax is an instrument of policy that must be harmonised to economic development, to job creation and to economic growth. For him it is essentially a business backed by the government to extract money in order to maximise profit.

This bill provides employers with two optional methods for determining their FBT liability on the cost of meal entertainment benefits to employees. The methods are a fifty-fifty split and a 12-week register. Many employers who adopt the fifty-fifty split method may pay more FBT than if they base their calculations on actual expenditure. Under the fifty-fifty method employers halve their total meal expenditure. Fifty per cent will be subject to FBT and the remainder will be non-deductible to the employer. This method totally ignores whether the expenditure would be deductible for income tax purposes, and the taxable value of meal entertainment expenditure cannot be reduced by employee contributions or under the `otherwise deductible' rule.

Where an employer elects to use the 12-week register method, it is entitled to claim a deduction for meal entertainment equal to the amount of the expense multiplied by the register percentage. The register percentage is the ratio of total value of meal entertainment fringe benefit to total value of meal entertainment expenses. The employer must keep the register for 12 continuous weeks. The period must be representative of meal entertainment patterns over the year. For most employers, especially small businesses, the Christmas period would not be representative and, in any event, a new register must be kept every five years unless total meal expenditure is more than 20 per cent higher than in the year the register was first kept—bear in mind that this is simplification.

The bill clarifies that corporate boxes are not `business premises' of the employer, with the result that food and drink consumed by employees and their associates on those premises will be subject to FBT. It also enables employers to apply the fifty-fifty method to the leasing and hiring of corporate boxes and other similar hospitality arrangements to determine what amount will be subject to FBT. The fifty-fifty option, while very simple, only applies to meal entertainment and not to recreation so that, as a consequence, where you have a Christmas party followed by a cruise you have got to separate meal and recreation costs.

The bill also aims to introduce some certainty in relation to living away from home allowances. An allowance will only be a living away from home allowance fringe benefit where the total period for which the employee has lived, or is required to live, away from his or her home is less than 12 months where Australian residents are posted within Australia or two years if the employee is posted to a remote location. The maximum residence period for employees working in Australia on temporary work permits and Australian residents posted overseas is four years.

The changes increase compliance costs by requiring declarations by both the employer and the employee in order for an allowance to qualify as a living away from home allowance fringe benefit. For the first time employers will be required to provide declarations which will duplicate employee declarations. A further problem is that, before the taxable value can be reduced for accommodation, the amounts actually spent on accommodation need to be substantiated. This will also increase compliance costs for employers and may be difficult, if not impossible, where the allowance is paid pursuant to awards.

The bill changes the benefits which accrue or apply in relation to fly-in fly-out where the employee's usual place of employment is an oil rig or another remote location and the employee returns to his usual place of residence on scheduled days off. The new rules introduce more certainty about when an employee is considered to be living away from home, but they do impose arbitrary time frames which may not be suited to arrangements in particular industries, such as the construction industry, or for arrangements of particular employers.

The 12-month/four-year time frame creates numerous inequalities. The Corporate Tax Association has argued that there is no justification for different treatment of employees required to move within Australia to employees transferred overseas. One adverse effect is that employers who elect to transfer foreign residents rather than Australian residents will be penalised.

Another aspect of the bill is the treatment in relation to car parking. FBT will no longer apply to car parking benefits unless a commercial station within a one-kilometre radius of employer-provided car parking facilities charges at least $5 per day on the first day of the FBT year. Whilst FBT will now generally be payable only on car parking benefits in CBD areas as a result of this change, it does discriminate between employers in CBDs and those in outlying suburbs and regional centres.

The insertion of a $5 threshold without indexation may result in the exemption for car parking in regional centres being short lived. The coalition will be supporting this measure but will be moving an amendment to index the $5 figure in line with CPI rises. In other words, you should not lose the benefit of the $5 by reason of the creep of inflation. I urge the government to accept that amendment. There is no reason why it would not do so, except a rapacious revenue appetite. All that will do is preserve that $5 threshold in terms of inflation.

The bill gives employers an extra optional way to value car parking benefits. Under the average lowest cost method, the taxable value is to be determined by calculating the average of the lowest fees charged by any operator of a commercial car parking station within a one-kilometre radius on the first and last days of the FBT year. The value is reduced by the recipient's contribution towards the benefit. The average cost method is simple and will reduce compliance costs for employers. However, it makes FBT planning and remuneration planning difficult since the average lowest cost cannot be determined until the end of the FBT year. You have to wait for the last day before you have a clear idea of the average cost, which makes planning difficult.

Employers are also given two extra ways to calculate the total taxable value of car parking benefits provided in a year. Under the first of these—the statutory formula method—the taxable value for each space is calculated by multiplying the statutory number of days, 240, by the daily rate amount. Unfortunately, in setting the statutory number of days at 240, the government has ignored public holidays, rostered days off, long service leave and days that employees may be away on business.

The coalition will be moving an amendment to reduce the statutory number to 228 to take into account 12 national public holidays. Again, I urge the government to accept using the statutory formula method. In using the number of working days to get the benefit we should take into account the number of days that are likely to be worked, excluding public holidays. I urge the government to take that into account and to accept the coalition's amendment. Alternatively, there is another method where a 12-week register is kept for a representative period. The new register must be kept every five years or where the number of car parking spaces increases by more than 10 per cent in a year.

The car parking measures in the bill may reduce compliance costs associated with car parking, but that is because the car parking application of fringe benefits tax has been ludicrous. It is also important that the $5 threshold be representative. It is also important, as I have said before, that that be indexed for inflation. The 12-week register method is less onerous than keeping records for the full year. But, as the Taxation Institute of Australia says, the 12-week register imposes another onerous obligation. It argues that the matters to be included in the register are too onerous. Employers still need to undertake a new register when the number of spaces increases by more than 10 per cent in a year. It cannot be kept over a Christmas period, which might not be representative with staff on holidays, and again it will lead to difficult account keeping requirements.

Bear in mind that all of these account keeping requirements are necessary so you can work out how much tax you have to pay the government for providing a benefit to an employee. The fringe benefits tax is all about how much tax an employer should pay to the government for the privilege of providing a benefit to an employee. That is what it is about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think the employee should pay?
—Have you ever employed anybody?
—Yes.
—Did you keep these records?
—The fringe benefits tax wasn't in then.
—So you did not keep them. If you had kept them, you might have realised the unnecessary burden that your government imposes in relation to these sorts of requirements. It is an absolute nightmare.

PARA.TAB: You try to create jobs and the government says, `We want you to keep all of these records so you can pay us for the benefits that are being provided.' It is an absolute nightmare. We have a Treasurer who has no comprehension at all. We ought to stick this Treasurer in a small business for three months and ask him to try to run it. I suggest that he buy a sandwich shop.

The bill also finally restores some sense to the FBT rules by exempting mobile phones, car phones, protective clothing, briefcases, calculators, tools of trade, electronic diaries, notebook computers and laptop computers, employee subscriptions to trade or professional journals, corporate credit card membership fees and airport lounge membership fees. Unfortunately, items such as fax machines, executive phones, answering machines and modems are not included in the list of exempt items, but perhaps they should be.

The items now being exempted should never have been subject to FBT in the first place. Little or no tax is being collected on these items, and often the compliance costs were greater than the FBT collected. As a result of the changes, employers who provide only minor fringe benefits will no longer be concerned with FBT in respect of these items, which is a positive result. Greed appears to have been the only fathomable excuse for the application of FBT on these items in the first place. The number of declarations that employees must submit to employers will also be reduced by the exempt status.

The bill changes the arrangements in relation to taxi travel provided to employees for travel directly between work and home between 8 p.m. and 6 a.m. and taxi travel provided for sick or injured employees to travel from work to their usual place of residence. The exemption extends to taxi travel between work and home via a doctor's surgery or other place of treatment. It also extends to travel from work to a place where the employee can get care—for example, a relative's home.

There is some sense in these amendments because employers will no longer be required to keep records to determine the taxable value for FBT purposes of taxi travel between 8 p.m. and 6 a.m.—that is, keep a record of when people actually travel by taxi in order to work out how much tax they must remit to the government for providing the taxi fare. But you do not have to keep the records, this government says out of the generosity of its heart, for the time between 8 p.m. and 6 a.m. because it may not be that much of a benefit to travel in a taxi at that time. We will be moving an amendment to modify the hours of the exemption to be from 7 p.m. to 7 a.m. to take account of the commercial realities. We urge you to take that into account when the debate comes on in the detailed stage.

The estimated cost to revenue of this measure is $45 million in 1995-96 and $30 million in each later year. Obviously many employees are given taxi travel for safety reasons. They might be asked to work back and it is unsafe for them to get on the train. But if they are kept back, given a taxi voucher and they leave before 8 p.m., this government says you have to pay a tax on the value of the taxi travel because it is such a lucrative benefit to the employee. This is how ridiculous the government's tax treatment has got. The bill also provides for recurring fringe benefits declarations, which I will not go into.

These measures will, with the exception of the living away from home allowance changes, commence on 1 April this year. As I said, we are debating legislation to apply changes which were supposed to have come in five months ago.

There is a big difference between the government and the coalition on the fringe benefits tax. When the Treasurer was asked whether these were the last changes we would see to the FBT, on 24 February 1995, he replied, `Well, I would certainly hope so.' Let me tell you that we do not believe these are the last changes that should be made to the fringe benefits tax. We do not believe that this is a successful review. We do not believe that this does anything serious in relation to compliance costs. We do not believe that this is the best taxation system that we can give business, including small business. We do not believe that compliance costs of this order are justifiable. We do not believe that these should be the last changes to the fringe benefits tax.

We will make sure that the fringe benefits tax has all of those stupid compliance costs rules taken out and that there is some understanding of the harnessing of the tax system to business and economic development. We will make sure that anti-employment compliance costs of the dimension that this government delights in are changed.

The fringe benefits tax—the costs of compliance, the utter inappropriateness of the way in which this government has managed its review—demonstrates the great differences between the coalition and the government. It is one of those things that will be attended to and fixed when the government of this country changes.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. N.B. Reid)—Is the amendment seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

—I suppose that people listening to the shadow Treasurer—probably the second most important job in the opposition—will be disappointed to learn that, notwithstanding all the rhetoric of his comments and some of the amendments he has proposed, the people of Australia really do not have a very clear view of what the opposition will precisely do with the FBT.

PARA.TAB: I tried by interjection to get some clarification, when he was complaining about businesses paying this tax on behalf of employees, about whether it was opposition policy that the tax should be transferred to the employees and they should pay it. I am sure the Hansard record will show that I was unable to elicit a response that would enable me to conclude that that position was false. So it is a clear warning—not overtly stated but covertly stated—that opposition policy is that they are dissatisfied with the FBT. They are concerned about the imposts on business. Their approach will be to transfer this from employers who currently pay it to employees. That is sad news for the people of Australia.

We can have no intelligent discussion about FBT unless we understand the history of it. Indeed, the shadow Treasurer was gleefully pointing out that there was an occasion when FBT was not paid. That is true. It is the Labor government, of course, which has introduced it. Let me explain why. The reason is very simple. If you are an ordinary Australian, man or woman, maybe a young person, and you have got a job, you pay full tax on your earnings. Your employer deducts it and it goes straight to the taxation department.

Many members in this House will recall that, under the previous regime of John Howard—then Treasurer, now Leader of the Opposition and the alternative Prime Minister—it was possible to claim things like entertainment. It was well known that the senior executives, not the workers, would go out and entertain their clients. Not only did they entertain their clients but they also entertained their families. Sometimes they did not even bother to have clients at those lunches and dinners. It was a haemorrhage on revenue.

I am not ideological about this. If this had been an even-handed approach where big managers and high-powered executives were able to enjoy these benefits, and ordinary workers were also able to enjoy them, maybe that would have been fair enough. But that was not the case; it was all one-sided. In fact, we saw more and more executive salaries being put into non-cash benefits and less into cash benefits, so there were things like cars, houses, entertainment and school fees. All of these were non-cash benefits being paid for by the employer—no tax was paid by the employer for it and no tax was paid by the employee, the hot-shot executive, for it. But old muggins, Mr and Mrs Average, Mr and Mrs Ordinary Worker, were paying every last cent of tax on the money they were earning.

We never hear an apology from those opposite about this being a rort and an outrage and that it was haemorrhaging the tax system. There has been not one apology from those opposite. But, here in this House, and indeed in the Senate, they will get up and lecture us, as the shadow Treasurer did. He did not say too much about what opposition policies were and he did not say what direction they will take or what major changes they will make, but he did lecture us. Those opposite say things like, `It is the compliance cost', and there is a compliance cost. They say, `This is onerous on small business', and it is onerous on small business. But can anyone tell me of a taxation system that is not complex or onerous? What humbug that is coming from the shadow Treasurer—a skilled lawyer, like all those hired guns, the lawyers and accountants, who do nothing more than pore over tax law to find a loophole.

When the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, was Treasurer, it was an utter disgrace. We had all sorts of schemes being dreamed up by the shadow Treasurer's colleagues in the legal and accounting professions. We had bottom-of-the-harbour schemes, cherry-picking schemes, you name it. It was seen as legitimate to pay little or no tax but, as I say, ordinary workers, ordinary Australians, young apprentices and people going into their first jobs were paying their full measure. There were no opportunities for them to shirk or avoid it. So it is absolute humbug on the part of the shadow Treasurer when he walks in here and says, `Look, there is a compliance cost; we are concerned about the compliance cost'. Of course we too on this side are concerned about the compliance cost, but we want integrity, equity and fairness in the taxation system. Did anyone hear any of those words used by the shadow Treasurer? He would not know what they meant.

The shadow Treasurer said that the Treasurer, Mr Willis—who is, some say, probably technically one of the best Treasurers this country has ever seen, bearing in mind I am the member for Chifley, and Chifley was not too bad—does not have an understanding of the ability of the tax system to harmonise and promote growth. This came from the spokesman for the Leader of the Opposition. For so many wealthy in the community, paying tax was a theoretical construct when we had the highest marginal rate of taxation—60 per cent taxation.

In those days, we did not have our system of dividend imputation—said by many to be one of the best regimes of dividend imputation in the world. In those days, we did not have capital gains tax. If you do not have a capital gains tax you distort the decision making processes of investors out there in the community. We did not have it.

I notice the Liberal member for Kooyong (Mr Georgiou), who represents probably one of the wealthiest electorates in Australia, loves talking about the battlers. I am talking about my battlers in the electorate of Chifley—they are the true-blue variety; they are good people. They did not have an opportunity to benefit from capital gains tax, but that was okay by the Leader of the Opposition and apparently okay by the shadow Treasurer. They talk about this need to harmonise the tax system to encourage employment growth. With great respect, I need to point out that in this Labor government's term of office, since the 1993 election, the economy has actually grown by some 600,000 jobs.

I was pleased to recently represent the parliament, along with the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney), by going over to some European capitals and trying to confront the French about their nuclear testing. One of the things I can honestly report to the House is that European countries envy the steps and reforms taken by this government. They would love to stand up in their national assemblies or their various parliaments and say, `Look, on a per capita basis, we are doing as well as Australia and Australia has 600,000 employment growth.' They would love it. They dream about it. They have all sorts of task forces and are developing new policies to try to emulate our performance.

Here we have the shadow Treasurer getting up and saying, `Look, our Australian Treasurer does not understand the tax system. There is a real need to harmonise the tax system to promote employment growth.' What nonsense and humbug coming from the opposition. Another comment that he made—and I apologise, Mr Deputy Speaker, that I seem to take so much umbrage at the shadow Treasurer, but I am sure many people listening to him would be sadly disappointed—was that this government has a rapacious revenue appetite. He says it as though we are some sort of three-headed monster that has got Australia to record levels of revenue and somehow the taxation burden in Australia is extraordinarily high.

You do not have to take my word for it. If you look at the list of OECD countries, you will find that there is only one country with a lower taxation regime than Australia and that is Turkey. Of all the developed countries that belong to the OECD—countries like America, Canada, the UK, France, Sweden and Norway; the list is pretty extensive—we have the second lowest taxation regime. How fundamentally dishonest it is to use the rhetoric of rapacious revenue appetite. My understanding of the changes to the fringe benefits tax is that they are designed to be revenue neutral. We really are not trying to take any more.

One other thing I wanted to pick up on was the shadow Treasurer's comment, `These measures came into force in April, with the exception of one, and look how much time has passed.' I know it has been said before, but I think if these statements keep on being repeated you have to respond to them.

It is the case that the Labor government has never enjoyed a majority in the Senate. Unlike other parliaments—such as the UK parliament—the opposition, in concert with other parties in the Senate, demands that what would be delegated legislation under the Westminster system must be legislation under ours. That is why we have the extraordinary volume of legislation that is required to go through the House.

I suggest to the shadow Treasurer, if we are interested in parliamentary micro-economic reform, that he talk to his colleagues in the Senate so that we can limit the amount of legislation that goes through. Probably in this House it is afforded greater scrutiny than I admit we have time for because of the volume of legislation. We should have other matters going through as delegated legislation, as would occur in other parliaments.

Of course, there are some departments which put through an extraordinary amount of legislation. Taxation is one of them. It is not because we have these little gnomes in Taxation dreaming up what bit of legislation they can put through; it is because they have to seriously respond to accountants, to lawyers, to judgments of the court where there are changes required to—

TALK.START.PARA: —And to correcting their earlier mistakes.

—I am happy to concede, on occasions to correct mistakes. Of course that is the case. That is the reason. I wonder whether, given my colleague's new independent status, he is prepared to take a broader view of these issues in terms of parliamentary reform.
—It will be very considered, whatever it is.

—That is true. It would be a great disappointment for the House not to hear the dulcet tones of the member giving us his contributions on taxation measures. I do not particularly want to go through all the provisions of the Taxation Laws Amendment (FBT Cost of Compliance) Bill because the shadow Treasurer really recited the general outline of the changes; so it would be repetitious. But I confess to having one FBT area of great interest; that is, as it applies to northern Australia. As far as personal income tax is concerned, there are zone allowances. In other words, the taxation system already provides some form of encouragement or subsidisation for those people living in north Australia.

PARA.TAB: Whilst we will probably never see northern Australia with a population as great as the eastern seaboard or southern Australia, I believe it is consistent to have a look at the impact in northern Australia of the FBT and whether or not some measures have the effect of discouraging the employment of people in northern Australia, where it is extraordinarily difficult to attract people—you have to provide a whole array of facilities for them.

I know, for example, that there have been some changes in the living away from home allowance for those fly-in fly-out operations. I think, incidentally, that fly-in fly-out is rather sad because you are depriving that community of the rest of the family. There is a two-year provision on that.

I want to say that I strongly support these measures. I strongly support the idea that the tax system should be fair and that ordinary Australians, Mr and Mrs Averages in my electorate, should not be unfairly treated; that is, they know they pay their last penny in tax based on their earnings whereas some may not. We do not want to revert to the previous system of high marginal rates which were more illusory than real or to go back to the bottom of the harbour episodes. We do not want to go back to having brothels run out of the Perth Taxation Office. We do not want to see loopholes, as existed prior to the FBT, and we do not want to see the loopholes that existed when there was no capital gains tax.

In the event that those opposite win the election, I ask them to tell the people of Australia what they propose to do about the taxation system. What is the opposition going to do about FBT? The shadow Treasurer seemed to imply that the opposition is going to remove the burden of paying this tax from the bosses and the employers and place it on the employees. I know that this is a long-held and cherished view of the opposition. This morning I was surprised when the shadow Treasurer did not deny this when I interjected. I strongly support this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) calls on the coalition to let him and his colleagues know what it may do in the area of taxation reform—particularly in relation to the fringe benefits tax. I remind him that it took Labor two years—until 1985—to come up with this piece of revenue raising taxation. There was not one word about it in the Labor Party's policy at the elections in 1983 and 1984.

PARA.TAB: Is the honourable member asking that we should do something which his party did not advocate at those times? It really is fallacious. I notice that the honourable member is very supportive of the legislation and the underlying principles behind it, but then he goes on to say, `Perhaps we should not be too hard in applying the fringe benefits tax in certain areas of northern Australia.' Even he is not happy. Admittedly, he did not rant and rave and he was not strident in his comments, but there is a whole lot to be concerned with. The member for Chifley is only concerned with northern Australia. The coalition and I have far wider concerns.

The Taxation Laws Amendment (FBT Cost of Compliance) Bill 1995 was introduced into the House on 28 June. This bill is important because it is supposed to reduce the burdensome costs of complying with the fringe benefits tax. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would recall that the government announced a review of the compliance costs of the fringe benefits tax in last year's budget. In so doing, Labor finally gave lip-service to the fact that the FBT net is cast in such a wide fashion that the cost of compliance is exorbitant.

However, with this particular piece of legislation Labor has shown that it still has very little interest in real reform but is instead pre-occupied with milking the fringe benefits tax system for as much as it can. The review not only is a disappointment to me, but has totally frustrated tax professionals who were inclined to believe the government's rhetoric. Labor has missed a golden opportunity to review the merits of the FBT policy, rather than just tinkering around the edges as this legislation intends to do.

It is now recognised that the fringe benefits tax, when first introduced, was intended to ensure that all forms of remuneration were to be taxed on a logical and consistent basis. The government claims that the FBT has been extremely successful in achieving that objective, yet what they do not tell us is that they have accomplished this by massive overkill. The FBT has grown way beyond what was originally intended, which was to close a relatively small tax loophole. It was to tax those benefits which were substituted for employment related income, pure and simple. Since then the FBT laws have become a millstone around the neck of the business community.

Where the government sees the FBT achieving equity and efficiency in the tax system, those affected see the administrative nightmare more focused on revenue raising as opposed to good tax law. When the government announced its review of fringe benefits taxes, the business community hoped that Labor had finally recognised there is a real need for reform of this particular impost. The review was a response to complaints from business that the FBT generates excessive paperwork costs for the private sector and that the impost has become an unintended source of revenue in many respects.

Ms Annamaria Carey of the tax institute was quoted in the Canberra Times of 25 January as saying `most people think the FBT is just a way of raising additional tax revenue'. That is very typical of people in professional organisations. In 1986-87, the first year that the tax applied, the government collected $535 million with the fringe benefits tax. By 1989-90, the FBT take had increased to $1.2 billion. In the 1994-95 budget the government estimated that it would garner FBT revenue to the tune of $3.2 billion—though this has been revised now to $2.7 billion—and $2.8 billion for 1995-96. Obviously this tax is no fiscal slouch. It appears, though, that Labor just cannot get the message. Simple laws are required to make the FBT regime fair, uncomplicated and cheaper to comply with. Labor has failed to meet even its own objectives, let alone those set for the government by the wider community.

On 24 February this year the Treasurer (Mr Willis) announced this package of measures, resulting from the government's review of the FBT compliance costs. Unfortunately, the announcement was too long in the pipeline. This review offers little hope that the government is taking the issue of tax simplification seriously. The FBT legislation was expected to have been introduced into this House at a much earlier date. As the shadow Treasurer has pointed out, it is to apply retrospectively in most respects from 1 April this year. To debate a bill almost six months after it is supposed to have application is a disgrace. The government seems to assume that this bill will pass through the parliament without amendment. But what happens if it is amended? It has happened before. Where is the certainty in the law?

The bill reduces some compliance costs associated with car parking, taxi travel, entertainment and living away from home allowances. The government will, however, increase the tax on employer provided cars to 10 per cent to offset the expected losses in revenue. But the real issue is the cost of compliance. Michael Evans of KPMG was quoted in the Australian Financial Review of 29 July commenting specifically on this bill:

SPEECH.PARA: It's evidence of the complexity of our tax system that an attempt to cut the cost of compliance for companies adds another 60 pages to our FBT law.

Any sizeable increase in the size—that is the wording—of tax legislation will, as a matter of course, add to the cost of compliance. It is axiomatic. When the FBT Assessment Act was last consolidated on 31 December 1991, it was 293 pages long. Since then, there have been 16 FBT amendment bills and two additional statutory rules. The act is now well over 300 pages long. It is no surprise that since 1991 the cost of compliance has been continuously escalating. The cost of compliance, along with the spread of the FBT, comprise the most insidious aspects of the tax.

PARA.TAB: The fact remains that since 1987 through to the 1996-97 FBT year there will have been six different fringe benefits tax rates. These constant changes only add to the exorbitant costs of complying with the FBT. Businesses face a cost of more than $1 billion each year in compliance costs. Of these costs, it is clear that the fringe benefits tax is one of the greatest contributors. In 1989-90 the compliance cost for the fringe benefits tax was something like $128 million, which was 10.2 per cent of the total fringe benefits tax revenue of $1.2 billion. This 10.2 per cent applied to the 1990-91 FBT year. Since then the impost has been applied to entertainment and car parking. You do not have to be a genius to expect that this percentage will now be much higher.

The time employers spent complying with the fringe benefits tax laws was annually an average of 1,100 hours. That equates to a half-time worker for the typical firm subject to the fringe benefits tax. The compliance costs for employers' PAYE was $629 million, which was only 1.4 per cent of the total gross PAYE tax revenue. For payroll tax the compliance cost was $206 million. Australian businesses spent up to 11 times more than companies in the United Kingdom complying with their direct tax obligations. Analysis shows that in 1990-91 96 per cent of companies on average in Australia incurred higher compliance costs, of $10,139, than they remitted in income tax, which is an average of $7,079.

Naturally enough, compliance costs are higher for small business. Small firms with a turnover of under half a million dollars spend on average three per cent of their turnover complying with taxation rules compared with 0.02 per cent of turnover of companies with a turnover in excess of $50 million. So it is that compliance costs unfairly discriminate against small business.

I mentioned earlier that the FBT legislation in Australia is well over 300 pages long. Compare with this with the situation in New Zealand. The New Zealand fringe benefits tax provisions are not part of a separate act but are instead divided between two different tax acts. However, the sections dealing with fringe benefits tax only come to approximately 51 pages, as against well over 300 in Australia. It should, therefore, be of no surprise that the cost of complying with the FBT is far lower in New Zealand. The Institute of Policy Studies in New Zealand conducted a study of business tax entitled `The compliance cost of business taxes in New Zealand', published in 1992. Chapter 5 deals with New Zealand's fringe benefits tax and opens with the following paragraph, which I feel puts the FBT and any comparison with New Zealand in some context. It states:
This method of taxing fringe benefits is unusual.

The usual way is to impose a charge on the value of the benefit in the hands of the employee paid by the employee, at his/her marginal tax rate (although the employers will normally be required to furnish the tax authorities with details of the benefits).

Of the OECD countries, and possibly of all countries, only New Zealand and Australia tax employers for the fringe benefits they provide to employees; New Zealand was the first country to adopt this system.

SPEECH.PARA: The survey found that the FBT compliance cost in New Zealand was 1.73 per cent of the total revenue collected. How does that compare with Australia? As I mentioned earlier, the cost of FBT compliance in Australia is 10.2 per cent. This is almost six times the cost of compliance in New Zealand.

PARA.TAB: What is also interesting, however, is that the compliance costs for PAYE in Australia and New Zealand are 1.4 per cent and 1.9 per cent respectively, yet there is such a large discrepancy between the FBT compliance costs. Obviously there is a need to simplify the FBTs in Australia to make them more concise, easier to understand and less expensive to comply with. The irony is that the New Zealand government with less legislation and lower compliance costs, actually garners more revenue from its FBT on a per capita basis than the Australian government.

I turn now to some of the detail in the bill because it covers a fair few clauses and I will not have time to deal with all of them. The bill amends the Fringe Benefits Tax Administration Act 1986 and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. It is supposed to reduce the costs of complying with the fringe benefits tax. It makes changes to the treatment of entertainment, living away from home allowance, car parking, FBT exemption for certain other benefits, taxi travel provided to employees, section 65 rebate for medical research bodies, declarations, car benefits as against the statutory formula, and substantiation rules and retention of records.

The changes to entertainment now allow employers to choose one of three methods to determine their FBT liability. There is a fifty-fifty split, with half being subject to FBT and the remainder being non-deductible to the employer; a 12-week register to gauge the FBT exposure of the employer; and the option of determining the FBT liability on actual entertainment expenditure over 12 months. This measure is unnecessary, because the government, if it were really serious about reducing compliance costs, would exclude entertainment from the fringe benefits tax and remove the deductibility of entertainment expenses.

The fifty-fifty split also appears to be unrealistic though. The Corporate Tax Association makes the valid point that the fifty-fifty split should be used as a standard, but where a difference can be justified it should be allowed.

Both the measures relating to car parking benefits and taxi travel provided to employees are expected to cost the government $76 million and $45 million respectively in 1995-96. Yet to maintain this so-called revenue neutrality, Labor has jacked up the statutory fractions used in the statutory formula to determine the taxable value of a car benefit. Funnily enough though, this increase will gain the government $121 million in 1995-96, which is exactly what it loses by the changes relating to car parking and taxi travel. There is no reason for the government to increase the fraction rate, except to recoup revenue forgone in making alternations which are plainly warranted anyway and on their own merits.

The changes outlined in this bill are not concessions, but are long overdue improvements and corrections to bring the legislation more into line with its original intent. The government has proved its critics right once again. Fringe benefit taxes are not about equity but about revenue. The draft taxation ruling TR95/D13 confirms that.

Consider these as a couple of examples. An organisation sets up a promotional stand at the Royal Perth Show which is open to the public and at which food and drink are consumed. If any food or drink is consumed by an employee, whether he is working on the stall or otherwise, then FBT is payable. This would apply if an employee was not working, passed by the stand and downed a glass of wine as they went by, or probably a paper cup of wine.

When the employee entertains a person who is an employee of an associated company and is subsequently reimbursed, then an FBT liability accrues to the associated company. Where an employee is travelling and dines with a non-travelling employee or client and the employer pays for both meals, then the costs of the travelling employee's meal will be subject to FBT and deductible.

However, if the employer had only paid for the non-travelling employee's meal, it would not be subject to FBT and would still be deductible. Where is the logic in it all? In the first case, the meals are regarded by the Australian Taxation Office as entertainment but, in the second, are regarded as sustenance. The draft ruling defines entertainment as a diversion or amusement to the recipients, so do not smile when you are eating if there are ATO inspectors around.

The Corporate Tax Association makes the point that where a travelling employee dines with a fellow traveller they are not being amused but merely sustained. If they dine with a non-traveller and eat the same food in the same place with the same number of people present, they are, all of a sudden, being amused rather than sustained. I have been to meals with a lot of people—none of my colleagues present—where I have not been amused.

Regardless of who the traveller is eating with, they are being sustained first and foremost and not necessarily amused. Such definitions defy logic. Only the non-traveller who has a meal paid for is being entertained. Surely when the government announced the review of FBT the aim was supposed to be to reduce the cost of compliance while protecting the tax base and overall equity. It is clear that the review process has not been approached in an appropriate manner by the government. Commonsense should also prevail, and it is sadly lacking. The government should seriously examine the New Zealand model to achieve its stated goals. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I am a bit distressed at how unforgiving the modern Liberal Party is. During the previous speech, the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Pyne) was reading a paper and obviously paying no attention to the words of wisdom that were given to us. However, I am pleased to see that the departure from the Liberal Party of the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) has led to his acquiring a sense of humour. I look forward to more of the same for the remaining months that he will have in this place.

PARA.TAB: I would like to go through some of the details of the legislation that is designed to reduce compliance costs with respect to the fringe benefits tax. Firstly, with regard to entertainment, there is the provision to close loopholes to ensure, for example, that corporate boxes at sporting venues are not business premises and that, therefore, food and drinks consumed on those premises are subject to the fringe benefits tax. Secondly, there is a fifty-fifty split on entertainment costs to ensure that compliance costs are reduced.

The living away from home allowance is subject to technical changes in definition with respect to the food and accommodation that is exempt from the fringe benefits tax. It is intended to simplify the guidelines and, again, to reduce compliance costs. There is a simpler averaging formula provided for car parking in order to determine the value of the parking benefit. The fringe benefits tax will apply only where there is a commercial parking station which charges more than $5 per day within a one-kilometre radius of work. This will be a specific benefit to employers in regional areas, where generally such arrangements are not available and, therefore, fringe benefits tax will not apply.

Further, there will be an exemption of certain benefits from the fringe benefits tax. An example is car phones and mobile phones that are used almost exclusively or overwhelmingly for business purposes. Another exemption of particular importance for workers is taxis that are provided for either sick workers or workers who are leaving work later than 8 p.m., which is an award provision in many awards. Those taxi costs will be exempt from the fringe benefits tax. I certainly applaud that change.

The fringe benefits tax will be rebatable to non-government and non-profit medical research bodies currently engaged in research. Declarations will be available for the fringe benefits tax on employee declarations relating to mixed business and private use. There are some changes to the formula involved in calculating car benefits, which are again designed to reduce compliance costs. Finally, the substantiation rules have been amended in order to bring the fringe benefits tax legislation into line with the Income Tax Assessment Act general substantiation rules that apply to tax deductions.

All of these are intended to reduce compliance costs to make record keeping for business, including small business, simpler and less costly. As has been pointed out by previous speakers, this is the result of a review conducted by the government relating to compliance costs for business with respect to the fringe benefits tax. It is true, as the honourable member for Curtin outlined earlier, that taxation in this country, including the fringe benefits tax, is becoming increasingly complex. I will make some observations about that in a little while.

In the case of the fringe benefits tax, it is important to remember the background to the introduction of this tax. Perhaps before the honourable member for Curtin bleats too much about the damaging impact of the fringe benefits tax on costs on business, he might recall where the fringe benefits tax came from and why it emerged. Basically, it emerged because in the early to mid-1980s many businesses began to engage in outrageous tax avoidance activities designed to effectively increase salaries for their higher paid employees, particularly professional and managerial staff, and avoid tax, thereby, in effect, reducing their own salary burden in some fairly naked and blatant ways.

For example, we had situations where screen jockeys and the like in the financial markets in the mid-1980s were on salaries notionally of $25,000 a year but were receiving fringe benefits in excess of $100,000 a year that were at that stage not taxed. That is a fairly gross example of tax avoidance being pursued by the very companies that the honourable member for Curtin now seeks to defend.

Honourable members on the other side of the House should keep in mind what the origin of this tax was. It was introduced because the credibility and the integrity of the system was being eroded by the more outrageous avoidance mechanisms being pursued by many companies in Australia. That is why we have it. Ultimately, that is why it is becoming increasingly complex.

The majority of amendments to taxation laws that I see in this place are responses to new avoidance brainwaves that have been produced by somebody out there trying to undermine the taxation system and to erode the integrity of the tax system to avoid tax. Yes, we do have a problem with respect to the complexity of the taxation laws but we need to keep in mind where that problem has come from.

It is also worth keeping in mind that, at the time of the introduction of the fringe benefits tax, as commonly happens with changes in taxation, a lot of organisations were crying wolf about the likely impact of the changes. Plenty of people on the other side of this House were also asserting that extraordinary things would follow. The restaurant industry, which is a very important industry in my electorate, was going to collapse as a result of the fringe benefits tax because the hordes of businessmen who spent thousands and thousands of dollars on long lunches would suddenly disappear because those expenses would now be subject to taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot of them have.

—Perhaps you should come to Lygon Street in my electorate, which is probably the premier restaurant area in the country. If you compare it with the mid-1980s you would see that basically there is no difference and, if anything, the restaurant industry is healthier.
—What about a cafe latte?
—I would appreciate—

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. N.B. Reid)—I think the honourable member for Melbourne should concentrate on the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, could you perhaps point me to anything I have said that is not relevant to the bill?
—I think all interjections are disorderly and should be ignored.

—Thank you. I am doing my best, but it is a bit difficult with the level of yelling that has been occurring. I would perhaps point out to honourable members on the other side and to the new Independent member for Curtin that, with their deep concern about administrative costs for business with respect to taxation matters, this is the same party that was going to introduce a GST that would have had, amongst other nefarious impacts, a very serious effect on small businesses. It would have meant that your average person in small business would have spent hours every week doing paperwork and compiling documentation on the inputs and flowthrough of goods and services in their business in order to comply with the goods and services tax.

PARA.TAB: It is a bit amusing to hear some of the bleating that comes from people such as the honourable member for Curtin on these issues when we recall that at the last election the Liberal and National parties proposed a tax reform, so-called, that would have increased compliance costs on business in this country massively—out of all proportion to anything that business currently has to deal with. So it is something of an irony.

It is worth making a few broad observations on the tax system and some of the difficulties the system faces in the context of this legislation. Since the late 1970s, taxation has been demonised by conservative forces in most Western countries. We have seen things such as proposition 13 in California in 1978 and a proliferation of efforts to undermine the credibility and integrity of taxation as a legitimate part of a contemporary Western society. This is partly related to a proliferation of private choice options in advanced industrialised societies. As we have advanced into a range of different activities and different choices in leisure, luxuries and so on, there has been an increase in individualism in society and a desire for people to have greater control over their own expenditure and greater choice.

There are underlying economic reasons as to why this has occurred. But what we see is businesses, on the one hand, promoting, at vast cost, endless arrays of products which people often do not want and, on the other, telling people that they cannot afford to pay the tax that is necessary to sustain a decent health system or decent education system. In effect, there is a crowding out phenomenon with private greed crowding out necessary social expenditure in the public sector. We have the idea that taxes are in some sense a burden, that they are eaten up by the public sector, when in fact taxes are in essence the price that we all pay collectively for mostly essential goods and services provided, again collectively, through the public sector.

We have the idea that taxes inhibit freedom. In a general sense, taxation promotes and enhances freedom. If you would like a simple illustration of this, look at the arrangements in Australia under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, an eminently socialist arrangement, which I applaud. It ensures that the vast bulk of people in the community have access, at reasonable prices that are generally affordable, to essential drugs. If you think that is not important, try living in a country where even the most basic prescription costs $100 or more. That is what taxation is ultimately about: it is society collectively ensuring that all of its members have reasonable access to basic, essential things that are part of living in a modern community. Mostly it relates to things that do enhance freedom, such as transport, libraries, universities and hospitals. Ultimately, taxation is the glue that holds our community together, that ensures that we all live, in spite of the differences, inequalities and variations, in one society.

It is worth while recalling the work of Robert Reich in Work of Nations. He highlighted the growing problem in the United States of the separation of wealthier communities, professional suburban communities, from the vast bulk of the community where everything is being privatised. Health, education, public parks and almost everything associated with living is being privatised for the wealthy so there is a growing disparity in life, in existence, between the better off and the worse off to a point where the two worlds barely collide. I do not think anyone would like to see such a situation develop in this country. It does not exist now. Taxation and redistribution of wealth through the tax system are an important means of ensuring that does not occur.

There have been structural stresses on the tax system and these are growing. Internationalisation is obviously one. In a sense, our tax system is competing with those of other countries. Changes in the production process and technology are making it harder to tax. Advances like the Internet are going to produce phenomena which will make it even more difficult. The prospect of the development of an indigenous currency on the Internet and services being exchanged through the Internet internationally will make it very difficult to tax.

The rise of services in the economy is equally a problem. It is generally a lot easier and a lot more acceptable to the community to tax the exchange of goods, whereas it is a bit harder to keep track of exchange in services. As I mentioned before, individualism within the culture is also a problem. Avoidance and evasion of taxation since the 1970s has been fairly widespread in the community, facilitated and indeed encouraged by some extremely irresponsible judgments by the High Court under Sir Garfield Barwick, who is a very able and very diligent representative of a class in the community very aptly tagged by Geoffrey Barker as the resentful rich who resent the fact that they should have to pay any tax to anybody for anything.

The GST was initially proposed as an anti-tax avoidance measure, amongst other things, including its earlier variety—option C. One of the things we will increasingly recognise is that, as change occurs in our society, as increasingly services predominate, as we become internationalised, as computerisation becomes more predominant, the problems we have with avoidance of tax based on income are going to become just as difficult and just as prevalent with respect to avoidance of tax on expenditure. So I think the proposed advantage for shifting taxes to consumption is gradually going to disappear. When I studied taxation law, the Income Tax Assessment Act was roughly about four inches thick.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two inches thicker than when I started.
—I suspect the Minister for Justice may be able to help me here, but I think it may be getting close to a foot, and that is a problem. There is no question about that.

PARA.TAB: We are also seeing the leaching of progressivity out of the taxation system. That is an infinitely more significant problem. So we are seeing a reduction in the scales under governments of both persuasions: the full imputation of dividends; the abolition of inheritance taxes; the lowering of company taxes; the de facto privatisation of superannuation and pensions; the reduction of council rates; and the Hilmer process of competition policy, which is leading to an erosion of cross-subsidisation within utilities and equivalent organisations—all of which is reducing the overall progressivity of our tax system. That is something to which we need to give some consideration.

The reduction is not occurring purely as a result of political forces. There are underlying international economic forces which are driving a lot of these changes. It is an issue we need to address and be concerned about. I for one take no pride in the fact that Australia is the second lowest taxed country in the OECD.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not.
—I do not regard that as a badge of honour.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—Order! The member for Melbourne is entitled to be heard in silence. The member for Mitchell is anticipating the call, which will give him an opportunity to participate in the debate. I would appreciate his waiting for the call.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying, the issue of progressivity is one that we have to turn some attention to. We have to ask ourselves: do we, as virtually the entire Western world has done over the bulk of this century, still want to have a society based on the twin pillars of redistribution of income and wealth through the taxation system in order to ensure that pretty well everybody in our society has a basic standard of living, a minimum level of protection? Secondly, do we think essential goods and services, which everybody uses—defence, health, law and order, education, et cetera—should be exclusively or predominantly provided through the public sector, through collective activity or through the taxation system?

PARA.TAB: Those pillars have been the basis of Western industrial society certainly since the Depression, and they are under threat. They are being eroded. We have to ask ourselves whether we are still committed to progressivity, to redistribution and to collective provision of goods and services, which is a fundamental component of fairness and equity in our society. Australian politics, in recent times, has made it pretty difficult for people who want to reform the taxation system.

We have seen from both sides of politics some fairly effective scare campaigns on tax issues at elections. In the 1980 election, the Liberals were pretty good at convincing everybody that the Labor Party would introduce a capital gains tax that would do all sorts of things. At the 1993 election, of course, the Labor Party was pretty effective at persuading people that a GST was not such a good idea. So it will be very difficult to address a lot of these issues. It will be very complex. Ultimately, we will be forced to address the structure of our taxation system by a lot of these changes.

I hope sincerely that we will be able to maintain progressivity and redistribution as fundamental principles around the taxation system. It will get increasingly difficult to do so because of the forces that have been unleashed by technology, internationalisation and the like. We have to ask members on the other side, people in business and people representing the better-off in our community whether they still have a commitment to these things. Certainly, they did in the past. The Menzies government, for example, was committed to the notion of progressivity and social solidarity, underpinned by the tax system.

There are elements in the conservative forces in our society who are no longer committed to those things. We need to ask the opposition an important question: irrespective of argument about individual detail about whether the FBT is a burden on business and compliance costs or whatever, is there still a basic commitment to this principle? If there is not, we have a very serious problem in our community, and it is something that we need to be addressing in some considerable depth, beyond the sorts of scare campaigns and difficulties that we tend to get into.

I commend the legislation to the House. I have endeavoured to show that not only does this bill improve things with respect to compliance costs and the administration of the FBT, but the problems that we are experiencing with taxation in the community are not problems merely associated with the government. Broader forces are at play in these issues. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The true picture as to where Australia stands and the ineffectiveness of the Australian government are best summarised by the comments made by Sir Roger Douglas—the Labor Party minister who reformed the economy of New Zealand—in June of this year, as reported in the Weekend Australian of 3-4 June:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is living in fantasyland if it believes it can enter the 21st century without major economic reform . . .
Further, about the regime operated by the current Treasurer (Mr Willis) and Prime Minister (Mr Keating), he said:

PARA.TAB: "There is nothing more crude and brutal than a government that seeks electoral advantage by refusing to make economic reforms that are desperately needed" . . .

SPEECH.PARA: That summarises the attitude of members of the Australian Labor Party in the debate today.
