They can bring out the old cliches and trot out social equity, but at the end of the day and at the end of their speeches they agree that the tax regime is a mess and it is too costly to administer. But they refuse to take it to a point of effectively doing anything about it. So the criticisms made by Sir Roger Douglas in June are effective and correct. I repeat the criticisms: there is nothing more crude and brutal than a government that seeks electoral advantage by refusing to make economic reforms that are desperately needed.

PARA.TAB: This debate today is on the fringe benefits tax which applies to employers and the way in which they treat their employees. It is not a tax that worries the majority of Australians. We have seen the same attitudes of acknowledgment by members of the government of the need for change due to the massive cost of compliance that is limiting the capacity of small business. Nobody in the small business sector, or its representatives, is arguing for rejection and dismissal of the fringe benefits tax. They are saying, `Make it simpler for us. You are cutting down on our time available on the job. You are cutting down on the time that we can be effective in our businesses by loading on to us a regime that is impossible and crude.' As one of my colleagues said, it is costing approximately six times the amount of time and energy for businesses in Australia to administer this tax than it is to their colleagues in New Zealand to administer the same tax.

We have to be complicated and we have to be sure that those `horrible employers' are not running away with one cent. The horrible employers are saying, `Just give us a go. By making it simpler, we will pay whatever you want us to pay. We know we have to pay tax. We are not asking you to take the tax away; we are asking you to make it easier to administer so that we can use that time for making profits, for looking after staff or for employing more people.' They want to succeed. They regard all this government claptrap, rubbish, form filling and record keeping as counterproductive—and it is counterproductive at the end of the day because the objectives can be achieved in another way.
Sir Roger Douglas went on, by the way, to say that his reforms:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . had seen New Zealand start to outstrip Australia on economic growth, unemployment, inflation, fiscal and balance of payments measures.

PARA.TAB: "The financial markets are predicting a more successful economic performance for New Zealand than Australia" . . .

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian government has been criticised by a former Labour minister from New Zealand, and he is making sense. Speakers on the other side have acknowledged that the philosophy put forward by Sir Roger Douglas does make sense, but they are not prepared to do anything about it.

PARA.TAB: As a further part of the argument, I refer the House to a leading article in the Financial Review by an editor who wrote about the government's reforms in taxation. In the area of the fringe benefits tax, last Friday the editor said this:

SPEECH.PARA: By extending FBT to a wide range of minor benefits and, more important, imposing it on legitimate business entertainment, the Government has lost sight of the need to ensure that the tax system takes proper account of the legitimate costs of doing business in the real world, not just the very artificial world of the Canberra bureaucracy.

The review of the fringe benefits tax that has been undertaken by the government was done in an unreal world of the Canberra bureaucracy because, as they visited various representatives of business, the Canberra bureaucracy could not understand what life was like in Sydney or Melbourne or parts remote from Canberra. They are remote from the real business world. They are remote from where people work. They are remote from the circumstances, for instance, requiring women in large cities to take taxis home at night or when it is raining or when they are ill. They are remote from the concept that if a person has a mobile phone they will phone home and say, `I am delayed,' and they will use the phone that is handy to them, their mobile phone, which is a legitimate use.

PARA.TAB: If they have a laptop computer they will put their personal accounts on it if they are going to do a quick calculation. The government has been trying to draw the line between private and business use and has been asking business to keep a record of how many minutes have been spent on the mobile phone for private use and how many for business use, and the same with the laptop computer. Can you imagine anything so ridiculous as taking your laptop computer home and doing your accounts at the weekend and being asked to keep a record of how much time you spent on the laptop for your private as compared with your public use? The government is scrapping those two items, but it has put in place greater complexity.

Take the taxi item, for instance. Instead of saying that all taxis for staff are a fringe benefit, they are saying that only those taxis used between the hours of six in the morning and eight at night are a fringe benefit. But, if they use a taxi after dark, if they do not use it too regularly and if it is raining or they are sick, it is not a fringe benefit. Who in the world will keep those records? You have made the thing more complex, not simpler. The use of a taxi in these circumstances for employees going home from work now has two options. Was it in the daytime? If yes, fringe benefits is paid. Was it after dark? If no, no fringe benefits if you fulfil this formula, and you have to write it all down to see whether you are exempt from a fringe benefits tax. This is stupidity.

In the name of simplification—and that is the name of the legislation; it is the FBT simplification bill—you have made the thing more complex by giving people more options in the answer. Instead of ticking one box, they now have to tick two boxes, which leads to another two boxes, and before you know where you are you have a whole raft of options or answers that have to be complied with under the tax legislation.
I am interested to note in an article in the Financial Review on Friday, 15 September that Mr Michael Croker of Coopers and Lybrand said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the new bill abolished FBT on a number of items such as mobile phones and lap tops, but had otherwise done little to simplify compliance with FBT.
He went on to say:

PARA.TAB: In some respects it had even made compliance more complicated by increasing the record-keeping requirements for meals . . .

SPEECH.PARA: The journalists, press and business community of Australia are saying, `The government has got it wrong. The system is more complex and not as good as you are all saying it is.' It is not. It is going to be terrible out there for people to try to keep the records they require. An article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 17 September stated:
. . . Mr Willis, yesterday attacked the Opposition's proposal to reduce capital gains and fringe benefits tax . . .

We have not said those things. The Treasurer is out of his tree. He is responding to crazy comments. These comments were outlined by a previous speaker in this debate for the Labor Party. He said that if we have a complicated tax system then it is the fault of small business and not the fault of the government. The theme of his argument was: do not blame us, we only wrote the legislation; blame small business, they have made it complex. The Treasurer is saying that we have to make it complex because we have a lot of nasties out there. He is not trying to think it through and achieve the simplicity that the Australian community requires.

PARA.TAB: If we examine the fringe benefits tax we find that the government thought it was a small tax which would raise $500 million. It now raises over $2.7 billion per year. This has been achieved by a process of extension and complication. In a feature article in yesterday's Australian, Access Economics outlined the record of the Keating government in the tax field over its period in office—that is, the last 10 years.

The claims of the Australian Labor Party that the OECD says that we are the second lowest taxed country in the world only picks up on one chart. The way the government gets at that figure is quite amusing. They say that all countries in the world include social security payments as part of their tax system. Australia does not. We compare our system which does not include the social security components—it includes health—with those systems that include social security payments.

If you turn to the next page of the OECD report that all Labor Party members are referring to, you will find the table that compares Australia's total collections of tax, which includes the compulsory superannuation levy, with other nations. We find that—surprise, surprise—Australia comes out in the middle to upper range of countries in terms of taxation. Australia is not the second lowest taxing country in the world. That is a lie and a manipulation of the truth by the Labor Party—the members of this government. It suits their argument. It is not true.

The taxation system in Australia is complex. It is the thing complained about most by business. It has not met the targets that the Prime Minister claimed it would meet when he attended the tax summit as Australia's Treasurer. There was a headline in the Australian entitled `Misleading claims by Prime Minister Keating that Australia is a low taxed country: more compulsory super'. That is a fact.

The tax burden on Australians is substantial and they do not see benefits from most of it. The Treasurer's claims about the changes this legislation will make to the cost of compliance are patently untrue. In an interview with Monica Attard on the PM program on Friday, 24 February, the Treasurer made claims about the changes to the current legislation. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: They dramatically reduce compliance costs for employers by taking a lot of small items out of the FBT net, and also changing arrangements for calculation of benefits of things like car parking and entertainment in a way which will considerably reduce compliance costs for employers, as well as also actually reducing the coverage of the FBT for quite a lot of car parking and for taxi fares. So, it's a pretty good package all round.

I have illustrated what I feel about the fringe benefits tax on taxis required by employees. If one runs through the items the government has claimed it is simplifying and one looks at the raft of formulas, ideas and options, one must assume that the government has deliberately set out to mislead employers, tax agents and the Australian community, because in every instance the options and processes are more complex than they were previously. Sure, mobile phones and laptop computers are out of the system, but the rest has just been made more and more difficult.

PARA.TAB: I have from the National Tax Accountants Association and the Australian Taxpayers Association the illustrations that they use for the formulas that must be applied by people seeking to follow what the government has actually done. The pages of their documents are headed `FBT Warnings'. Let me give you an example of what the government is doing. There are three methods by which new entertainment rules can be applied—not one but three. They are the actual method—where the actual cost is kept—the 12-week register method and the fifty-fifty split method.

Doesn't that make it interesting for employers to have these three options for their business? They have to work out which is going to be the best and easiest to apply. The actual method is the existing method and requires employers to keep actual records of the expenditure incurred. The expenditure must be allocated between employee and non-employee costs, but the Taxation Office accepts a per head basis of apportionment. The 12-week register process is as follows:

The employer must elect to use this method. It requires the employer to maintain a register for a continuous 12 week representative period in a FBT year to determine the ratio of employee and non-employee entertainment.

The ratio is then used as the basis for taxing the total yearly expenditure on food and drink. The ratio can continue to be used until the total yearly meal entertainment varies by more than 20% from the first year.

SPEECH.PARA: At that point a new register is started. The document continues:
A new register is required every five years.

Isn't that simple? That is great simplification! Then there is the fifty-fifty split method. This is the third one. The first is the actual cost and the second is the 12-week register for five years. But if the amount goes up by 20 per cent you have to change the basis, and you have to find out whether there were employees or non-employees at the meal, who paid for it and how you apportion that. Then there is the fifty-fifty split method, outlined as follows:

PARA.TAB: If an employer elects to use this method, the total yearly expenditure on meal entertainment must be apportioned 50/50 between employees (and their associates) and non-employees.
The 50% relating to employee meal entertainment will be subject to FBT and be tax deductible. The 50% relating to non-employees is non-deductible and not subject to FBT.

SPEECH.PARA: WARNING: By adopting this method, you are choosing to pay FBT on all employee meal entertainment regardless of whether it is deductible or non-deductible for income tax purposes.

Most small businesses say, `Who cares. You charge me what you like. I'm not going to keep that rubbish. Come in and raid me and tell me how much I owe you.' They cannot stuff around with this sort of thing. They are absolutely sick of the claims made by the tax office and the bureaucrats on their lives. Corporate boxes at the tennis and elsewhere are used generally for advertising.

PARA.TAB: Car parking involves another change. There are two methods in the car parking system. This is really interesting and I would love to have the time to be able to read right through the proposals. I will outline the first method. The document states:
The first limits the choice of commercial car parks to those which charge $5 or more a day.

The current car parking rules require employers to calculate a car parking benefit if the car has been parked at or near the employee's primary place of employment and there is a commercial parking station within one kilometre of that location.

SPEECH.PARA: The editor has a note on this car parking method, which is the first method. He says:
Car parking records and the employer's FBT liability commence from the day the lower all-day fee of any commercial car park within 1 kilometre exceeds $5.00
The second method is:
The second method provides employers with three alternatives for determining the number of car parking benefits provided during the FBT year.

He makes that calculation. It is the lowest rate within one kilometre of where the place of business is. What a mess! What a process of justification people have to go through to establish whether or not they are sticking to the rules.

PARA.TAB: In a recent survey of all businesses in Mitchell, I asked people to nominate what they thought were the things that they were finding most difficult. By far and away the most significant thing for small businesses—5,000 of them—was the cost and time spent in applying themselves to administration and compliance costs. They just find that abhorrent. The fringe benefits tax was bad enough. The capital gains tax, the compulsory super and all of those other bookkeeping exercises are bad enough. But it is not the money that is worrying them. It is the time and the compulsion of bookkeeping and compulsory administration that this government has imposed on them. It is no wonder that Roger Douglas complains about this government. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) has quite rightly talked about how small businesses become burdened with a whole lot of paperwork and administration costs, and he compared us unfavourably with New Zealand. What he did not say in his preoccupation with New Zealand was that there is only one house of parliament making rules for small business in New Zealand. We have got 15 houses of parliament in Australia's states and territories; the national government makes rules for small business in New Zealand. It is true that we ought to get it together. It is very hard to get it together. Similarly, it is much easier for New Zealand to introduce the sorts of tax reforms that the honourable member was talking about. I want to return to New Zealand a little later.

PARA.TAB: The fringe benefits tax is an important part of a fair tax system. That fairness includes acknowledging that there are some applications of fringe benefits which are legitimate business expenditures. Without a fringe benefits tax there would be a great diversion of incomes into benefits. If we look at the situation before 1986, we will see how true that is.

A manager, director or other relatively highly salaried person could receive a car, fuel, servicing, vehicle registration, high-class meals, education for their children, a rent-free home, newspapers, entertainment or football tickets. Maybe $30,000 or more of these benefits could be used for private purposes per year. A salary of $70,000 may have become $100,000, with $30,000 of that salary tax free.

Even some members of parliament benefited. The base salary in the mid-1980s was about $55,000. An electorate allowance might have been $17,000. Many members spent the whole of their electorate allowance on electorate and office expenses; I know that I did. But some did not spend that. If they did not, the unspent allowance was tax free. So a member of parliament could be $2,000 better off by not paying tax on the benefit and an executive could be tens of thousands of dollars better off. While all this was happening, of course, most wage and salary earners earning less income paid much more tax. Posties did not have a free car, long lunches, entertainment and education for their children in a private school while other people were getting that.

Taxes are paid to satisfy wants in the community. Some of us would use the taxes differently. Some people do not want to pay any tax at all, for instance, for defence. Others do not want to pay any tax at all for sole parents. Others do not want to pay any taxes to the unemployed, to Aborigines or to politicians' wages. People elect governments to allocate the distribution of taxes, apart from certain matters, including politicians' wages, which are fixed by the Remuneration Tribunal.

Few people criticise expenditure on hospitals, roads, education or age pensions. It is not so long ago when people were criticising expenditure on education, saying, `What are you educating people for when you won't have jobs for them?' We are now finding a huge increase in the likelihood of people getting jobs when they have had a good education.

The more simple the collection of tax, the better. Of course, fairness often requires complexity, but not always. This government simplified income tax by taking the 60 per cent top marginal rate down into the forties. That actually reduced the incidence of tax avoidance and increased the amount of tax that was being collected. For some people it was no longer worth paying a tax consultant

SPEECH.PARA: $6,000 a year to avoid, say, a $30,000 or higher tax bill. We need to have a balance between a fair system and a simple system, and that is what we have been talking about today.

PARA.TAB: Prior to the consideration of the fringe benefits tax and a range of other taxes, in 1984 this government suggested a consideration of a value added tax or a form of goods and services tax. That approach generated widespread hostility: businesses were hostile; farmers were hostile; the unions were hostile; the states were hostile; and the Liberal and National parties were hostile. Eventually, after a summit which was held in the Old Parliament House, that suggestion was replaced with an option that included a fringe benefits tax along with a capital gains tax, the prescribed taxes and a different tax system.

After setting up the new system and getting it in place—which was difficult enough—the opposition changed its mind, the farmers changed their minds and businesses changed their minds. Almost everyone except the unions and Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen changed their minds. Those who changed their minds said that a goods and services tax was the way to go.

There is trauma with any change in the tax system. There is a cost to business and government. The government was naturally reluctant, especially under the economic conditions at that time, to once again change the tax system.

There are points against a GST. There are points in favour of going the way we did with the fringe benefits tax and other taxes. First of all, a GST can be avoided by people. People who are producing and selling can sometimes avoid the tax. The GST is an act of faith. I suspect that the opposition still supports a GST. I point out to the opposition that a GST is an act of faith by low income groups. People who pay little or no tax at all would be paying far more tax under a GST. Every time they make a purchase they would pay the tax. They would pay taxes on clothing and food which they have never paid before. Pensioners, wage-earners, low income investors, small businesses and farmers with low incomes would be paying more tax. They would have to trust us in this parliament to boost their incomes so that they could pay the tax.

It is true that that might be done for pensioners and it might be done by backing wage increases for wage-earners to make up for the extra tax that they would be paying. However, we must remember the occasions when we have had wage pauses and there have been no wage increases. We can recall the days of the previous Fraser-Howard administration when pensioners were asked to share in the wage pause and put up with no increase in pensions. What would happen to small businesses with low incomes? What would happen to farmers?

The fringe benefits tax took courage from the government. Admittedly, the GST takes a lot of courage, but there are two forms of courage. There is a silly quixotic type of courage, and there is a courage which is tempered with foresight. The GST took courage all right! It was a new tax for Australia. Other countries that have introduced the GST have, almost inevitably, lost the next election. In Canada, the government, which was made up of progressive conservatives, was reduced to a rump of two people. In Japan we saw a change in government after decades of Liberal Democratic rule—decades. In New Zealand there was a change in government after the introduction of a goods and services tax. Only the UK managed to hold their position, but that was because they created a war—the Falklands War.

The Liberal-National parties showed even more courage than all of those countries put together. The courage of the Liberal-National parties astonished even David Lange, who was prime minister at the time of the introduction of the value added tax in New Zealand. They announced a proposed new tax before the 1993 election. They also announced an industrial relations policy and a policy of privatisation of Telecom and lucrative parts of Australia Post. They lost what they thought was an unloseable election, not just because of the GST.

Compare that with the sort of courage that you can get with a bit of foresight, with a fringe benefits tax and other taxes to prevent fraud, tax evasion and tax avoidance. That sort of courage saw the introduction of an assets test so that people who were receiving pensions and who did not have many assets apart from their home were able to receive a higher benefit. Those who had high value assets—in some cases millions of dollars worth of property—were no longer entitled to receive pensions or could receive only a part pension. So the government showed courage with foresight when it introduced that option which included the fringe benefits tax. I hope the government will keep that up, because we now have a low inflation recovery and we have a lot of people out there who want to return to the boom conditions. It is easy in small business, for instance, to blame the fringe benefits tax for some of the problems of small business. They really want to return to the boom conditions. They forget the busts that follow the boom conditions. I admire the government for being about keeping a low inflation cycle.

The issue of the Economist that came out this week has on the front page a wolf in sheep's clothing. It points out how the United Kingdom and the United States are relaxing their resolve about inflation. They are starting to think that some inflation will give some growth. They are lowering their vigilance. Just as fringe benefits without a tax is a trick on low income people, inflation growth is a trick on workers. It is as insidious as fringe benefits being given to high income people. Under higher inflation, the governments would allow higher prices in the hope that workers would allow wages to stay where they are. Workers resist wages dropping back, but they do not resist wages not going up to the same extent. Similarly, pensioners do not resist their pensions not going up to the same extent that they would if they were reduced. So governments are tempted into allowing high inflation.

It took courage on our behalf to give us one of the fairest social security systems in the world. It took courage to change the taxation system to eliminate a lot of the avoidance, including bottom of the harbour schemes, and to give us a fairer tax system which includes fringe benefits tax. We must use that same courage and foresight to retain the low inflation cycle that we have now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to contribute to the Taxation Laws Amendment (FBT Cost of Compliance) Bill 1995. I welcome the opportunity to be part of the debate on this important legislation. This bill is a very belated recognition by the government that the fringe benefits tax compliance costs are still far too high. Whilst acknowledging that there are some changes which will improve things, the reforms proposed in the bill do not go nearly far enough. Businesses which are trying to become more efficient in today's internationally competitive environment are still being strangled by the fringe benefits tax compliance costs. The administrative complexity and excessive regulations imposed by Labor's fringe benefits tax mean that precious resources such as time, labour and materials are all tied up in red tape. Far from improving the economy's efficiency, the fringe benefits tax compliance costs dampen entrepreneurial spirit, overload business operations and impede further investment.

PARA.TAB: The changes to the whole fringe benefits tax structure are urgently needed but the measures proposed in this bill are not nearly enough. A recent survey of Australia's top 100 companies has revealed that the so-called improvements to the fringe benefits tax will cost these companies an additional $28.7 million each year. Current fringe benefits tax compliance costs are running at an estimated 10.9 per cent of fringe benefits tax revenue. This stands in stark contrast to the example of New Zealand, where compliance costs are only 1.7 per cent of the fringe benefits tax revenue. So it is still a very complex and inefficient tax in regard to compliance arrangements.

These figures reveal the hollowness of the government's rhetoric about trying to help small business in this country. There is no doubt that the fringe benefits tax compliance costs are having a harmful effect on the productivity of Australian businesses. The Australian Manufacturing, Engineering and Construction Industry Association has noted that some of its members are faced with compliance costs equivalent to employing three full-time staff. In other words, just complying with the cost of the fringe benefits tax is costing Australians jobs.

Small and medium sized businesses are even more disadvantaged than larger corporations. They cannot afford the extra staff to cope with the paperwork created not only by the fringe benefits tax but also by the many other taxes they have to face every day. These include the PAYE tax, income tax, payroll tax, workers compensation, and the superannuation guarantee levy, to name just a few. Scarce resources are also spent on training employees to keep up with the frequent changes to what are extremely complex and difficult administrative rules.

Another example of the impracticality of these arrangements is the difference between the fringe benefits tax accounting period and the normal tax year. The normal tax year ends on 30 June each year, but for the fringe benefits tax that period ends on 31 March each year, adding another element of complexity and cost to business out there in complying with government regulations.

The fringe benefits tax legislation is far too complex and unwieldy. There are over 250 definitions, 260 separate sections and nearly 300 pages of legislation. In contrast, in New Zealand, where there is a fringe benefits tax, the legislation is less than 50 pages.
Many business operators report difficulties in complying with the complex factual requirements and onerous documentary evidence obligations to secure what are intended to be exempt benefits.

The fringe benefits tax compliance cost structure is very inequitable between different classes of taxpayers. For example, all employees are assumed to be on the highest marginal tax rate of 48.4 cents in the dollar. This means that the tax has no regard to the progressive tax rate system applying to employees' salaries and wages. This, quite clearly, is blatantly unfair, particularly in the light of some of the benefits made subject to the tax, such as car parking and taxi fares.

The existing fringe benefits tax structure has clearly extended its scope in recent years beyond that intended by the original legislation. Originally, the tax was designed to target non-cash employee remuneration used essentially for tax evasion purposes. Yet its current operation covers any benefits seen to accrue to an employee regardless of the purpose for which the benefits are provided.

A prime example of this occurs in the mining industry. Given the location of most mining sites, the companies often provide free housing and other so-called benefits to their employees. These are regarded as necessary for a number of reasons. Life in many mining communities, particularly in remote Australia, is not particularly easy. The remoteness of many of these mining locations makes living out in these areas not as comfortable as living in our capital cities.

These so-called benefits that the mining companies extend to their employees are really only measures to lift the standard of living of employees to something approaching that which people in urban areas take for granted. These benefits were also considered necessary to attract employees to these regions. Yet they are now subject to the fringe benefits tax. This is having a profound effect on the nature of work in these areas as well as on the nature of the traditional mining town.

In this nation today we have some very traditional mining towns—Mount Isa, Kalgoorlie and Broken Hill—in remote parts of Australia. Those towns grew around the mining operations in those areas. One effect of this fringe benefits tax has been that mining companies now resort to what is known as fly in, fly out. Instead of providing the accommodation and the associated benefits which are subject to the tax, the companies fly the workers in at the beginning of the working period and fly them out when it ends. This transportation of the workers in and out of these mining communities is not subject to a tax. As a result, companies often reject the idea of setting up permanent town sites in preference to the fly in, fly out arrangements.

Mining employees have always been central to the existence of these communities, but their loss means that these settlements face the very real prospect of decline. In addition, a vibrant, well serviced community is needed to attract not only skilled workers, but other essential people such as doctors and teachers.
The reality of this situation is that fringe benefits attract these people to remote areas. But a fringe benefits tax attracts no-one anywhere. As a result, once thriving communities face decline.

The mining communities established in Kalgoorlie, Broken Hill and Mount Isa, which were part of the decentralisation of this nation, would not be set up today by mining companies because of the fringe benefits tax. That would be the result of applying a fringe benefits tax to so-called perceived benefits that mining companies give to their employees in order to attract them to these areas. It just illustrates the government's hypocrisy about equity in this matter. It also makes a mockery of its so-called commitment to regional development. Those opposite mouth off in the House day after day and over the airwaves of this nation their apparent commitment to regional development. But, quite clearly, the fringe benefits tax and the way that it applies to remote mining communities is disadvantaging any chance of mining companies establishing mining communities that are sustainable in the long term.

You only have to witness Mount Isa, Kalgoorlie and Broken Hill today to see that there are viable communities there that were built around a mining industry. Those mining companies provided benefits to those employees to work and develop this nation. As a result, we have communities that are today of immense benefit to this nation. Today, under the fringe benefits tax rules, you find that mining companies are opting for the fly in, fly out operation because it is cheaper in terms of their own operations, and it ensures that their shareholders obviously get a higher dividend. That is a responsible position for the mining industry.

The government's approach to taxing the perceived benefits of mining companies in remote locations in this country is quite clearly impeding regional development. It will continue to do so whilst ever this government fails to acknowledge that the impact of this fringe benefits tax on the remote mining locations in this country does encourage these companies to fly their employees in and out of the site rather than develop a community where that wealth is being extracted from the ground.

This is not the end of the bad news, because many important industries are located in rural and remote regions. One industry that this legislation hits is the pastoral industry in this country. It is still illegal for an employer to cash-up the benefits under state awards. I will quote clause 14(1) of the Queensland station hands award:

SPEECH.PARA: Every employer shall provide all employees with accommodation free of charge.
Food shall be supplied to the employees of sufficient quantity, sound, well cooked and properly served by the cook.
The employer must provide these benefits under that state industrial award. Section 14 of the Pastoral Workers Accommodation Act 1980 states that accommodation is to be free of cost.

PARA.TAB: This is also the case in the federal wool classers award. Clause 18 of the 1994 award says that the employer shall provide the employee with suitable board and lodging free of charge. If an employer were to cash-up this accommodation or perceived fringe benefits, the employee would be clearly in breach of the award.

Whilst union officials at this stage are probably turning a blind eye to this situation, nevertheless the situation still exists where these employers could one day find themselves taken to court on the basis of the technical breach of an award. Employers in Queensland are not permitted by law to charge fully kept employees for accommodation or food. This mandatory provision of free accommodation and meals under the Queensland awards prohibits employees from negotiating the value of any non-cash benefit, renegotiating the value of any provided benefit or withdrawing any benefit which has been provided in accordance with the requirement of the award.

Quite clearly, employers in Queensland under these state awards are in a very difficult position, and the fringe benefits tax only adds to the complexities they face. The employer has no right to exercise a choice. The employer is forced by law to provide a benefit but is then taxed on that provision, while the recipient is not taxed at all. This is a tax that employers pay. Whilst it might be argued that employers can claim a tax deduction for the payment of fringe benefits tax on behalf of their employees, if you are not paying tax the tax deduction is not worth anything to you.

This is just another tax on the people in the pastoral industry in this country. Out in many parts of rural Australia, farmers and pastoralists have experienced five years of drought. According to the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, many have recorded negative incomes. A tax deduction is not worth anything in these cases. So the fringe benefits tax the employers have to pay for these perceived benefits under mandatory industrial awards clearly ends up as another tax with no benefit to the employer.

I also want to touch on how the fringe benefits tax is impacting on local government in this country. Under the rules of the fringe benefits tax legislation and under the grossing up provisions, local governments are now paying the equivalent of 98.3 per cent tax on the benefits that they may be providing to their employees. Local governments are being unfairly treated under the grossing up provisions of the fringe benefits tax regime. Why? Because local governments do not pay tax.

Local government as a non-taxable entity does not receive the benefit of the tax deduction for the fringe benefits tax. Therefore, they are paying fringe benefits tax at the 98.3 per cent level. Given the upcoming requirements of competitive neutrality under the national competition policy, it could well be argued that it is reasonable that local governments should expect to be able to pay fringe benefits tax at the same rate as their potential competitors.

Whilst this bill does go some way towards simplifying what is a very complex, bureaucratic piece of legislation that impacts unfairly in some areas, this area of tax law is still too complex. The bill has not addressed the issue of the local government inequity; it has not addressed the issue of the remote mining communities; and it has not addressed the issue of the industrial awards in Queensland, such as the station hands award, where employers have to provide certain benefits as part of an industrial award. Quite clearly, those are issues that the government has no regard for. I hope that, in time, we will have the opportunity to address these issues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot think of many things more depressing than a fringe benefits tax bill. I can think of other depressing things in this Parliament, such as the salad bar in the members dining room and things like that that tend to turn one off, but the stupefying complexity of this scheme to tax benefits in kind gives me reason to wince and grimace.

PARA.TAB: Whilst there are some improvements to the general scheme of fringe benefits tax law embodied in the Taxation Laws Amendment (FBT Cost of Compliance) Bill, I echo the sentiments of many small business people, and certainly many of their clerical employees—some of whom I had the pleasure and honour of employing myself before I was elected to this place—and express their hatred of this scheme and their urge for reform. Hopefully, after the next election, when those of us on this side of the House are in government, we will have the opportunity to make some of the reforms which my colleague the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Costello) outlined yesterday in a speech at the Old Parliament House.

One of the ironic things about the bill we are debating today is that it seeks to simplify the fringe benefits tax law. But it adds to it 60 pages. How can you seriously come into the House and say you are going to simplify a tax scheme by adding 60 pages to it? Members in the chamber today may observe that I have not taken the opportunity of asking the attendants for a lectern, the reason being I brought with me the tax act. I do not need a lectern for my notes today because, as is obvious to everyone who can see this, the tax act in its full majesty is high enough to support my notes. I understand that when I was born the tax act was some 342 pages long. It now exceeds 5,000 pages and, by the end of today, it will be another 60 pages long.

It is no secret these days in the business community that the nature of the tax office has changed in recent years and that the pressures arising from the budget deficits that this government has thrust upon the nation have given ascendancy within the tax office to the hawks, the hard line revenue raisers, as opposed to the moderates who seek, in their duties in the tax office, to make it fairer perhaps from the point of view of the taxpayer. This change in the nature of the tax office was described by a former officer of the tax office, Mr Douglass, in an article in the Financial Review last month. He described the change in the culture that was made when reporting lines were changed from a vertical nature to that of a horizontal nature. He stated that this gave ascendancy to the accountants within the tax office as opposed to the lawyers who were more interested in procedural fairness.

SPEECH.PARA: That is perhaps a small matter in comparison with the stupefying mess that fringe benefits tax law is. The bill before us today carries the parenthetic title `FBT Cost of Compliance'. I intend to make a few remarks on the substantive provisions of the bill and also I want to elaborate on the proposition that the cost of compliance is greater than the pecuniary or financial cost borne by the employers who must pay this tax. The cost to the investment climate within Australia of an overcomplicated and intrusive tax regime is almost unquantifiable, but it is certainly very great.

PARA.TAB: In considering this stupefying mess, I put to the House three propositions. The first one is the obvious one: that, as technology changes, and as the incidents and the nature of employment grows more complicated year by year, the revenue raising means of a government will likewise need to change and adapt to those changes in the workplace.

The second proposition is that, in effecting that adaptation of the tax law to cope with the changes in the workplace, a government that chooses a very mechanical and intrusive approach by enacting highly technical legislation that imposes a tax liability on the employer—which is exactly what the FBT law is—that government will thereby fetter or restrict that employer's ability to produce profits and a return on equity invested. Restricted likewise are the employment prospects for the pool of labour from which that employer draws its staff and, of course, the further investment prospects that the employer might otherwise undertake, such as the member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) described when talking of the trouble that some of the mining companies have in his electorate as a result of FBT.

The cost of compliance, which is what this bill is supposed to be all about, goes beyond the financial penalty to the employer; it goes also to the opportunity cost that is lost by the burden placed on those employers. In that respect, it is well to remember that everything a government does, every law it passes and every administrative act it performs, has an effect on the psychology of investment in a jurisdiction whether it be a state or a federation such as Australia. So you must take into account the atmospheric effects of what a government does as well as the technical beauty or technical ugliness of whatever it proposes.

Such atmospheric effects, in particular of this FBT, are illustrated I thought very clearly by a report from the APEC Capital Markets Working Group, a group of business and financial market leaders established under the rubric of APEC to lobby the government to strengthen efforts for Australia to become a major financial centre for the Asia-Pacific region. In doing that, we are competing against other countries, other capitals—New Zealand, Singapore, Hong Kong. In studying the tax law that confronts foreign companies when they consider whether to establish a regional headquarters in Australia to service these markets, this group reported that Australia has now:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . an international reputation for being unsympathetic to regional headquarters and a taxation system considered to be a significant disincentive.
That is plain. That is what you get when you enact a highly technical and intrusive tax law. That is what I mean by these atmospheric effects.

PARA.TAB: It is one thing to say that you are trying to achieve vertical equity or horizontal equity between taxpayers in seeking a more thorough approach to taxing benefits in kind, which is really what fringe benefits are, but it is another thing to do it in such a way as to harm the future prospects of an economy and the workers within it. It is a terrible thing to poison the investment atmosphere in that respect. It is my view that the direction of tax regulation, the trend and the quality of our investment atmosphere, is getting bad as time passes.

The issue of the report by Access Economics boiled up and was debated with some vigour in question time yesterday. It is now 10 years since the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—or the Treasurer, as he then was—introduced these changes to our tax system. It astonished me to learn that the tax burden on Australians is actually greater than it was then. That is strange in view of what the Prime Minister said on 19 September 1985 when speaking in this House: `The benefits of tax reform will be shared among all Australians.' If an increased burden is of benefit, I can understand why a lot of people no longer regard the Prime Minister as credible in what he says. You cannot persuade me that paying more tax is a benefit.

When I saw this bill on the Notice Paper and put my name down to speak to it, I started to do a little bit of research on the subject. Being of a curious nature, I went to the library to inquire what the situation was regarding benefits in kind before the FBT, before this monster was born. I do not know whether to describe the fringe benefits tax as a monster; perhaps `disease' is a better noun to use.

I discovered that before this regime benefits in kind, fringe benefits, were taxed with a combination of common law and statute—that is, decisions by courts as well as provisions in the tax act, as it then was. The main taxing provision was section 25, and the government enacted section 26(e) in an effort to catch these benefits in kind.

First, let us have a little look at the common law, as it then was. It began in England last century with a case called Tennant v. Smith. In that case, a bank housed one of its bank managers in a provincial English town. When the Inland Revenue sought to tax the value of that accommodation given to the bank manager, the case went all the way to the House of Lords, and the House of Lords ruled that there is no taxable income if the benefit is not in money or money's worth.

That was followed by another case, Abbott v. Philbin, where the court decided that an indirect ability to turn the benefit into money or money's worth was enough to call it income and therefore to have it taxed. This led to some strange rulings in other parts of the Commonwealth.

Following that principle, there was in New Zealand the case of Dawson v. Inland Revenue Commission where a company which I understand manufactured colour televisions issued a bond or a debenture and offered the investor the free use of a colour TV instead of its paying interest on the bond. Surprisingly, the court in New Zealand said that this was not taxable because you could not convert the free use of a colour TV into money or money's worth. That is a somewhat extreme example of what happened to the common law. It certainly was not the case here in Australia.

In Australia the courts decided, as late as 1980, in the case of FCT v. Cooke and Sherden, that the English doctrine that there is no taxable income unless the benefit can be turned into money or money's worth should be accepted here in Australia, and we did accept it. So we had a body of judicial law, a judicial concept of income, which matched the legislative provisions that were in force at the time, section 25 being the main taxing provision.

This legislature enacted section 26(e) to cope with fringe benefits. When I read it I frankly could not understand why we had gone to such a complicated scheme of FBT, because when you read the words of that provision it seemed pretty plain that it would catch the sorts of things that employees receive these days called fringe benefits. What is taxable is described in section 26(e):

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the value to the taxpayer of all allowances, gratuities, compensations, benefits . . . given or granted to him in respect of . . . or in relation directly or indirectly to, any employment of or services rendered by him, whether . . . given or granted in money, goods, land, meals, sustenance, the use of premises or quarters or otherwise . . .

That seems to me to be a very broad provision. I cannot understand why it was held to be inadequate. There must have been something wrong with the way it was enforced, or with some of the decisions of the High Court in the late seventies and early eighties, that the court in the New Zealand case went to an extreme in holding that some of the more contrived tax avoidance schemes were lawful.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps that is why this government, when it was first elected, saw the need to rush in and burden us with an enormous and complicated scheme to replace what struck me as a perfectly well drafted legislative provision. As I have said—and pointing out that I did not need my lectern—you can see what this government has done by way of burdening us with all sorts of tax schemes since it was elected. You can look at the size of this pile and see why I make that point.

In trying to frame a legislative scheme to collect tax off benefits in kind, or fringe benefits, you have to make sure that there are two solid legs to the scheme. The first is that the legislative scheme must examine carefully and properly the nature and the purpose of the benefit that the employee is receiving. You have to ask whether it was really a reward to the employee or whether it was an unavoidable business expense that the employee happened to be the beneficiary of.

Likewise, the second leg of a good legislative scheme to tax benefits in kind must be a proper valuation of that benefit. When you go back and look at section 26(e) you see that the nexus for the benefit received by the employee is drafted in a wide fashion, directly or indirectly, and the valuation of that benefit is described as the value to the taxpayer. There is a bit more common law on that which I will get to later.

It struck me that this provision should surely apply to many modern situations. If it caught non-income receipts to taxpayers in those days, then I cannot see why it could not be used today if the tax office performed its duties in a more diligent fashion rather than sought help from the legislature and, in doing so, poisoned the investment atmosphere. That apparently was not enough. We ended up with the birth of this monstrous FBT. As you see it has grown ever since. It has grown more complicated as time has passed.

When I went back and read the then Treasurer's second reading speech when introducing the FBT scheme I found that he sought to explain the need for the scheme by saying that there was widespread non-disclosure of benefits in kind. Maybe there was. That gave rise in my mind to the issue: why was the tax office not out there frightening people with the prospect of an audit so that they would disclose the benefits in kind that they were receiving. There must have been something wrong with the way things were done then if people felt they could get away with not disclosing them.

Likewise, he said that the existing law had a poor test of valuation in saying that the value to the taxpayer was not somehow sufficient in judging how much of these benefits should be subject to tax. That gave rise to a general rule instead of giving separate consideration to the benefits derived by each taxpayer, which seems to me to be a sensible way of doing it.

The principle that lies behind self-assessment is that we obey the law and put our tax return in and if we seek to defraud revenue by misstating our income or understating it we run the risk of being punished. That is a perfectly legitimate scheme to have in a country where people are generally honest, as I think Australians are. There were other things behind the introduction of the FBT that the Prime Minister did not see fit to disclose at the time.

The trade unions said that many fringe benefits won by workers on work sites around Australia were really not benefits so much as property rights. Before I was elected, I was engaged in the construction business—earthmoving, irrigation and so forth. There were certainly many things that we provided to our employees, as part of their jobs and according to the award, as a matter of occupational health and safety. They certainly regarded them as hard won property rights rather than benefits in kind given by a generous employer such as myself. Somehow or other you can see the influence of the trade union movement in persuading its government. There is no more generous earthmover employer in this jurisdiction or any other where I have worked. My former employees who came to hear my maiden speech, among other things, will always be willing to testify to that effect.

Back to this stupefying mess. You can see the influence of the trade union movement in persuading its representatives in the parliament that we should shift the burden of paying tax on what were, in some cases, obviously derived fringe benefits to the employer, with no regard to the effect on the investment atmosphere. There is not really much more I can say other than to recall a statement by a long dead English judge who, when looking at documents comprising a general law title deed, said, `They were difficult to read, impossible to understand and quite disgusting to contemplate.' That is exactly the way I and many of my electors feel about this fringe benefits tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moylan Mrs J.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Tax Research Foundation, in its study entitled The compliance costs of employment related taxation in Australia, identified the fringe benefits tax as the most administratively expensive tax for employers and the one which was most likely to require outside help to administer. This study found that in 1989-90 the compliance cost of the fringe benefits tax totalled a staggering $128 million or just under 11 per cent of the total FBT revenue. That is the compliance cost; that is not the cost of paying the tax. If we look at the actual FBT tax projected for this financial year—$2.8 billion—and extrapolate those figures, as my colleague the shadow Treasurer did yesterday, we will find that the total cost of compliance is $300 million per annum.

PARA.TAB: Even the smallest remitters—88 per cent of all fringe benefits tax payers—incur costs of around 42 per cent of the tax remitted. In addition, about 66 per cent of businesses liable for FBT employ a professional adviser to undertake the compliance aspects of this tax. This type of tax structure epitomises this government's lack of commitment to the small business sector. It is a government that basically does not understand the dynamics or the nuances of small business and it is content to simply wring every tax dollar possible from that sector of the economy to prop up its thirst for big government.

When the Treasurer (Mr Willis) announced on 10 May 1994, in the context of the 1994-95 budget, a review of the FBT compliance costs, small businesses around Australia thought that the madness associated with many aspects of the FBT would at long last be addressed. They were somewhat heartened by the Treasurer's promise that not only would this review take place but also it would be completed and action would be taken by the end of July 1994. It was all too good to be true; the Treasurer quickly returned to type. The final report of the review sat on the desk of the Treasurer and the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) gathering dust for no less than 243 days before the government announced what the benefits would be for the business community.

The fact that this review was initially promised to be completed by the end of July 1994 and was not implemented until April 1995 highlighted the government's total lack of consideration for the impact on or the cost to small business of complying with this particular tax. The government is oblivious to the fact that small businesses are responsible for managing the bottom line of their financial affairs. Funds are limited and must be allocated to issues of priority. There is no such luxury for them of imposing additional costs on their customers and clients to recoup the cost of government excesses and mismanagement.

The Treasurer and the small business minister should do a quick financial analysis and figure out what productive use small business could make of the around $900,000 a day, if it was not being squandered on FBT compliance costs. The funds could employ a lot more people, purchase a lot of new capital equipment or support a lot of productive investment. If the 243-day delay was imposed on the small business community, on today's estimate of $900,000 per day for compliance costs it would add approximately $200 million of needless cost to the operation of Australia's 860,000 small businesses. That is, the total cost is estimated at around $200 million. That is needless cost. That is simply the cost of complying with this tax. It does not include the cost of paying the tax.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the small business minister profess their support for small business and do plenty of public hand wringing about small business issues, but when it comes to the test of action and commitment their words have a very hollow ring. The rhetoric is more evident than any meaningful action.

The small business minister stands condemned by the small business community for continually ignoring requests for action on this particular issue. It is not unusual, though, for the government to delay things, do a lot of public hand wringing and have a lot of enquiries, committee hearings and so on, but fail to translate that into meaningful policy, particularly in the small business area. Eleven months after receiving the final report on the review of franchising, for example, the minister for small business has indicated that this will be the week when he will announce the government's response to the issues of importance in that sector.

This is typical of what we see from the government when it rushes into this place at five minutes to midnight with little time for industry groups to consider the implications of the recommendations. There are other examples of the government being aware of major concerns in the sector but delaying any consideration to address those issues.

What is clearly apparent is that the small business sector is being administered by a minister who has no passion for, or understanding of, the dynamics of this sector. The government's standard ploy is to announce an inquiry with an ambitious reporting target to give the impression that something is being done. It does not fool anyone except those on the government benches.

Business and community organisations willing to commit valuable resources to participating in these endless reports, reviews, inquiries and investigations demonstrate their goodwill towards overcoming the obstacles to efficiency, investment and employment growth, but the government seems to have little commitment to producing any kind of meaningful policy to fix some of these problem areas. Businesses are sick and tired of the constant stonewalling and the indecision of ministers in this Keating government, which obviously is indicative of their inability to translate into meaningful policy all of the outcomes of these committees and hearings.

In yesterday's Australian there was a feature called `A decade of taxation reform'. It contains some very telling criticisms of the government's current commitment to tax reform. Geoffrey Lehmann referred to the reform of the Australian taxation system—affectionately known as RATS—and summarised the feelings of the small business community very well when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: For a few years after RATS tax reform continued in the heroic mould but, in the last few years, the Federal Government has shown signs of reform fatigue. That much of the legislation enacting the RATS proposals was hastily drafted and appallingly complicated on matters of detail has contributed to that fatigue.

PARA.TAB: Armies of public servants have drafted what Richard Vann described last week as `a stupifying mess'.

SPEECH.PARA: This morning other colleagues have referred to that.

PARA.TAB: This, of course, is not the fault of the very hardworking public servants who have to wrestle with these problems; rather it is a lack of leadership being demonstrated by this government. Small business can attest to and relate with comments of such honesty in respect of the FBT regime. They, not the out-of-touch small business minister, are the ones trying to manage a business and, at the same time, fight their way through the consequences of the government's stupifying mess.

The reform fatigue that Geoffrey Lehmann referred to is symptomatic of a tired, listless and out-of-touch government. The government has become too comfortable. We constantly hear various ministers extolling the virtues of export market development, international best practice, benchmarking, networking and the need for new paradigms in management practices. All of these issues are being promoted by a government that is in a period of stagnation and disinterest in the direction of the small business sector and, worse still, incapable of managing some of the basic fundamental requirements of the business sector in order for them to take advantage of the new global markets that are emerging.

The small business minister has been remarkably reluctant to offer advice to small business employers on how they can focus on the challenge of international market development, innovation and business management, while he supports the FBT regime that requires small businesses to constantly run around car parks checking the price of daily parking. It is just a ridiculous situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a joke.

—It is a joke; you are quite right. The government's disinterest in the viability and profitability of the small business sector is further underlined by the fact that in September 1985 the government estimated that FBT would bring in about $550 million in its first full year. Ten years on, the annual FBT take is forecast to increase to $2.84 billion in the 1995-96 budget. The government has been so busy gloating on the fruits of this tax that it has not considered important the pernicious impact that small business face in complying with the aspects of this tax, nor the stupidity of some of the current applications of the FBT.

PARA.TAB: I was interested to listen this morning to your speech, Mr Deputy Speaker Snow, on this matter. I agree with you that it is very important that we deliver fairness, equity and simplicity in the tax system. I have no problem with that at all. But this country's 850,000 small businesses produce 30 to 40 per cent of our gross domestic product and employ 47 per cent of all Australians. We must recognise that they play a vital and integral part in producing an income base that allows this country to have good health facilities, good education facilities and enables it to look after its unemployed. I think it is high time that we get things into perspective and recognise that we have to look after our income producers—those people who are contributing to the pool of money that this government enjoys distributing in various ways throughout the community.

Our small businesses not only look after their own needs; they help others in their community. If you have ever visited a country town, you would see that there is a stark understanding of how important small businesses are to the social fabric of those communities in which they operate. I think you are quite right that we do have to have a fair and simple system. I have not heard very many businesses complain about paying the fringe benefits tax where it is truly an offset against salary, where they are receiving benefits in kind in lieu of salary. I have never heard too many business people complain about that. What they are complaining about is the complexity of this system and the madness of tying up enormous resources in this country that could be going into productive investment and the production of jobs for the many people who are still unemployed in Australia today.

I want to refer briefly to the Treasurer's comments of yesterday, which can be found in yesterday's Hansard. He named me and the shadow Treasurer, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Costello). He says that we are going around the country `winking and hinting' about changes to the tax system. I can certainly say that I have never talked about abolishing the fringe benefits tax where it truly applies to items received in lieu of salary. What I have consistently talked about with small business groups around this country is how we might address the huge cost of compliance, how we might simplify the tax and how we might make this a fairer application of paying tax. I have certainly done that, and I make no apologies for that. The Treasurer also commented:

We know, having recently been through the process of looking at reducing compliance costs and making a number of changes to the system to reduce those compliance costs, that you cannot do it without losing substantial amounts of tax revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest that is bunkum. I also suggest that it shows this is a very tired government and that it is indeed in a policy vacuum. If the government had a will it could certainly address this problem without damaging the revenue base. That is something the coalition is committed to trying to achieve.

PARA.TAB: In a speech also delivered in this place this morning, my colleague the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) demonstrated very succinctly that while New Zealand has been able to introduce a FBT tax, the compliance cost of our FBT tax compared to New Zealand's is six times higher. That is a very fair demonstration that, if we had a will and if we had a mind and if we put ourselves through a bit of lateral thinking, we would be able to come up with a solution to the damaging and pernicious cost of collecting taxes.

Clearly this government cannot stand to see business conditions improve. The minute small businesses start to make a bit more money the government thinks it is a signal for it to just willy-nilly spend more and waste and squander taxpayers' money. When it runs out of money it simply puts up the tax. In the last budget the government demonstrated that it only put up the tax in one sector of the economy, and that was the small business sector. The small business sector bore the brunt of most of the tax increases in the last budget.

When announcing the review in 1994 the Treasurer did say that the aim was to minimise compliance costs while protecting the tax base and overall equity of the tax system. They were his own words. He has used the protection of the tax base argument as an excuse to increase FBT payable on cars to compensate for the loss of revenue in other areas. I suppose that was his stated agenda as well—that it would be revenue neutral. But the Assistant Treasurer announced that the package would dramatically reduce compliance costs. This allegation has been refuted by some business organisations. The Corporate Tax Association said:

SPEECH.PARA: A survey of Australia's top 100 companies revealed that the so-called improvements to the FBT will cost these companies an additional cost of $28.7 million annually. The survey also revealed there would be minimal savings in compliance costs.

The Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants has described the review as `a bald-faced revenue raising exercise which simply reshuffles the formula by which the government milks business for every last cent in an effort to raise its own revenue base'. Another accounting firm, in a Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu article called `Another taxing week', summed up the Treasurer's result as follows:

Mr Willis's result is disappointing, given the time and resources devoted by the business community to helping with this subject. Overall his effort seems to benefit Treasury rather than the business community.

While the small business sector will benefit from some of the changes to the FBT on car parking benefits as the amendments should reduce associated compliance costs, the amendments do not completely eliminate the need for employers to monitor changes in fees charged by car park operators. So we still have this ludicrous system where a business proprietor's time is taken up running around checking car park costs instead of getting on with the business of creating wealth and business for the benefit of all people in this nation.

PARA.TAB: It is very evident that the small business community is going through a great crisis of confidence in the government's ability to deliver meaningful policies. We saw the Beddall report on small business delivered several years ago. We are still seeing the government unable to tackle some of the hard issues in terms of releasing small business from these wasteful processes of paying tax and complying with regulation and legislation.

It is a reflection of the government's understanding of and interest in the impact of its policies on small business that in regard to this amendment and other amendments in the last couple of days specifically involving small business we have seen 25 coalition members contributing to the debate in this place, while only 12 government members consider small business issues important enough to come in and participate in the debate on these critical issues. The level of commitment will not be lost on the small business community. I support the second reading amendment which has been moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and the shadow Treasurer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Somlyay Mr A.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is significant that the Taxation Laws Amendment (FBT Cost of Compliance) Bill should be introduced 10 years and one day after Treasurer Keating released his tax reform package back in 1985. Yesterday in the Australian, Mr Carmody of Access Economics reminded us of the 1985 tax summit and the white paper reform of the Australian tax system, which at the time was shortened significantly to the word RATS.

PARA.TAB: The white paper identifies several features of post-war tax history. Five of those features were: an increasing Australian tax burden, an increasingly heavy reliance on personal income tax and less on other taxes, a significant escalation in tax rates found by the average income tax earners, wide differences in the tax treatment of income from different investments, and the narrowly based high set of rates of consumption taxes. The government's response to these identified deficiencies was the introduction of dividend imputation, which was designed to eliminate the double taxation of company income tax, the introduction of income tax on most realised capital gains and the introduction of a fringe benefits tax. Access concludes in the white paper that the problems identified in the white paper are still with us. In some instances, those problems are worse now in 1995 than they were in 1985.

The fringe benefits tax has been a monster—a policy monster and an administrative monster. It has been a tremendous burden on business. But it is very clear that members of the Australian Labor Party do not understand business—they do not understand that a tax is a cost of doing business. When compliance costs become excessive, they become an excessive cost to business.

In an era of so-called micro-economic reform and competition policy, surely one should expect, and even the Labor Party must realise, that the burden of excessive compliance costs is anti-competition. It guarantees that the Australian business community cannot compete with foreign competitors. Excessive FBT compliance costs are anti-business and anti-employment. My colleague the honourable member for Pearce (Ms Moylan) pointed out a few moments ago that the compliance cost in Australia of FBT is six times that of New Zealand.

At a time when we are plagued by balance of payments problems, Australian companies are moving offshore in their droves to do business, we are relying on imports month after month, year after year, and our unemployment still hovers around 800,000 or more than eight per cent, why does the government persist with placing burdens in the way of business—disincentives, paperwork and red tape?

Business people in my electorate say, `What's the use.' They see no hope. After 12 years of Labor, their only salvation is a change of government which, for them, cannot happen too soon. I remind the House of the inquiry conducted by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts into the Australian tax system. The terms of reference of the committee were wide ranging. The committee did not have a charter to canvass tax policy, and it was very careful to avoid that. Policy is a matter for the government. The JCPA examined the administration of tax policy. It was a very high profile and emotive inquiry. Many people will recall clashes between members of the committee and the Commissioner of Taxation and others.

During the inquiry, in excess of 120 submissions were received, amounting to over 5,000 pages of evidence. A further 1,600 pages of evidence were taken during the public hearings in 1992 and 1993. The committee tabled its report No. 326 in November 1993. All in all, there were 148 recommendations. The committee felt that 148 matters of an administrative nature, not of a policy nature, needed to be addressed. It was not about tax policy but the way that the tax system is run. On 23 August, the government responded to the JCPA report No. 326 and, in fairness, many of our recommendations were adopted by the government. The recurring theme in submissions and public hearings before the committee related to the burden of the high cost of compliance on business.

The committee set about its recommendations. The high cost of compliance was a major factor in our considerations. As the inquiry proceeded, it was patently obvious that people upon whom the tax burden fell did not understand the complexity of the tax. Not only did the people upon whom the burden fell not understand the tax; their tax agents were confused by the tax. In many instances, it was again obvious that the Australian Taxation Office did not understand the tax. The system of rulings which the government introduced to clarify tax laws, in fact, added further to the confusion. The committee received evidence that it was not unusual for tax practitioners to approach different branch officers of the ATO who they knew beforehand would be favourable to their case or a request. Some officers of the ATO were very strict in their interpretation of the legislation and rulings; other officers were sympathetic. Tax practitioners soon learned where to go to get a favourable ruling. Under these conditions, what chance does the poor taxpayer have of understanding tax law when these blatant inconsistencies prevail?

The bill before us today is designed to simplify tax law. That is a clear indication that the tax law has failed and is complicated. If you need to simplify it, it is complicated. It was made clear to the committee that the major problem with our tax law is its complexity and the cost to business and individuals in complying with it. In every submission received which touched on the FBT, the major complaint was the cost of compliance.

In many instances, it cost more to comply with the tax than the tax itself. No-one would argue that benefits received in kind instead of cash should not be taxed. However, there is no justification in my mind for an FBT to be paid by the employer for a benefit received by the employee.

In 1987 the government figures showed that there were 138,360 employers caught in the FBT net—that is, 138,360 FBT payers—who paid a total of $521,810,000 in tax. By 1994 the number of FBT payers had actually declined by 10,000-odd. There were 128,000 people caught in the FBT net, but the amount payable to the tax office was a staggering $1.414 billion. So 10,000 fewer taxpayers were, in fact, paying three times as much in FBT as when the scheme was introduced.

In the current budget, the FBT take is estimated to be $2.7 billion. It is no longer a measure to close loopholes in current tax law. It is now a new way of taxing business, purely to provide revenue to this cash strapped government which is in debt up to its eyebrows. There is only one way to pay for its extravagant expenditure and that is by increasing the net of the current taxes.

The trade union movement prevents the government from exercising responsible fiscal policy on the expenditure side and forces the government to use revenue raising measures and borrowings to pay for its excessive spending. But let us understand this very clearly: FBT is purely a revenue measure which continues to spread its ugly tentacles way beyond the original purpose for which it was intended.
One recommendation of the JCPA report No. 326, which I personally strongly supported at the time, was recommendation 26 which said:

SPEECH.PARA: All future tax legislation be supported by a taxation impact statement which details the impact on taxpayers of the legislation including the total compliance cost and the extent to which simplification objectives have been achieved.
In its response to report 326, the government supported this recommendation. But that was last year. I can see the papers associated with this bill, but where is the taxation impact statement?

PARA.TAB: In making this recommendation, the committee assumed that certain procedures would be followed and that consultation with business would have to be undertaken and the results of this consultation published. Was the trade union movement consulted? Are they subject to fringe benefits tax? I understand they are exempt from income tax. There is no indication in the bill or the supporting documents that such consultation has taken place.
