We find legislation appearing before us in this place which corrects things like errors in drafting, anomalies or unintended consequences—you can call it what you like. The simple fact is that the parliament quite often has to revisit legislation because it is wrong. That was the purpose of recommendation 26 in relation to tax law.

I ask the minister: where is the taxation impact statement? Who was consulted? What assurances do we have that this legislation before us is correct? How do we know that we will not be revisiting this matter next week, next month or next year? It flies in the face of the JCPA report to introduce this bill in September when its provisions come into effect in the previous financial year.

Is the government treating the parliament again with contempt? Is the government assuming that this bill will pass through both houses without amendment? What happens to businesses which have lodged returns if this legislation is amended? Will the businesses be penalised? The government's logic on simplification and reducing the cost of compliance is flawed. If simplification and reducing the cost of compliance reduce revenue, it shows what an anomalous tax FBT and its administration add up to.

Businesses in my electorate laughed at the government's attempts to redress the high cost of compliance. On the one hand the government reduces business costs, the cost of compliance; on the other hand you increase the rate of tax applicable to motor vehicles to make up for the revenue shortfall. That's clever! Tell me how business wins from that. Tell me how that reduces costs. Tell me how that makes it more competitive. Tell me how that addresses our balance of payments problem. Tell me how that creates more jobs.

In the committee stage members will have a chance to examine each of these measures in the bill in detail. I presume the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) will be in the House in the committee stage and I want to address a number of questions to him on the question of consultation, a taxation impact statement which details the impact on taxpayers, including total compliance costs, and the extent to which simplification objectives have been achieved.

The shadow Treasurer, my colleague the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Costello), in speaking to this bill foreshadowed an amendment in the committee stage to modify the hours of exemption from 7 p.m. to 7 a.m. to take account of commercial realities. This amendment is in relation to that section of the bill which exempts taxi travel provided to employees for travel direct between home and work between 8 p.m. and 6 a.m. and taxi travel for sick and injured employees to travel from their usual place of residence. We accept that this amendment which the Assistant Treasurer has introduced in this bill is a sensible one but we believe that our amendment to change those hours of applicability is more commercially realistic.

In conclusion, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition quoted some of the tax experts in this country about the fringe benefits tax. It has been said before but it is worth repeating that, as much as we search the documentation, we do not find anybody who supports the way that this tax is applied. Bob Jeffery, the National President of the Australian Society of CPAs, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The so-called review of FBT has turned out to be just a thinly veiled exercise to appease genuine business concerns while still slugging business to raise the same amount of money.
I covered that before. It is inequitable and business does not understand why that has happened. Bob Bryant, Executive Director of the Corporate Tax Association, said:
What he handed down in our view was not a serious attempt to come to grips with the inadequacies of the FBT regime. He has let us down.
David Taylor, Chief Executive of the New South Wales Chamber of Commerce, said:

No business, small or big, will benefit from this. All the government has done is admit it has made hideous errors with FBT. Small business may have a few less forms to fill in, but the underlying problems with FBT and the difficulties caused are still there.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting, when discussing the Taxation Laws Amendment (FBT Cost of Compliance) Bill 1995, to consider the history of the fringe benefit tax. I can recall quite vividly that, when it was first introduced, the Treasurer at the time—the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—made a declaration that fringe benefits taxes would be assessed, and would be taxed to the employee and not the employer.

PARA.TAB: Within 24 hours, the ACTU boss—I think it was Mr Cliff Dolan—found out that his package had been arranged on the basis of free cars, free accommodation and free everything else and, apparently, got in touch with the Treasurer of the day. Within that 24-hour period, we had the fringe benefits tax's impact being reversed from the point where it should be, on the employee, onto the shoulders of the employer. I think we should always remember that this deep commitment that the Labor Party has had to a fair and equitable fringe benefits tax was determined solely on the point that the ACTU boss did not think it was equitable and told the Treasurer of the day that it was.

I have no trouble in understanding that fringe benefits should be assessed; I just have difficulty in knowing where that assessment should be. In this connection, abuses were there. Given the salary packages that were being offered—and it mainly was at the high end of the business area that they were being offered—by way of accommodation, light rental, education for children, motor vehicles, telephones and the whole lot of those things, there was obviously an abuse of procedures and they should have been assessed. Perhaps the only way around that was to tell the business end of town that these packages were not going to be tolerated in the future unless there was tax paid on them.

But at that stage it was optional. The fact that the previous speaker pointed out that fringe benefits taxpayers have reduced from 138,000 to 128,000 since the time of the first impact, which was in 1994, indicates to me that many of the businesses took the options. They took those cars from the employees, or they gave them one-tonne utilities or things like that, which was okay. They took away those fringe benefits. But it was optional. To the extent that those businesses stayed with the system of paying their own taxes in connection with these benefits, it was recognised by them that these were legitimate expenses incurred in business and perhaps they should pay them.

The trouble today is that fringe benefits taxation is no longer optional. This is particularly clear when one looks at what have been, just in the course of this bill, described as fringe benefits, but really have no connection with FBT. Let us go back to entertainment: entertainment itself is no longer a tax deduction, as far as an employer is concerned. The aspect of entertainment still has within it a no-option basis for an employer.

We can look at the living away from home allowance. I might say that the biggest fringe benefit this government, or this parliament, ever paid was a living away allowance to the then Treasurer, Mr Keating. That was because the allowance was not paid for living away from home; it was an allowance paid for living at home. His own house in Sydney was being renovated and was unlivable, and he still declared it as his residence and was paid a living away allowance in Canberra. That might be fair enough, but it is a fringe benefit. When I challenged this with the Taxation Office—in view of the fact that I did have a constituent who was having trouble with the Taxation Office because of a living away from home allowance and having to justify it—the Taxation Office came back and said that allowance was free from taxation in the hands of the employee. If that was the case, the government certainly should have picked that up and paid tax on it, because it was a living at home allowance, not a living away from home allowance. Yet that finds its way into the current web, but not in the same manner as I have just described.

As for car parking, one is really scratching the bottom of the barrel when suggesting that car parking on an owner's premises is a fringe benefit. Those people have already gone through the rigours of town planning to indicate they are supposed to have the car parking blocks for the purpose they are using them for. To come now and suggest there is a tax payable on it because of certain criteria again insists that the car parking is no longer an option for an employer to avoid. So it goes on.

We can talk in terms of those items which are now being excluded. One has to ask the question, `Why in the name of goodness did the government include them in the first place?' Could I mention them? Exempt items include mobile phones, car phones, protective clothing, briefcases, calculators, tools of trade, computer software for use in an employee's employment, electronic diaries, notebook computers and laptop computers, employee's subscription to trade or professional journals, membership fees and corporate credit cards, and membership fees for airport lounge membership. It just defies belief that in the course of this review we have been assessing employers on these types of benefits that were not benefits in any case. It just goes to show that there is no end to which this government will not go to try to include fringe benefits into the package.

Take taxi travel provided to employees. Under the safety and health regulations I would suggest that this is a prime concern to an employer. If an employee is working after hours and needs a taxi to get home safely, that should be supplied under the normal conditions under which the state says it should be. To suggest that taxi travel in those circumstances is a fringe benefit is an absolute nonsense. There is a long way to go in amending this act before we get back to the option that an employer has as to whether to pay the tax on the benefit or cash out the benefits, as many of them have already done.

Mention has been made already of the New Zealand precedents. Their tax legislation is 51 pages long versus our 300 pages and yet ours is to be extended by another 60 pages to bring this lighter compliance into place. That is a contradiction in terms. To say that we are introducing through this bill something which is easier and not as complicated, and yet it takes 60 pages to do it, is certainly a contradiction.

My son has been studying for a degree and he has just finished studying the fringe benefits tax. Although he passed the examination he was driven mad by the tax because there are so many contradictions in it and it is absolutely not understandable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you give him your speeches on this? Did you give copies to your son?

—I will give a few more speeches in future. Thankfully, he did pass the examination. This is the problem: the old common law adage that ignorance of the law is no excuse. I could find tax practitioners in this country who would admit they do not understand this law. That is a ridiculous situation and now we have the 300 pages versus the 51 pages in New Zealand.

PARA.TAB: I wonder whether any government member has had experience of running a small business or a business of any description. Do they know the cost of compliance and the cost of taxation on those businesses? The fact that there are only four of them prepared to speak in this debate suggests to me that most of them are going to use the excuse back in their electorates when talking to small business operators, `At least I did not speak on the bill in the House.' That will be a great way to recommend to employers out there that they did not support the bill. But ring the bells and they will be in here to support the government.

Has the minister at the table, the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee), had experience in small business and experience in employing people and knowing what the cost of compliance is? We have had this compliance cost factored into this. The cost of compliance in Australia is 11 times greater than it is in the United Kingdom and six times greater than it is in New Zealand. It is 10.2 per cent of the cost of the tax itself.

I am associated with a small business, and every time I go to a board meeting I cop a trouncing on this type of thing. Recently in the House, we have had to put up with the stupidity of trying to simplify company law. It is not a simplification. It goes right back to imposing further burdens on small business. I would suggest that people within the Australian Taxation Office should have a couple of years experience in small business so they know exactly what the impact is.

In the small business I am referring to, we probably employ one or two people just to keep track of taxes and their implications. Having made that admission, I am probably going to be told that that is another fringe benefit and that the employer should be taxed accordingly. The cost of compliance which this bill is endeavouring to reduce begs the question of why it was so difficult to understand before and why the cost of compliance was so heavy.

If any members of the government, anyone in the Taxation Office, or anyone in the bureaucracy were in a small business, they would know that the costs of compliance, taxation, health and safety regulations, training regulations, excise, payroll tax, the superannuation guarantee—the list just goes on and on—are telling features. That is why small business is suffering as it is.

As I said, the fringe benefits tax was designed to cover abuses. But it is no longer optional. In fact, the whole thing is a miserly approach by the government to gather more tax so it can cover its huge spending agenda. I have to say that, over the last 13 or 14 years, this Labor government has made an art form of the acceleration of the payment of tax—and that is just the acceleration—and it has delved into every corner to tax items which should not be taxed in the way they are. Just as an indication, revenue collection for 1994-95 is estimated at $2.720 billion and for 1995-96 it is $2.840 billion. That is an indication in itself that this government is only interested in getting taxpayers to pay more taxes.

In the Australian dated 19 September 1995, an article on a study undertaken by Access Economics says that the total tax burden on workers is greater now than it was 10 years ago when the tax summit was held. This study also reveals that Australians are paying more in indirect tax than they would have under the coalition's goods and services tax plan. The report by Access Economics shows that workers have received a poor return for 10 years of income tax cuts under Labor. This is all hailed as part of the glorious tradition of tax reform. It is not tax reform; it is tax exploitation at its worst. This government has an addiction to raising taxes and slugging businesses and workers alike, often to the detriment of the economy.

In evidence given before the Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration when it was visiting tourist establishments right around Australia, a basic complaint—and it was demonstrated when people were entertaining the committee on occasions—was that the managers had to separate the cost of their entertainment, for fringe benefits taxation purposes, while they were entertaining visitors. The actual cost of compliance for that drink or that meal would have been as great as the cost of the taxation itself.

The member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) mentioned pastoral awards this morning, and I believe they should be mentioned again. Board and accommodation requirements are written into the pastoral awards so that no pastoralist can charge an amount for that, and yet fringe benefits tax is applied to it. The inquiry by the Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration was also asked by witnesses why people had to pay fringe benefits tax on health and safety issues.

Let us look at isolated mining townships: is it a fringe benefit when you are living in such isolated areas—which most of our mines are in—to accept lower priced accommodation, particularly when that is an agreement between the employer and the employee written into an award? Is it a fringe benefit to provide airconditioning and power in places where the temperature gets up to 35 to 40 degrees celsius? Is it a fringe benefit to provide annual visits to major centres, so that these people can leave their isolated surroundings and go elsewhere? Is it a fringe benefit to send their children elsewhere for education, when that township is so small that it cannot provide the education that is required? Of course, it is not. Many mining companies have now adopted fly in, fly out arrangements which as yet have not been accepted as a fringe benefit.

I refer again to the pastoral awards. It is worse since an amendment was made last year. A lot of people on the land would not, if the employee was taxed on the benefit, pay anywhere near the high rate of tax that applies to the fringe benefits tax; it would probably be half of what it is. Yet the fringe benefits tax is applied at that higher rate. The situation is even worse in many of the pastoral industries and establishments in my area. Although people are not earning sufficient income to pay tax, they are being called on to pay the fringe benefits tax on the grossing up system, and they get no relief for the taxation paid from the other end.

At least under the old system, if they had no income the fact that the fringe benefits tax was not a tax deduction meant that they did not suffer any disadvantage. But after five years in drought situations many of my pastoralists are now being called on, through the grossing up situation, to pay the tax, although they cannot get the deduction because their income is so low. These are items that have to be addressed.

I have already mentioned some of the New Zealand comparisons, and I note that the New Zealand tax reform package is far superior to Australia's tax exploitation package. This is showing in New Zealand's economic results.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's because they've got a GST. You'd love to introduce one.

—What is wrong with GST? I ask that question because 10 years ago at that same tax summit your current Prime Minister was very much in favour of option C. He still would be in favour of option C because he knows it is the sensible way to go. That is not just a politician speaking; you ask any business in Australia today, particularly those who are exporting, whether they would like an alternative to your sales tax indirect taxation. They would say `yes'.

PARA.TAB: It is significant that 10 years after the then Treasurer was forced to bow to the whims of his trade unionists he is now collecting more in indirect taxation, particularly through the sales tax, than would have been collected through the GST proposed in 1993. The minister at the table does not stand on very safe ground when he talks of that tax reform—a GST, which he himself would privately champion, and which his Prime Minister certainly championed at one time.

I believe we can look to New Zealand in many ways. Their taxation law has the merit of simplicity. They may be taking a tax on a fringe benefit basis, they may be taking tax in many other ways, but they are outperforming Australia in leaps and bounds as far as the economy is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Except for jobs growth.

—They are fair dinkum jobs. The 600,000 jobs that you tell us about refer to people who might be employed for two hours at the most on a casual basis, or any other basis, and yet you come into this House and say there are 600,000 jobs. What a load of codswallop. The whole thing is just a nonsense. The minister at the table knows it and he would do better not to interject.

PARA.TAB: Ignorance of the law was never an excuse as far as compliance with any act was concerned. We have now got to a situation where this cannot be asserted. There needs to be a lot more done to bring Australia's spending structure back within limits, to enable us to tax people sufficiently to bring this budget into balance.

But what taxation law does lack is equity and simplicity. While this bill in some way goes to correct anomalies which should never have been taxed in the first place, we have a long way to go before we reach a situation where we can say that Australia's system sits with New Zealand's—as an encouragement to business to get out and expand, an encouragement to business to profit, and an encouragement to business to employ. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment (FBT Cost of Compliance) Bill 1995 is designed to reduce costs to small business but is going to raise another $121 million in the financial year 1995-96. It is also designed to reduce the cost of compliance to small business but overlooks many of the major compliance costs that small businesses face at the present time. The government proclaims that the bill will have a particular impact but an examination of it shows that it will do the opposite.

PARA.TAB: The bill implements the results of the government's review of fringe benefits tax compliance costs announced by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) on 24 February 1995. The review was announced on 10 May 1994 in the 1994-95 budget. The government anticipated announcing the results in July, but they were not announced until some seven months later. When announcing the review in May 1994, the Treasurer said that the aim was to minimise compliance costs while protecting the tax base and the overall equity of the tax system. He has used the protection of the tax base argument as an excuse to increase the fringe benefits tax payable on cars to compensate for the loss of revenue which will result from relaxing the car parking rules and exempting minor benefits such as laptop computers. The other changes are expected to have only a minimal effect on the revenue.

The review has been described by the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants as a `bald-faced revenue raising exercise which simply reshuffles the formula by which the Government milks business for every last cent in an effort to raise its own revenue base'. Others have also been disappointed that the review did not go far enough. Some have argued that the effect will not be revenue neutral but will increase the revenue take.

So the government is to be condemned for its poor performance in relation to the review, something which small businesses and middle sized businesses, in particular, throughout Australia have been waiting for in the hope that there might have been some real action taken in terms of the costs of compliance with this taxation. After announcing the results of the review some seven months after the scheduled date, the government has now taken a further few months to introduce the legislation to implement the review and it has also made changes to the original announcement in the bill.

One of the ironies of the review is that employers who currently use the statutory method to calculate their fringe benefits tax liability on cars may switch to the alternative method, which has higher compliance costs, in order to avoid paying more fringe benefits tax. Of course, the review was necessary in the first place because of the widespread complaint, indeed widespread condemnation, about the cost of complying with this tax measure throughout the business community. In fact, compliance costs were unreasonably high in Australia and, even after this bill, will remain so.

The 1993 study by Pope, Fayle and Chen, The compliance costs of employment related taxation in Australia, estimated the total compliance costs of fringe benefits tax in 1989 at $128 million or 10.9 per cent of the fringe benefits tax revenue. That is, 10.9 per cent is the proportion of the revenue which is raised in order to comply with this taxation measure. They concluded that the compliance costs were high when expressed as a percentage of tax revenue and made the telling comparison with New Zealand, where the percentage is nowhere near 10.9 per cent; it is just 1.7 per cent.

So a comparison across the Tasman Sea shows that we have a compliance cost regime in Australia which is about 10 times as expensive as that which is operating in New Zealand. In other words, every one of the almost one million small businesses in Australia is paying, in complying with the fringe benefits tax legislation, 10 times the equivalent costs in New Zealand. We talk in this country—and we hear from the Prime Minister and ministers from time to time—about how we have to adopt international best practice, how we have to be competitive with the rest of the world and yet, when compared with New Zealand, Australia has this massive discrepancy.

If you take the figures which were cited as the costs in 1989-90 in the report by Messrs Pope, Fayle and Chen and then you apply that percentage to today's figures, you come out with a result that the compliance cost to business for raising this revenue for the government is something like $350 million a year—$350 million a year which Australian businesses, many of them small business, are paying out simply to comply with this legislation in the first place. That is something which is unacceptable. It is something which hits small businesses very hard. The same study estimated that, so far as small businesses were concerned, the compliance cost represented 42 per cent of the fringe benefits tax which was actually paid by the small businesses themselves. So, if you get a situation in a small business where the cost of actually complying with the legislation is the equivalent of almost half the tax you pay, I think that points out how ludicrously high the compliance costs are. Here we have the Treasurer saying that this bill will dramatically reduce compliance costs, but when you look at the bill it will not do that at all.

The Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) announced that the package would dramatically reduce compliance costs. The Corporate Tax Association said that a survey of Australia's top 100 companies revealed that the so-called improvements to FBT will cost these companies additional fringe benefits tax of $28.7 million annually. The survey also revealed that there would be minimal savings in compliance costs.

When we talk about FBT, it ought to be put in the context of the total tax system in Australia. If you look at what has happened to the tax system under this government, you will see that there has been over the period of the Hawke and Keating government a continual increase in the tax take from Australians, from individuals and from businesses. For example, since 1983 total individual tax has risen by 136.8 per cent. Total company tax has risen by a massive 370 per cent. Total indirect tax has risen by 149.8 per cent. Sales taxes under this government have increased by 305.7 per cent. This is the government the Prime Minister of which ran around the country campaigning against a GST because it was going to increase taxes on ordinary Australians, yet here he is, day after day, month after month, year after year, increasing taxes on ordinary Australians through company taxes and indirect taxes and others included. The total tax revenue will also have gone up by 189.8 per cent with taxes—if they had all been effected—that were announced in the budget. So you can see that over the period of this government there has been a massive increase in taxes in this country.

We also see that, compared with those countries which we were repeatedly being told we have to compete with, some of our tax rates are not competitive tax rates. For example, if you take company tax rates in our region, you will see that, compared with a company tax rate of 36 per cent in Australia, Hong Kong's company tax rate is just 17.5 per cent, Taiwan's is 25 per cent, Singapore's is 27 per cent and Indonesia's, Thailand's and Malaysia's are 30 per cent. The company tax rates for operating businesses in those Asian countries which directly compete with us are all below the tax rate here in Australia. This week we have had a report from Access Economics which says that the total tax burden on workers in Australia is greater now than it was 10 years ago when the now Prime Minister, then Treasurer, Paul Keating, unveiled his tax reform package to slash marginal tax rates to, as he said at the time, restore some fairness and credibility to the tax system.

Despite that fine sounding rhetoric, what he has done is continually rip off more and more tax from more and more Australians, whether they be individuals or businesses. In fact, those on average earnings of $28,348 a year are paying just $4 a week less in income tax now than they did in 1985, when average earnings were less than $19,000 a year. When the superannuation guarantee levy charge is added to the equation, the total tax burden is greater today than it was in 1984-85, for all but the highest income earners in Australia.

Of course, that points to the other phenomena which is continuing to occur in this country, and that is the gap between those who are poor and those who are very rich, which continues to widen in this country. Here we have a government—a Labor government—that proclaims the virtues of egalitarianism and has actually presided over the greatest change in terms of the widening gap between the poor and the very rich in this country, and it goes on today, even as I speak.

To return to the particular bill before the House, I said at the outset that one of the things which this bill purported to do was to reduce compliance costs. Yet, in fact, it overlooks one of the major concerns of business so far as complying with the legislation is concerned, and that is the misaligned reporting period for fringe benefits tax compared with the income tax year. The fringe benefits tax year, of 1 April to 31 March, and the income tax year, of 1 July to 30 June, are obviously misaligned, and this has enormous costs for business.

Taxpayers have continually requested that the FBT year of tax be aligned with the income tax financial year, under the Income Tax Assessment Act, due to the prohibitive compliance costs of the FBT year of tax straddling two financial years. An intolerable situation has occurred for business in this country since July 1986, wherein, in order to determine the FBT taxable amount, an employer must first review two separate accounting periods, being the period from 1 April to 30 June and the period from 1 July to 31 March in the subsequent financial year. In order to avoid any unfavourable negative cash flow consequences, all that would need to be done in relation to this would be to change the quarterly FBT instalment dates, which can be done pursuant to section 103 of the fringe benefits tax legislation.

So, when the government talks in this legislation about reducing compliance costs, the most obvious compliance cost which is facing business—the most obvious compliance cost which business owners and operators have to face year after year—is a reporting period for one system of taxation which ends on one date and a reporting period for another system of taxation which ends on another date. That involves a great deal of additional paper work in aligning those two periods, in terms of the records and the returns of each and every small business in Australia that is subject to FBT and to other taxation. All that needs to be done is to align those two periods. Here we have a government saying that this is a massive reduction in the compliance costs for business, while the most glaringly obvious matter which could be corrected is simply left uncorrected in this legislation.

There are also other examples where the government has not taken any steps to change the legislation and, therefore, the costs that remain on business. The meal entertainment allowance and problems arising with that have been referred to by other speakers. It is interesting to read a story on the front page of the Financial Review of Wednesday, 16 August this year, which says:

Australia is losing out on a share of the $600 billion in wealth generated by the Chinese diaspora in Asia because of high taxes, high labour costs and a complex tax system, the Federal Government has been warned.

A major report by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade also criticises Australian endeavours to forge business ties with overseas Chinese noting that many joint ventures have failed because of "poorly selected local partners".
Australia's tax system—particularly the controversial fringe benefits tax—was regularly cited by ethnic Chinese as the key constraint on their investment in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: It went on to say:
The FBT, as it applies to business entertaining, was seen as unnecessarily penalising one of the main ways in which Asian business people do business: over a meal and outside the office.

This is not a report which has been written by somebody sympathetic to the coalition; this is a report which comes from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. The government's own bureaucrats, their own advisers, are saying, `Here is a major problem as far as investment in this country is concerned.' There is a major bucket of investment from the Chinese quarter available, but it is going elsewhere. And why? Because we have an uncompetitive tax system in this country and, if we do not do something about it, that situation will continue to apply.

PARA.TAB: I do not intend to go through all the deficiencies in this legislation. They have been pointed out in some detail by the shadow Treasurer. What concerns me is the failure to go further and to address the real problems with compliance, problems which can just be enumerated in the time available here. There is difficulty in the preparation of FBT returns spanning the two financial years, as I indicated. We have a situation where employees must complete declarations, but the employer is responsible for the information contained therein. This is inequitable and time consuming, for both the employer and the tax office.

There are problems with phones and car parking—car parking having been pointed out by others in the duration of this debate. There are also problems with housing benefits, some of which were pointed out by a previous speaker in this debate. There are many other problems. For example, for self-education purposes for income tax, an individual must deduct the first $250 under section 82A. Yet, if the employer pays the self-education expenses of an employee, for FBT purposes no such requirement exists. The tax office also says that, where a long-distance truck driver receives an allowance for meals and incidental expenses, he or she is only exempt from substantiation if the allowance is reasonable and he or she is away for five nights. If you are a public servant and you are away for more than 10 hours, you do not have to substantiate a reasonable allowance.

Another problem—and there are myriad problems which time prevents me going into this afternoon—is that, where an employer is required to provide sun hats and sunscreen for employees to protect them from the sun, the Australian Taxation Office will apply the FBT to the benefit provided to the employees. How ridiculous can things get! In this country we have had campaigns going on now for over a decade to reduce the incidence of cancer—in particular, to reduce the incidence of skin cancer, particularly in the more northern parts of this country but also in southern states, such as Victoria, whence I come—yet, if an employer provides sun hats and sunscreen to an employee, this is regarded as a benefit for which fringe benefits tax must be paid!

That, in a nutshell, encapsulates some of the problems with this legislation. It is legislation which has obviously been written by bureaucrats in an office in Canberra who have no real appreciation for the real world outside this city. The real world, in which Australia hopefully can stride forward, will not be generated in this city; it will be generated outside in the areas in which small businesses are trying to operate, despite all the problems which this legislation fails to address.

So the difficulty with this legislation is that, as usual, the government says it is doing one thing but, when you read the fine print and look at the way in which it actually will be applied, it is having the opposite effect. There is much more that needs to be done as far as fringe benefits tax compliance costs go in Australia. If we are going to be a competitive nation, we have to make sure that in this country the circumstances exist in which small businesses, in particular, can go forward in a way which gives them confidence that they can compete on terms which are equal to, if not better than, those for small businesses in other parts of the world.

In order to do that, this legislation needs a great deal more refinement than has been generated by this particular bill. In some cases, this bill is not going to aid the situation but is actually going to put small business further behind the eight ball. For those reasons, and for the reasons which will be addressed in more detail in the consideration in detail stage of this bill, we find that this is a highly inadequate way in which to try to deal with compliance costs. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to talk on another ALP achievement—a convoluted tax that is a burden on business. I am, of course, referring to the fringe benefits tax. Only the Labor Party could turn the tax act into a multi-volumed administrative nightmare and consider that an achievement. These amendments stem from the review of the FBT compliance costs which was announced by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) on 24 February 1995. In typical fashion, the government's announcement of the results of the review was also seven months late.

PARA.TAB: When announcing the review, the Treasurer said its aim was to minimise compliance costs whilst protecting the tax base and overall equity of the system. So what happened? I think it is worth quoting the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants. They described the results as:

SPEECH.PARA: A bald-faced revenue raising exercise which simply reshuffles the formula by which the Government milks business for every last cent in an effort to raise its own revenue base.
You cannot get it much clearer than that, and that is pretty much the reality. Under this tax-and-spend government, any opportunity will be taken to squeeze more tax out of the people.

PARA.TAB: It is remarkable that we are discussing this package 10 years almost to the day after the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) `reformed' our tax system. It was on 19 September 1985 that he presented his tax reform package. It was supposed to slash marginal tax rates and make the system more equitable. It is ironic that Access Economics has now produced a report which shows that Australians are now carrying a greater tax burden than in pre-reform package days. Again, the ones who have suffered most in this are Australia's middle class. And here we are, still discussing reforms and amendments in some sort of annual ritual that the parliament goes through to make the package seem more workable.

The fringe benefits tax is now a major money spinner for the government. The budget papers estimate that the tax take from FBT will increase from $2.7 billion in 1994-95 to $2.8 billion in 1995-96, after already increasing from the 1993-94 tax take of $1.4 billion. The FBT is manna from heaven for a tax-and-spend government like this one. Any time you need a bit more cash to pay for out of control spending, just widen the FBT net a bit more. After all, it is only business that suffers the consequences.

For the benefit of my colleagues opposite, they might remember that it is business that does the employing in this country. In fact, the FBT has now become such an expense that the Financial Review wrote recently that some executives were reported as saying that the expense of keeping records for the latest additions to the tax were in excess of the tax actually collected. That is tax reform, Labor style!

Instead of being able to get on with the business of making profits, growing and employing, firms are having to divert significant resources to the onerous tax detail. The only thing growing out of control are the screams of frustration from business and tax accountants in regard to the FBT. But it would seem that the ALP does not even bat an eyelid. It has, in fact, bettered its ambitions in regard to this area. Not only is the FBT time consuming and onerous, but apparently even tax accountants consider its requirements onerous as well.

As an interesting aside, the Tax Institute of Australia had a party yesterday—but they were not celebrating tax reforms; they were commemorating the comparative simplicity of the tax system of the days prior to the Prime Minister's tax reform package. As Peter Cowdroy, the national president of the institute, said, `There's not a hell of a lot to celebrate.' It really raises the question of whether there is anyone, other than lifetime tenured tax office bureaucrats, who thinks that the FBT is working well?

The coalition supports the government seeking to stop tax evasion but what we take issue with is the method. Even these new amendments, while going some of the way to alleviating compliance costs, still have problems. Let us look at a couple of areas. There is the living away from home allowance amendment. This benefit arises when an employee is paid an allowance in the nature of compensation for additional expenses incurred, and other disadvantages suffered, because the employee is required to live away from home to perform employment duties. This amendment provides that the allowance will only be a fringe benefit where the total period for which the employee has lived or is required to live away from his or her home is less than four years for a foreigner or Australian posted overseas or one year for an Australian resident.

What is involved in this? While this will introduce greater certainty about when an employee is considered to be living away from home for the first time, employers will be required to provide declarations which will duplicate the employee declaration. In addition, before the taxable value of the benefit can be reduced for accommodation, the amounts spent have to be substantiated, thereby increasing compliance costs yet again. This is reform ALP style—more paperwork and more compliance costs within the bill to reduce compliance costs.

In addition, why is there a differential between domestic postings and foreign postings or between Australian residents or temporary residents? One wonders whether we will be back looking at this in the future in yet another fringe benefits tax amendment bill. The real sting in the tail is the statutory formula for car benefits. The government has lost some revenue by making it easier for business with other measures, so it is going to belt business to make up for it. It is no coincidence that this measure is being targeted at the most commonly provided benefits, and that is cars. It is another revenue hit to the tune of $121 million in 1995-96 and $91 million each year thereafter.

You will not see this government giving up any revenue, unless it is an election issue when it makes lots of promises and commitments about lowering taxes so it can break them at the first opportunity. Under this amendment, employers are given a choice. They can reduce their compliance costs by using the statutory method but they will have to pay higher tax, or they can pay a lower tax cost by staying with the operating cost formula but pay higher compliance costs as a result. What a choice! It is lower compliance and higher tax or higher compliance and lower tax. Either way, business ends up paying the price.

One would think that this government might consider lowering compliance and lowering tax, but not this tax-and-spend government. I often ask myself how anyone who knows anything about business could continue to come up with such convoluted schemes, but then it dawns on me. They keep coming up with these schemes because they do not know anything about business. They have never worked in business or been in a position where the health of a business is vital to its profitable outlook. The FBT convolution simply reflects the background of the members of the government.

Let us look at the list of ministers. You have the Treasurer. His occupation before entering parliament was research officer and industrial advocate for the ACTU. You have the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook). His occupation before entering parliament was secretary of the Western Australian Trades and Labour Council and vice-president of the ACTU. You have the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley). His occupation before entering parliament was lecturer in social and political theory. Then there is the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton). His occupation before entering parliament was some sort of traineeship in the electrical trades and then he went straight into parliament. And let us not forget the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht), the supposed advocate for small business. His occupation before entering parliament was primary school teacher, temporary organiser for the Australian Labor Party and political press secretary.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about me?

—I'll let you off, David. Then, of course, there is the Prime Minister himself, the Hon. Paul Keating. What did the Prime Minister do before coming into parliament? In addition to spending a very brief time with David Jones, he was a research officer and industrial advocate for the Federated Municipal and Shire Council Employees Union of Australia. He also managed a rock band into oblivion. Some things never change—he is obviously employing those skills in his current job! The point is that the senior members of this government, the people who make these decisions, cannot even begin to grasp the impact at anything more than an academic level simply because they have no experience of life in the business world.

PARA.TAB: However, the problem is not an isolated one. It is symptomatic of their whole approach, as evidenced by the lift in company tax and wholesale sales taxes on cars, and also the attempt to put the WST on building products. This government promised not to impose any new taxes. But to feed its spending frenzy and to support its loose fiscal policy at the time of the last budget, it imposed extra taxes on companies, lifting the company tax rate from 33c in the dollar to 36c in the dollar, and lifting company car tax from the 15 per cent threshold to 20 per cent, and now to 22 per cent.

When the government lowered that tax from 20 per cent to 15 per cent, the Prime Minister said that they were proposing to lower the rate permanently to 15 per cent. We now know that `permanent' in this government's terms means a very short period; in fact, until such time as it needs to get more money to feed its spending habit. This happened despite promises to the contrary.

In addition to this, the waterfront is going backwards, labour market reform has stalled and onerous requirements have been imposed relating to native title. This is all symptomatic of a government which is out of touch with the sector that generates growth and employment—the private sector. These things make it harder to do business in Australia and make it more tempting for businesses which can move offshore to do so. Why, for example, is BHP opening operations in South America, despite the vast mineral resources in this country? BHP's investment in job growth will benefit the citizens of Chile, but not those of Australia.

This example, and others like it, should be ringing alarm bells for this government. We need to keep as much activity as possible in this country. We need to make it easier for businesses to do business in this country and to employ Australians. That starts with the budget. We need to ensure that tax is as simple as possible to collect and pay, and is as low as is reasonable.

To assist in this, we need to ensure that government spending is as low as possible within the parameters of legitimate government activity. This is clearly not the case. Spending is too high, having almost taken on a life of its own in recent years. This causes increasing pressure for more and more taxes, and this means that areas such as fringe benefits are placed under increasing pressure to feed government coffers. This bill is a case in point.

So great is this government's need for tax that it is not possible to simply reduce compliance costs to absorb the revenue impact. Tax must be lifted in the same bill to offset it all; so business is no better off in real tax terms. As I mentioned earlier, the problem you get in this country with these sorts of taxes is that we still have 750,000 Australians unemployed; a record foreign debt of $180 billion; the worst current account deficit in the OECD, and growing; and underlying inflation starting to grow to boot.

We need a vibrant business sector devoting as much time as possible to doing business, not filling out forms to satisfy bureaucrats. This bill is a very small step down that road; there is still a vast amount to do. The difference between the government and the opposition is that we will take on the hard yards, not just talk about doing it. As I mentioned, the problem with the government's FBT legislation is that the government has to keep feeding an ever-growing need for spending. In the 1990s alone, this government has run up debt and has run budget deficits of just on $50 billion. That is why in this year's budget there is a figure of some $9.3 billion just to service Commonwealth debt.

Had this government a more responsible fiscal policy, they would not need to put up company tax to lift the WST on cars and start to make it difficult for that industry. They would not have needed to go for the throat of the building industry, which measure luckily was knocked off, to fund the bottom line. They would not have needed to increase taxes had they run budget surpluses when the economy was of a mind to let them do it. We would not now have such a large figure in this budget, such as $9.3 billion, to cover Commonwealth debt.

This government does not understand business. They do not understand the need to have a healthy economic sector so businesses in this country can employ more Australians. This government does not understand that if they do not increase national savings they have been the villains. We can only have constrained growth and that is the very reason we are choking off growth in this country at this point.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ambit of the fringe benefits tax is very discriminatory. It is like petrol taxes that apply to one sector of the community and not to another sector. Petrol taxes, which will bring in effectively around $10,000 million this year—one tenth of the entire budget revenue—are levied upon people who go to work of a morning in their cars. In the electorate that I represent many of those people drive 60 or 70 kilometres to work. My son drives 40 kilometres to work of a morning and home again in the evening, as do the other 400 miners who work at Mount Leishan mine. Similarly in Mount Isa, at the Hilton mine, people drive a considerable distance to get to work. Shearers—to a large degree these days their work is called `suburban shearing'—drive out in the morning and back in the evening even though the distances are huge. When those people go to work they are taxed.

PARA.TAB: The vast bulk of employees that work in the cities—some 60 per cent of them—go to work of a morning on commuter transportation systems which are effectively funded by the public purse. In Queensland, 50 per cent of the cost of the commuter rail system and arguably 50 per cent of the cost of the commuter bus system in Brisbane is paid for by the public purse.

For those people who go to work in the country areas outside of Brisbane—Brisbane is the only place in Queensland that has a commuter system: effectively there is no commuter system outside of Brisbane, and that includes the Gold Coast as well as places like Townsville—there is a 50 per cent tax levied on their motor vehicle. If a fringe benefits tax is levied as well, the rate will be even more than 50 per cent. When I say that the rate is 50 per cent, I might add that it is made up of a 22 per cent sales tax regime and a 27 per cent tariff regime on top of that, which brings it up to 49 per cent. The electorate that I represent is the third biggest in terms of population in Australia. I represent more people in this House than anyone else, with the exception of three other members of parliament.

For the people I represent, there is absolutely no commuter system. A significant proportion of them get assistance from their employer to get to work of a morning. The mining companies most certainly pay some assistance to their employees. So they pay a fringe benefits tax, the tariff to protect jobs in the cities as well as a sales tax that is not levied upon anyone else to get to work. On top of that we have the petrol tax, which is now 130 per cent. When they go to work of a morning, they pay a tax rate of between 50 per cent and 130 per cent. The people in the cities who go to work of a morning enjoy a subsidy from the government to the tune of 50 per cent. As my own son is aware, the cost of driving 40 kilometres to and from work is quite considerable in a year. The city of Charters Towers, if you like, and the city of Mount Isa, are not only taxed upon that but also bear another cost burden—the fringe benefits tax.

I could go on ad infinitum giving anecdotal evidence of how the fringe benefits tax is a totally unacceptable tax to the people in the state of Queensland who live outside Brisbane. When this coalition was in government and attempted to bring in a fringe benefits tax, my own government in Queensland, along with the trade union movement—which was remarkably silent when this government brought it in—fought tenaciously against it. I suppose the trade union movement was silent because the tax was levied on the employers. There was unanimity of opinion and unanimity of rejection of that proposal.

Whether or not the employer meets the burden in a well-regulated society, there should not be any excess profits because where there is decent unionism—not that we have that in Queensland with the likes of the AWU representing about half the work force; it is anything but—those excess profits are taken by the wage earners. That is not a bad thing; that is a good thing. If there are no excess profits, obviously there must be some pain inflicted here.

Suddenly Mount Isa Mines is up for another $1 1/2 million for travel allowance alone. The trade union leadership, after a long and protracted fight, won for the workers this wonderful privilege or work practice where the company paid for their entire families to be flown all the way to Brisbane for a holiday and back again. That was a way of overcoming the isolation of the Mount Isa community. It was very much appreciated. The removal of that benefit was substantially the reason behind the worst strike in Queensland in the last 20 or 30 years, which probably goes back to the first Mount Isa strike. The two-week strike at Mount Isa Mines cost the state of Queensland very dearly.

One of the precipitating factors was the fringe benefits tax. The company not only had to pay about $5 million—I cannot remember the figure but it was very large—to fly all of the families to Brisbane and back again but, on top of that, had to pay a fringe benefits tax of another $1 1/2 million to $2 million. Clearly, it was a very significant item in the Mount Isa budget. When times got tough and cutbacks had to come, that privilege was cut because it was such a large item. There was no doubt in anybody's mind that a very large part of the reason for that sudden cut was the imposition of the fringe benefits tax upon it.

Every shire in western Queensland, with the exception of Longreach and one other, has lost between 35 per cent and 54 per cent of its population. Towns like Mount Isa have lost 30 per cent in the last four years. Cloncurry has lost 30 per cent in the last seven years. The population of the vast bulk of the continental land mass is galloping away from Australia. One of the forces that is driving them away is the fringe benefits tax.

Let me explain the pernicious influence of this tax and how, when we talk about micro-economic reform or even macro-economic reform, everything out there in the marketplace is being distorted by this warped imposition. We should not be losing this population from Cloncurry and Mount Isa. Mines are opening up there all the time these days. But the mines are being run by people living in Brisbane. They have a thing called the fly-in. If we turn the clock back prior to the imposition of this fringe benefits tax, we find that the Western Australian, Queensland and Northern Territory governments banned fly-ins. I am informed—although I have not been able to verify it as I have in the other cases—that the New South Wales government has also banned fly-ins. To take a resource from an area and leave it with absolutely nothing, in return for the exploitation and removal of that resource, creates enormous pressures and hatreds. You can see that flashing forth in the Bougainville situation and the Ok Tedi situation in New Guinea.

Let me tell you that, if anyone here had been at the Australian Mining Industry Council President for Australia meeting in Mount Isa recently, they would have seen the same venomous hatreds warping through that community against faraway governments that are destroying our towns and our cities and removing all of the population from the continental land mass of Australia.

No-one in this place ever reflects upon the fact that the population of Australia will decrease. These are not my words. Professor Blandy from the Melbourne University, in a landmark article in the Australian newspaper, quoted the figures for the estimated population of Australia in 2095. I have addressed maybe 100 meetings of various types in the last 12 months, and at every single meeting I have asked what the population of Australia will be in the year 2095. There are 18 million people now. Only one single person, out of about 3,000 or 4,000 people I put that question to, said that the population would be less then than it is now.

The population of Australia in the year 2095 will be six million people. That is all. You do not have to be an Albert Einstein to work out that, if the fertility rate is 1.7, as it is, the population must clearly go down. And, if the immigration is kept at around 50,000 or 60,000, as it is, that will clearly be infinitesimal in the bigger scheme of things. From Boigu Island—and I have visited Boigu on many occasions—you can see on a clear day the Indonesian coastline in West Irian. It is 28 kilometres away. The population of that country will not go down. It will leap from 180 million, as it is today, to 650 million.

Do you think that the halls of power and the people on planet earth will accept the situation where a fat, self-indulgent race of people sit on a continent this size? If we cut away the seven big electorates similar to my own from the rest of Australia off, it still looks like a map of Australia. It is just a narrow belt around the coastline; if you were to cut around the eastern coastline, along the bottom a little bit and then over to the south west, it would still look like a map of Australia, and you would still have 85 per cent of the continental land mass. The people of the world are not that stupid. I have heard people say, `But all that 85 per cent continental land mass is desert.' The people of the world will check up on this. They will find that 75 per cent of Australia's rainfall run-off is in that 85 per cent. Almost all of Australia's water resource is in that 85 per cent of the land mass. Almost half of this nation's arable land is also in that continental land mass.

If you were to drive right across the Kennedy electorate from the town of Prairie to Cloncurry, about 600 or 700 kilometres, you would not get off thick, rich, fertile, rolling, flat, black-soil treeless plains: the best farming country that exists on earth, possibly, because it has never been touched. Nobody lives there; there are no cattle there, no sheep there, there is no water there—there is nothing there.

Since its introduction, the fringe benefits tax has been one of the major driving forces pushing people away from these towns. People went out there because they got free board and accommodation, whether they were working in mining towns such as Mount Isa or Cloncurry or the little townships such as Mary Kathleen or Gunpowder. When working in those towns, they got free accommodation for themselves and their families. In days past they paid very little taxation with the zone allowances that they then received.

When I first worked at Mount Isa Mines, we paid $5 tax on an income of $65 a week, which was about double the weekly earnings in those days. They were very high wages out there, and we paid less than 10 per cent in taxation. But now free housing is a thing of the past. It has been destroyed for the workers of outback Australia by this government because every single mining company has now said, `No longer will we have free housing'. They have decided to fly people. Quite frankly, a lot of the wives think this is quite good as they can live in Mackay, Townsville or Brisbane while their poor damned husbands lives in dog kennels.

I did not pluck that term out of the air; it was a term used by an employee who worked at the Osborne mine. I asked him why he had left and had started work at one of the mines in Charters Towers and he said, `Because I got sick of living in a dog kennel'. On television last night they had pictures from Hong Kong where people live in little boxes six by three by three. I used to go to mining and construction camps in days past and, basically, that was what they lived in—but you did not mind because you made huge amounts of money. You only had to spend a year or two out there and you could go somewhere, buy a business and set yourself up for the rest of your days. But these people lived like that. This man went on to say, `After about six months you are either a druggie or an alcoholic, and', he said, `I didn't want to become either; I looked at the blokes who had been there for a while, and that was not my scene.'

The fact is that you do not watch your kids play football, you are not there with your little daughter when she breaks a leg because you are 1,000 kilometres away in a mining camp—and you most certainly cannot afford the price of chartering an aircraft to go on a 2,000-kilometre round trip—or, when your wife has a crisis and is close to a nervous breakdown, you are not there to hold her hand. These people do not have families.

The price paid for this international competitiveness and the greed of this government is the broken back. Mr Deputy Speaker, you smile. I do not want to reflect upon the chair, but I seriously do not think that this is a matter for a smile or for humour or mirth. I have seen the broken families, I have seen what is happening and what is being foisted upon these people by the intransigence and criminal stupidity of the government in power at the present moment via the fringe benefits tax. Whether a government from our side will show more enlightenment is yet to be seen.

The fly-ins are breaking the hearts of those people who are left. We had the minister for mines, the local state member for Mount Isa, telling us how wonderful everything was going to be for us, how the north-west was going to prosper, but, since these mines announced that they were opening, we have seen a decline of some 30 per cent in the population of Mount Isa. I use that as an example. I could just as easily have used the towns of Mareeba or Chillagoe or a dozen other towns in my electorate which are in exactly the same position. Thank goodness for the small city of Charters Towers; they were able to get in while we were still in government and the mining companies were told to base their work force there.

To deprive these people of free housing is really to take away the great attraction of going west of the Great Divide into a mining town and convincing your wife to go with you. The great attraction is removed once they lose the free housing. Suddenly that place does not have the same attraction. In days past, people would go and work out there for a few years. They would buy a house on the coast and rent it out. By the time they were ready to move back to the coast they would have just about paid the house off. They could go into a free house and look at doing a job that did not pay as much and enjoy the situation they were in.

A lot of the people in the towns in the goldfields had a better standard of living and quality of life than you see anywhere in the world. The houses were nice and they were airconditioned. The towns had all the amenities. Even though the towns were geographically isolated, they presented a high standard of living and quality of life. They are no longer like this. Our families our now separated. A Catholic priest got up at a public meeting in Mount Isa and said, `What do you work for? What do you go out there and get a job for?' Clearly, it is to have a happy family life and to give something to your kids. To deprive kids of a father does not seem to me to be the right way to go about it.

I will be very specific in the minute I have left. In Cloncurry there is a big mine which is 26 kilometres out of town. An awful lot of people throughout Australia drive 26 kilometres to work every morning. The mining company's stated reason for not going there—and this is true—is that it will cost them $800,000 a year to provide housing and it will cost them $1.3 million to fly in.

There is a half a million dollar difference in operating costs between housing and fly-ins. When we take into account this most incredible piece of legislation—this incredible decision by this government—that says that fly-ins are tax deductible but free housing is fringe benefit taxed, suddenly it becomes half a million dollars more expensive to house people and provide them with a standard of living where husbands and wives can live together and fathers can watch their kids grow up. That is the difference. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is good to get the opportunity to speak in the debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment (FBT Cost of Compliance) Bill 1995 and support the amendments moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Costello) which attempt to improve the bill. This bill results from the government's recognition of the fact that the fringe benefits tax, which I think was introduced in the mid-1980s, has mushroomed or grown like a toadstool after a storm on a humid day and its tentacles have reached out into some incredible areas.

PARA.TAB: The genesis for this tax started in 1985 when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the then Treasurer, introduced his historic tax reforms. There was an interesting article in yesterday's Australian with the headline `Keating reforms fail to lighten tax load'. That article stated:

The total tax burden on workers is greater now than it was 10 years ago today when Paul Keating unveiled his historic tax reform package to slash marginal tax rates and restore fairness and credibility to the tax system.
Australians are also paying more in indirect taxes than they would have done under the Coalition's goods and services tax . . .

SPEECH.PARA: The editorial in the same paper stated:

PARA.TAB: Ten years on from the major taxation reforms Mr Keating announced as treasurer, it is time the tax system was put through a fresh round of renovation. The 1985 package was meant to relieve part of the load on middle-income Australians. Mr Keating said they were paying too much income tax, partly because others were avoiding their share. Among the measures announced that day were a capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax, a broader sales tax, dividend imputation and changes to marginal rates of income tax. They were substantial reforms. Labor's courage in making them, and subsequent success at the next election, surprised many people. The reforms suited the times, but a decade's experience has exposed their limits and created a need for further reforms.

SPEECH.PARA: Politics is all about change—the changing landscape of the country, the economy and the people who live within it and how the economy is running. Things are totally different today from what they were 10 years ago, albeit we are still running a very high rate of unemployment. This government has not yet come to realise that a lot of the taxation measures it introduced 10 years ago on the basis that they were going to provide more fairness and equity in the tax system are having a dramatic and profound impact on other areas. One of those areas is unemployment.

PARA.TAB: Talk to any small business person in Australia about their concerns at the way things are running in this country and the first thing they will complain about, the first thing they want changed, are the hassles that are foisted upon them by government: the superannuation guarantee, the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax. All these things provide them with extra paperwork and take away the time they need to spend running a profitable and viable business which will ultimately generate more employment. These are the concerns of small business people throughout Australia.

This bill is an attempt to reduce the impact of compliance with the fringe benefits tax—not the financial impact it has right across the economy, but the compliance impact. The government is not concerned about the financial impact; it is trying to alleviate the pressures of compliance. The fringe benefits tax when first introduced in 1986-87 raised $535 million for the Commonwealth. In answer to a question earlier this week, the Treasurer (Mr Willis) indicated that this year the tax was going to raise $2.1 billion. That is not quite correct. The Treasurer said: `The tax raises at the moment $2.1 billion.' But in this year's budget, in 1995-96, it is estimated that the fringe benefits tax will produce revenue to the Commonwealth of $2.84 billion; that is, $2,840 million being paid out by the productive sector in Australia.

Over time there has been a very strong argument that a tax should have been imposed on the provision of non-cash remuneration. The thing has just mushroomed. It is unbelievable how the tentacles have grown like a cancer to the extent today that the Commonwealth raises $2,840 million from fringe benefits tax. I was in the gallery this morning listening to the second reading speech by the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear). I will quote a few points from it. The Assistant Treasurer said:

SPEECH.PARA: The bill will exempt from fringe benefits tax a range of benefits that are primarily used for business purposes.
That is an interesting admission. He went on:
These benefits include employment related protective clothing, briefcases, calculators, electronic diaries, tools of trade, employment related software and portable computers.

I will guarantee that the majority of people out there in Australia did not realise that a lot of those articles were subject to fringe benefits tax. But the Assistant Treasurer is now exempting those from the act. He went on:
Mobile car phones will also be exempt where their use is primarily for employment purposes.

If an employer supplies an employee with a mobile car phone surely it is for use in the business and he is going to get the greatest benefit out it. Before coming into this place I used to run a couple of real estate offices. We had mobile car phones in the cars. Prior to that we had two-way radios. They were there for the prime purpose of operating the business effectively and efficiently—which they certainly did. The Assistant Treasurer went on to say:

In recognition of the safety and health issues involved, taxis provided by employers to employees to travel to and from home between the hours of 8 p.m. and 6 a.m. will be exempt, as will taxi travel for sick employees to home or to another place of care. The exemption of taxi travel is estimated to cost $45 million.

If the average punter in the community were to read this speech he would say, `Oh, that is going to cost the business community $45 million.' But that is not correct. What the Assistant Treasurer is saying is that it is costing revenue $45 million; it is $45 million that the Commonwealth will not collect because of these exemptions and changes.

PARA.TAB: We welcome these changes as commonsense changes to the fringe benefits tax arrangements that have grown unbelievably over the years. The Assistant Treasurer went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments in the Bill will also reduce the compliance costs associated with the taxation of car parking benefits.
This is an unbelievably complicated and convoluted system of assessing a tax liability. The Assistant Treasurer went on:

First, fringe benefits tax will no longer apply to car parking on the employers' premises unless there is a commercial car parking station within a one kilometre radius that charges more than $5 a day at the beginning of the fringe benefits tax year.

What about Canberra? What about this place? What about the car parking spaces that are provided to ministers, shadow ministers, staffers, the people sitting in the advisers boxes and all the people who work in the building? Are they subject to the fringe benefits tax? Is there a commercial car parking place within a one kilometre radius of this building that charges more than $5 a day?

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—The answer is no. I ask the Assistant Treasurer: is that equitable compared with the CBD in Sydney? An employer might build premises where he is going to provide employment for 100 people. He puts his application before the local government authority and the first thing the authority does is assess the floor area of the building for car parking requirements. The authority says, `Thou shalt provide so many car parking places for your employees as a requirement of the local government act and ordinances in the state.' That employer has to pay something like $10,000 to $15,000 per car parking space because of the number of employees and customers attending at that building every day. We are going to hit that employer with a fringe benefits tax simply because he has had to provide those car parking spaces if there is a public car parking area within one kilometre that charges more than $5 a day.

PARA.TAB: I know that these amendments were framed when looking at the CBD areas in Sydney and Melbourne, but they cover the rest of Australia. I suppose in most cases the one kilometre rule should exempt most of those people, but in some cases it will not. There is going to be a need for further amendments to this legislation.

The general public in Australia—and particularly the small business community—need not think that the government, in introducing this amending legislation, is going to reduce the amount of money collected by the Commonwealth as a fringe benefits tax. In his second reading speech the Assistant Treasurer, when dealing with the statutory car formula, said:

SPEECH.PARA: In order to maintain the revenue neutrality of this package of compliance cost reduction measures, the Bill will increase the statutory fractions used in the statutory formula for car benefits by approximately 10 per cent. Even with these increases in the statutory fractions, the statutory formula will remain significantly concessional under a wide range of circumstances. This amendment is estimated to raise $121 million.

I presume that is $121 million more than appears in this year's budget. It is all about maintaining the revenue neutrality of this piece of legislation—that is, maintaining in 1995-96 that the Commonwealth will collect $2,840 million fringe benefits tax from the business community in Australia. The areas that this covers are unbelievable.

PARA.TAB: The previous speaker, the member for Kennedy (Mr Katter), laboured long and hard on the impact of the fringe benefits tax on the living away from home allowance, particularly in remote areas of Australia. It is very important that we pay particular attention to that area of our economy and the remote areas of Australia in which people have to work. I noted in question time on Monday of this week that the Prime Minister crowed long and hard about an international study that indicated every Australian was a millionaire. The study found that we were all worth at least a million dollars because of the asset values of Australia, including the mineral wealth and the agricultural wealth of this country.

I put it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and to the government that we will never ever realise the enormous wealth and potential of the vast and diverse land of ours whilst we continue to put imposts instead of incentives in the way of the people that are trying to develop the regional and remote parts of Australia and the mineral wealth that we have in Australia. They are not recognising by way of incentives how important it is to encourage people to go and work in these parts of Australia, to encourage our Australian companies to develop these parts of Australia. They are not providing incentives under any circumstances, whether it be taxation or otherwise, yet they are providing imposts and impediments by way of taxation measures similar to that of the fringe benefits tax to companies and people that are prepared to invest in remote parts of Australia.

They do not need incentives that are lip-service. They need fair dinkum incentives to get people to live and work in remote areas. It is very important that we recognise that the living away from home allowance that is attracting fringe benefits is a very integral part of the future development of Australia. If we are not prepared to provide these sorts of concessions and if we are not prepared to provide community service obligations through different government instrumentalities—such as Australia Post, Telecom and air services access for regional airlines into major capital cities in the FAC-run airports—we will not have anybody living or working in regional and remote Australia. They will all be living up and down the eastern seaboard.

If they cannot find employment along the eastern seaboard, what will happen? The rest of the community, because of the safety net that we have in place and because of the egalitarian society that we have become, will have to keep those people. The point is that the government can do something about the situation. It is anathema to the Labor government of today to provide those sorts of incentives and concessions which assist and encourage the development of this great nation.
