The current position with the living away from home benefit is that it arises when an employee is paid an allowance in the nature of compensation for additional expenses incurred and other disadvantages suffered because the employee is required to live away from home to perform employment duties. It is all part of his job description, his employment package and his duties. The additional expenses include food and accommodation expenses but do not include expenses which the employee could claim as a tax deduction.

The taxable value of the living away from home allowance fringe benefit is reduced by the exempt accommodation component and the exempt food component. The current definitions of those terms are complex and uncertain. Where an employee does not receive the living away from home allowance benefit, it will usually be assessed in the hands of the employee. This bill provides that a living away from home allowance fringe benefit will be granted only where the total period for which the employee has lived or is required to live away from his or her home is less than four years for a foreigner or 12 months for an Australian resident. This period begins when the employee begins to live away from home and ends when he or she is no longer required.

It has been argued that the 12-month period for Australian residents posted elsewhere within Australia is too short and the period should be extended to two years. In addition, the distinction between foreign postings and domestic postings raises policy issues as to whether there should be a differential. The CTA has argued that there is no justification for differing treatments of employees required to move within Australia and those who move overseas. One adverse effect is that employers who elect to transfer foreign residents rather than Australian residents will be penalised. The treatment of expatriates visiting Australia is flawed since not all have temporary working visas. The bill also treats benefits paid to employees in remote areas differently from those fly in, fly out arrangements.

There are a number of changes being made in this piece of legislation. I highlight again for the people of Australia and the parliament that the amount of revenue that the Commonwealth is collecting is not being reduced. I will put it on the record again: it has increased from what was collected in 1986-87, $535 million, to the proposed level in 1995-96 of $2,804 million. On the government's figures, the compliance cost as a percentage of what is collected—in this bill today we are supposed to be addressing the compliance cost—runs at 10.6 per cent. So on those figures—and that is a government statistic—in 1986-87 the compliance cost for all those people who fell then within the FBT net was $56.7 million. In 1995-96, based on the fact that the government will collect $2,804 million, the compliance cost will be $301 million. That is $301 million worth of impost on business in Australia.

The Labor Party has been in power in Australia since 1983 and it still has not come to the realisation that it is the private sector that will ultimately provide the employment that is needed to significantly reduce the critical unemployment problem we have in Australia, not massive government spending on different programs. Some of the labour market programs that we are seeing today are an improvement on the labour market programs of 10 years ago, but that does still not recognise the fact that it is the private sector that will provide the fair dinkum and full-time jobs for the unemployed in Australia, not the public sector. Imposing these sorts of taxes will not help this situation. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me start with the last point first. The member for Lyne (Mr Vaile), who preceded me, talked about employment and the generation of employment. I will just take him back to the last federal election. This government said then that it would create 500,000 new jobs in this period of government. We still have six months to go and we have created over 670,000. That is not a bad effort I think—all with this tax in place; and it has been in place for a long time.

PARA.TAB: Let us have a look at the tax itself. The member mentioned that in the first year of its operation we collected $535 million. I am told that our estimate at that time was $350 million. You have to remember that when we introduced the fringe benefits tax, we did not know how much income was being delivered in this way. We knew it was being delivered, but we did not know how much. So it is $535 million as against our estimate of $350 million. It just shows that we underestimated the provision of fringe benefits to people in the work force.

People talk about the fact that this tax now is raising $2.7 billion. You have to remember, once again, that this—in most cases—is an optional tax. Nobody forces somebody to salary package in terms of taking a car. In many cases they can choose to do that or choose to take the money. This is an optional tax. The fact that we are raising $2.7 billion this year means that these benefits are being given and they are being given freely. They are being given instead of a cash payment. That is why the tax is there, of course.

Before we introduced a fringe benefits tax, people on substantial incomes paid tax on only a fraction of their income. For example, back in 1985 when we first talked about this tax, workers on about $25,000 or less total cash a year—as most workers were on about then—paid tax on all of their income. Yet at the same time somebody with a salary package of $100,000, taking only $30,000 in cash and $70,000 in other forms of income like cars, holidays, low interest loans, school fees, health insurance and all of the other elements that went into a salary package paid tax on only the $30,000.

That was not fair and that is why this government brought in a fringe benefits tax. We have to remind ourselves, and the House needs reminding too—some members, a couple of them at least, might not have been here at the time—of who opposed it. The Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia opposed this tax coming in—a tax seen as fair in the community. We had to fight them all the way to get this tax in so that people who were salary packaging were having tax paid on 100 per cent of that package rather than just on the cash component. In that way we made the tax system just that much fairer.

So with that basis today, I should congratulate the opposition on admitting, after all of this time, that they got it wrong when they opposed the government's fringe benefits tax legislation all those years ago. Now they are saying, `Yes, we'll accept that this tax should be in place and we will not remove it.' Thank goodness for that. It has taken them a long time to come around to that point of view. They opposed it at the start.

They always talk about how they are going to make taxation easier for business or ease the compliance costs, which is what this bill is all about. I will get on to their amendments in a few minutes. One would have thought that, if they had any ideas about how they were going to make this tax simpler and fairer, here was the forum. We opened this up to debate by introducing this bill. In effect, we said to the opposition, `If you've got some great ideas, here's your chance to put them. If you believe that our amendments don't go far enough, that our amendments won't simplify the law to the exacting standards that you are talking about outside, then you can move amendments.'

The amendments moved do nothing of the sort. In actual fact, the opposition has pulled up short on this one. They are out in the community promising everybody that they are going to ease the compliance costs on the fringe benefits tax and they are talking about watering it down. As the Treasurer (Mr Willis) pointed out in question time yesterday, a National Party resolution talked about abolishing it.

Imagine going back to those bad old days when we taxed only part of a person's income? If the Treasurer's observation was right and the National Party are going to move that the fringe benefits tax be abolished, then that is what we are going to do. We will take a trip back down the time tunnel to where some people paid tax on all of their income and one section of the community, usually the most privileged, paid no tax on a substantial part of their income. It is a nonsense to even think about those things, to even think about going backwards. There are still sections in the coalition who want to go back down that time tunnel to the bad old days, and they are still moving motions in their forums talking about doing it.

Before we introduced this bill—and members will remember this—in the budget before last, the Treasurer announced a review of the compliance costs for fringe benefits tax because we were getting complaints that the compliance costs were too high. Therefore, we set up a process whereby we could investigate these compliance costs. I was given the job, along with two people from the Australian Taxation Office, of going around and talking to a selected number of companies about how we could reduce compliance costs for the fringe benefits tax.

This occurred after receiving a significant number of written submissions. We picked out of those written submissions a number of representative firms in Sydney and Melbourne and we went to speak with them directly. The sorts of things they brought up are addressed in the bill. In fact, at the time, car parking topped the list. They wanted that streamlined. They came up with a number of proposals on ways in which we should go about that. We have picked up those suggestions, put up by private firms themselves, and incorporated them in this bill.

Another thing that business has told us is that the record keeping involved for the value of a large number of small fringe benefits was way out of whack. This included benefits like laptops, portable phones and airport lounge membership, et cetera. It really was not worth the compliance costs involved in keeping track of all those things. The government agreed with that. You will notice in the bill before the House today that they have been taken out.

Another area they pointed to was record keeping on meals. We agreed with them on that. There should be simpler ways of recording what FBT should be paid on meals when those meals are given to employees. You will notice in the bill that there are a number of options. The fifty-fifty split was put to us by small business. I still remember one small business person who spoke to us saying that that would be the most equitable way for small business because that is the way that small business operates. It usually operates on a one-to-one basis, and a 50 per cent split was exactly what they were looking for. In the bill today, the 50 per cent split is one option, among others.

I notice that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Costello), in his contribution, complained that the new fifty-fifty rule for entertainment will cost employers more. But, as I said before, that is one of a number of options. He was not on the tour I was on where I spoke to businesses about the ways in which they wanted compliance lowered on the FBT. If he had been, he would know that that is what small business asked for.

I come to the amendments that the opposition have moved. I am told that, considering the way that it is drafted, the first one will not work. The words `whichever is the greater' have been left out. Therefore, it is technically deficient. The government will not be agreeing with the others.

I make the point again: for all the huffing and puffing and all the posturing around the community about ways in which they will lower compliance costs, this is all the opposition could come up with. They are technically deficient amendments that basically do nothing. There is nothing in here from the opposition that should lead anyone to think that they would significantly improve the government's bill. The amendments just are not there to prove it. When you were given the chance, you pulled up short.

I noticed that the last speaker, the honourable member for Lyne, and a couple of other speakers have talked about the fact that this is a revenue neutral package. That is right. There was a very generous concession on cars. The way that the government has clawed back the concessions given through the package is to increase the amount paid on cars given to employees. An article in Business Review Weekly last year showed that this concession was so concessional that in many cases firms were giving two cars to employees—one for the employee and one for his wife. It was in the article. This is how concessional it was. We make no apologies for lifting that rate.

Because of the budgetary situation, a revenue neutral outcome is what the government desired. We have done it in a way which eases compliance costs and protects revenue, particularly in a year in which we are trying to maintain a surplus because of other considerations in the economy. It is all very important that this happen.

The opposition should always be reminded that, had they won the last election, the consumption tax they were going to impose on Australia would have been on top of the fringe benefits tax. It would add layers of complexity to the tax law to have a consumption tax sitting on top of a fringe benefits tax. You can imagine the sigh of relief that went around the business community in terms of compliance costs on fringe benefits when that one hit the fence.

I will just wind up my contribution by answering some questions raised by other opposition speakers. A number of them have said that the living away from home allowance changes will increase compliance costs instead of reducing them. In fact, the changes will do what people have actually asked us to do during the FBT review—we received many submissions on this—and that is to clarify when an allowance qualifies as a living away from home allowance. Another member said that there is no taxation impact statement with the bill and he asked: where is it? There is a compliance cost impact statement for every measure proposed by the bill. It is in the explanatory memorandum.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Clauses to 1 to 3—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move government amendments Nos (1) and (2):

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Schedule 1, page 7, item 2, omit proposed paragraphs (c) and (d) of the definition of business premises, substitute the following paragraphs:

PARA.TAB: "(c)boats or planes used primarily for the purpose of providing entertainment unless the boat or plane is used in the person's business of providing entertainment; or
(d)other premises used primarily for the purpose of providing entertainment unless the premises are used in the person's business of providing entertainment.".

SPEECH.PARA: (2)Schedule 1, page 9, item 6, proposed subsection 51AEB(2), omit "log book", substitute "register".

I table an explanatory memorandum to the amendments. Food and drink provided to employees on an employer's business premises are not treated as fringe benefits. The bill amends the definition of `business premises' in section 136 of the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986 to clarify that corporate boxes and boats and planes and other premises used for entertainment purposes are not business premises. This will ensure that FBT is properly payable where food and drink are provided at these other premises.

PARA.TAB: Amendment No. (1) will change the definition of `business premises' set out in item 2 in schedule 1 so that both boats and planes and other premises which are used only incidentally for entertainment purposes, and premises used by employers who carry on the business of providing entertainment, will continue to be treated as business premises. Food and drink provided to employees on these premises will consequently continue to be exempt benefits.

Amendment No. (2) will correct a technical drafting error in item 6 in schedule 1. Amendments Nos 3 to 18 will correct technical drafting errors in a number of items in schedule 3. In relation to amendments Nos 19 to 24 to schedule 6, section 162G of the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act currently sets out the circumstances in which a log book needs to be kept. The new rule proposed by the bill is that, generally, an employer will need to keep a new log book only every five years. The detailed rules set out in existing paragraphs 162G(1)(d) and (e) and paragraph 162G(2)(c) concerning the keeping of log books will become superfluous under the new five-year rule and will be omitted by proposed amendments Nos (20) and (23). This will necessitate several consequential technical amendments which will be made by amendments Nos (19), (21), (22) and (24).
Amendments agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 3 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The member, if he wishes, will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

—My question is addressed to the Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations. Does the assistant minister stand by previous claims in the House that enforceable compulsory unionism does not exist in Australia? If the minister does stand by those claims, what action will he take to rectify the injustice done only last month at the TNT depot in my electorate to Mr Grant Parker, a self-employed truck driver? Is it illegal for a Transport Workers Union official to demand $180 in union fees from Mr Parker which he had to pay before his truck was unloaded? Can the minister say what protection is available to ordinary workers from such coercive practices?

—I have said before that there is no law in this country which says a person must be a member of a union. There are provisions within the commission and the act which say a person can not be a member of a union. In fact, we expressly passed a bill which says that we cannot discriminate on the basis of whether someone is or is not a member of a trade union.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member and I well know that the important element of industrial relations is that we have an equivalence of power so that people are well-organised when they approach the boss to make sure they get a reasonable deal. In the fullness of time, I prefer that the work force is organised by a trade union movement and has a good chance when it goes in to bargain for its rights. There are those individuals who can exclude and excuse themselves from being members of a trade union.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Employment, Education and Training seen a report indicating that university places in Victoria could be at risk? What is the government's response to that report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I might say at the outset that one of the government's great achievements has been what it has been able to get for the higher education sector. In case there is any doubt about it, I should quote what Professor Alan Gilbert, the vice-chancellor of the Tasmanian University and soon to become vice-chancellor of Melbourne University, had to say last Friday at a function attended by the member for Braddon:

ANSWER.PARA: I am sure that when the history is written accurately one of the main things said about the government that has been in power since 1983 is that it has done more for education and for higher education I think than any government in Australia's history.

Not only is that an accurate statement but also in the last budget we did even more for higher education. We increased the number of new places by 5,850 which, when you take the pipeline effect, means 11,000 new places over the course of the next 3 1/2 to four years. We also increased research funding in the order of $150 million over three years. It was a package that at the time was applauded by the vice-chancellors, the academics and the student bodies. But it is a package that is now under threat because of the continuing vandalism of the opposition in the Senate in relation to budget measures.

PARA.TAB: What the opposition came out with yesterday was a commitment to blocking two important measures in the government's higher education package. The first measure introduced intermediate thresholds for HECS students, with not even a $1 increase in any debt to HECS students—only thresholds by which the money can be recovered; so there was no increase to students—and our second measure required people who had not taken out citizenship after being in the country for three years to pay HECS up-front. I might say that this decision in terms of non-citizens versus Australian citizens is a direction that the US and UK governments are now pursuing. But not the opposition; they have to be the spoilers as always.

TALK.START.PARA: —They had started their courses. What is the equity of that?
—Order! The member for Ballarat!
—The effect of these two measures, which do not impact on any Australian student, is to cost the higher education package some $20 million per year.

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. In the interests of saving the time of the House, standing order 144, as it is listed, states that questions cannot refer to debates in the current session. I thought the minister just told us that this matter was under debate in the Senate. If so, I would say he is out of order.

—The minister is in order. He is directly responding to a question before the House. Might I just say, I appreciate the fact that the minister is being heard in relative silence so far. But members at the far end of the chamber who continue to interject and put across a point of view will be dealt with.

—The effect of these two measures being blocked by the opposition is to cost higher education $20 million per year. That is, 2,000 places in universities are now in jeopardy because of the inane position that has been adopted by the opposition and is being pursued in another place. It was a position arrived at through no consultation with the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, none with the academics and none with the students. It is policy developed and based on pure opportunism, but it is actually policy at its very worst.

PARA.TAB: Let me point out what the consequences of this are. The states that got the growth places were Queensland, which got the bulk of them, New South Wales, Western Australia and Tasmania. The concern of Victoria and South Australia is that they would lose places to give the increases in these other states. They did not, as a result of our package. I would like to know whether the member for La Trobe, for example, who has often expressed concern about places for Monash University, whether the member for Adelaide, who has also been concerned about the possibility of places being lost in Adelaide, and whether the member for Braddon, who got growth places the other day in terms of the northern part of Tasmania, were consulted that the implications of this policy position would cost those universities places.

The simple fact of the matter is, we cannot put the package together if the $20 million is denied us. Those members really have to search very long and hard about how they respond to the universities when the universities come to them and say, `How are we going to be able to secure or retain these places?' The simple fact of the matter is that your strategy is being run by dopes. Whether they consult you or not, I do not know. So far as the Western Australians are concerned, there is no-one on that side of the House to consult because they are all moving across to the cross benches.

It is a very perverse situation when the opposition says that it will support and protect non-citizens but do it at the expense of Australian students, particularly our young people. What about the people who were around on the youth bus last week? Did you tell them you were going to adopt a policy that meant you would look after people who had not taken out citizenship but it would cost them places in universities? I am sure they would be very interested to find out.

I hope the Leader of the Opposition takes a bit more notice as to what his shadow spokesman for education is doing in the other house, understands the implication of what they are blocking in that place and realises that it is costing students places in universities. They will come from Victoria and they will come from South Australia. It is members associated with those states who ought to get on board, understand the implications of Senator Robert Hill's stupidity and get him to change tack.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I remind the minister that in the last year there has been no decline whatever in the rate of teenage unemployment, which remains at 28 per cent—32.5 per cent in the Bendigo region—and that the rate of unemployment among teenage males has increased. Will the minister explain the complete failure of Working Nation to provide effective assistance to unemployed teenagers?

—I do accept the fact that there is still a major problem associated with youth unemployment. It is unacceptably high, and it is something that was particularly focused upon through the Working Nation strategies. For example, the youth training initiative that was introduced under Working Nation—it did not exist before Working Nation came into effect—ensures, through case management and commitment to the job compact, a job offer for anyone who has been out of work for 18 months or longer.

PARA.TAB: It is true that we also have a significant structural shift in teenage unemployment. When you and I were at school, our ability to get jobs was legion in the marketplace, essentially because many unskilled jobs were available. The fact is that those jobs do not exist today. They do not exist in the banks as they used to. Technology has seen to that. But the same principle still applies. We have to find the start for young people, and the start these days increasingly is not built around an unskilled job but one that involves a level of skills. That is why the emphasis on the part of this government has been to lift those skills.

The simple fact is that 84 per cent of people who go through a traineeship get a job, and they are still in the job 12 months after the traineeship has concluded. The other simple reality is that your chances of becoming unemployed are twice as high if you do not have a year 12 qualification. They are very stark statistics, and that is why the emphasis of this government has been on lifting schooling and lifting training in schooling that is relevant. It is a commitment for the whole nation to get to 95 per cent of school children completing year 12.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing is happening.

—It is happening. In fact, it is over 80 per cent now, and it has gone up from 36 per cent since 1983. If you say that an increase from 36 per cent to 80 per cent is nothing happening, you have got a very strange view of the facts. The commitment is to get to 95 per cent, an objective that all governments share.

PARA.TAB: From the point of view of the government, we do have to go further so far as the youth of this country are concerned. We have to make the pathways in school much more relevant. That is why we funded the Student Traineeship Foundation—because states were dragging their feet. We are directly funding a program that should be the province of the states.

I have gone further than that. In the last week I have also said that we will develop programs by which we link that training to a real job. We will offer people who have completed that training a guaranteed job for 12 months after they have completed it, and that is in train. The other thing that I believe we have to do is to recognise that the start we are giving people through the various labour market programs goes on and links to a traineeship and a job. That is also something that we will be developing.

My commitment is to develop those guarantees for young people. We have an obligation to ensure that the young people of this country get an opportunity to work, that we tap their talents and that we tap their creativity. But the structures as they existed before did not do it. Apprenticeships were effectively the only traineeship. We have now developed traineeships that cover a whole gamut of operations—in the environment, sport, arts and entertainment, telecommunications, information technology. None of these things existed before Working Nation.

Working Nation was not just a one-year commitment; it was a four-year commitment. It is a commitment that is funded. The message that we have been getting across in the last few months is that there is a new deal and a new opportunity for the young people in this country, but it will be secured only if that program is given the opportunity to run the full four years. Under us it will, but under you it would be decimated.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the minister aware of the European Parliament's debate, which I understood took place yesterday, concerning the French nuclear testing? Can he advise the House what the government is doing to reiterate its very strong opposition to that testing?

—Mr Speaker, I have seen those press reports; in fact, I was reading them not long ago. They relate to the protests in Strasbourg by members of the European Parliament against French nuclear testing. If I were as immodest as the member for Mayo, I might be tempted to claim some credit on behalf of the all-party delegation—including the member for Mayo, the right honourable member for New England, Senator Vicki Bourne and the member for Moreton—which was recently in Europe to protest to various countries in Europe and to raise the profile of Australia's objections to French nuclear testing in a number of European capitals. In the course of that we saw a number of ministers, we saw a great number of European members of parliament, and we gave plenty of interviews to the European media about Australia's stance. I welcome the stand which was taken overnight by members of the European Parliament. I am sure that all members in this place wish them well in their efforts.

PARA.TAB: For our part, the Australian government has been absolutely tireless in its opposition to nuclear testing and will continue to be active on a range of fronts to encourage a sustained international response to the French nuclear testing, as well as, of course, the nuclear testing being conducted by China.

Last week I accompanied the Prime Minister to Madang for the 26th meeting of the South Pacific Forum. Members will know that the forum itself has been a source, and a consistent opponent, of nuclear testing in the South Pacific. Indeed, one of the main reasons the forum was established in 1971 was to oppose French nuclear testing. At the Madang meeting, the forum leaders issued a declaration which expressed in very trenchant terms the region's opposition to nuclear testing. `Extreme outrage' were the words that they used to describe their view.

They also had the opportunity to convey directly their views to a French government minister during the post-forum dialogue meeting. At that meeting France for the first time was represented by a cabinet-level minister, Mr Jacques Godfrain, who is Minister for Cooperation in the French government. The dialogue session with the French lasted for over two hours. It was a frank, robust exchange which included ministers from PNG, the Marshall Islands—which, of course, has itself been a victim of nuclear testing in the past—the Solomon Islands and Western Samoa, as well as Australia. The French side explained at length why they were going through with the testing program. They offered to open the testing site to the region following the conclusion of the tests as a scientific research facility. From our side, we made the point fervently that what we wanted to do was stop the tests, not to talk about what might happen after them.

What effect, apart from the Strasbourg debate to which the honourable member refers, has all this been having? Some other dialogue partners told the forum that the actions of the South Pacific nations, small as those nations are, were having a real impact globally, including on the French government, and I think we are all familiar with public opinion in France now on this matter. So I believe that the actions of the government are having an effect on the global stage which is out of all proportion to our place in the South Pacific.

In the coming weeks the government will intensify its efforts, something which the delegation pursued in Europe, to obtain a United Nations resolution which calls for an end to all testing. As well as that, the President of the Senate will shortly lead a delegation to the European institutions which, among other things, will follow up the work of our delegation earlier this month, and seek to draw attention to the views held throughout Australia and the South Pacific, and more widely, about this issue.

I conclude by saying that I thank the members of the delegation to Europe. I believe that we worked together very well. I pay particular tribute to the member for Chifley, who asked this question, because he took over the leadership of that delegation after I was obliged to return home. I do not want to be partisan about this. I think all members of the delegation did an excellent job and I thank them for their efforts.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the honourable member for Bruce.

—And I will be after the next election, too. My question is directed to the Deputy Prime Minister. I draw the Deputy Prime Minister's attention to reports in today's newspapers that the Prime Minister has assured the Labor Party backbench that the government would have an election manifesto containing many policy initiatives. In view of your constant calls for policy exposure, why is the government holding back on these policy initiatives until the election campaign?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do find this passing strange, coming from the opposition on the day when 10 little dickybirds from the opposition appeared in front of the MTIA and said to the MTIA, `We actually endorse all government policy. We are not going to have change for change's sake.'
—Wrong!
—Is that right? Is that in fact a wrong assessment? The AAP report on this quotes John Howard as saying:

ANSWER.PARA: We are not in the business of turning the investment climate in Australia on its head just to play out some particular ideological game. The coalition was in the business of identifying areas of common ground between the government and the opposition to ensure there were no concerns about wholesale policy changes.
He rocked into the MTIA and said to the MTIA:
We agree with everything, but do not expect an answer on policy from us.

When the election comes around the 10 little dickybirds will come back and they will all be wearing their coats and when they are asked for a policy they will rip their coats open and they will all drop out. On the back of every little postcard there will be a policy. There will be no analysis of them—not a single piece of analysis capable of being put in place will be on them. You want to run through this as a no policy election campaign. You are not going to be permitted to do that.

PARA.TAB: As far as I am concerned, there is enough of your policy already out and running for us to be reasonably seriously alarmed with the consequences of it. A couple of areas of policy go straight to the heart of insecurity in the Australian community about critical areas of what your industrial policies are going to be. You stood up in this place and said that you would have as your model the Western Australian industrial relations legislation—that is, no meaningful safety nets.

TALK.START.PARA: —No. Forget about it.

—We are not going to forget that one, sport. We are going to rub your noses in it from here until election day. Those policies from Western Australia that you have put in place and endorse pose a substantial threat to the lives and livelihoods of virtually every member of the Australian community. They affect the capacity they have to earn a decent income, the capacity they have to have decent treatment before the IRC and the capacity they have to effectively bargain collectively and even individually with their government.

PARA.TAB: There is enough policy out on that for us to know exactly what you mean. We know your other policies, whatever you subsequently release in your dirty postcard display six weeks or whatever before the election, will be meaningless as to your true intentions. The only place where you seem to have any policy light at all is where you genuinely choose to agree with us.

Our policies for the next election are in place and they are public. What you have for the next election is an industrial accord which will build on the delivery of 670,000 jobs with another 600,000, an industrial accord which will offer the work force protection, an industrial accord which defends workers against unfair dismissal, an industrial accord which means that they will not have ripped out from underneath them sick leave and all the other things that are associated with the benefits in their employment that make life livable for them. Those things are in place as far as this government is concerned.

On top of that you have a total savings package associated with the superannuation guarantee levy and what was built on that with the budget. That is a fundamental addressing of the nation's savings requirement—in the end the only sensible answer that you can put in place for problems that we confront from time to time with the current account deficit. That is out there. That is the policy of savings for our election. You have opposed it. Your position is you will accept it to this point, and this point does not deliver the outcome that the Australian community needs either in terms of savings for the nation as a whole or for their retirement. That is our policy. It is out there. It is available for debate in the community. You have joined that debate to oppose it.

You have joined the debate on the industrial accord to oppose it. You have joined the debate on Working Nation. I heard you get up and ask a question a moment ago on the position of teenagers and employment. Let me tell you the difference between now and when we came to office. The number of young people seeking full-time work, unemployed now, is a tragic 90,000. When we came to office, the number of teenagers seeking full-time work was a tragic 150,000. If we had had the sorts of participation rates that you dealt with when you were in office flowing through the period of time we were in office, unemployment would have risen to 20 per cent. That is the position you would have put in place.

We have an employment policy with the Working Nation paper which is working, which is getting long-term unemployed people back to work. Our savings policy is critical to put in place the answers to the current account deficit. That is in place and working as far as this government is concerned. With industrial policy what we have put in place is defending the conditions of the ordinary Australian. Today you launched your policy on the issues of foreign debt. You had your fully imported, all clockwork, plastic wind-up—
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the member for Mayo and the member for Flinders!

—Mr Speaker, they can't help it. You have a fully imported lorry of lies wandering about out there in which you say that every man, woman and child has to pay the interest on our foreign debt. This, I must admit, is a dramatic policy announcement by the Liberal Party subliminally. It is the socialisation of the debt of Australian companies. I suppose it is going to be accompanied subliminally by the socialisation of the assets of those companies to pay for it! That is the logical implication of the fully imported lorry of lies that is out there.

PARA.TAB: You had your position announced at the MTIA. At the same time as you were out there shuffling your way into the public to say you had some deep concern on foreign debt, what were you saying to the MTIA? You said this to the MTIA, and I conclude with it, because if you wanted a better endorsement of the policies of the opposition member who asked this question you could not get a better one than this from the Leader of the Opposition. It was on foreign investment, and it was not discouraging it, unlike the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, who said last week that for the next 20 years he would rather invest in Singapore. The Leader of the Opposition said this:

ANSWER.PARA: Any potential overseas investor couldn't do other than look upon Australia as a place where continuing long-term foreign investment remains extremely attractive.

Thank you for that endorsement of our policies. Our policies, which are policies of very considerable substance, are there for the next election. You can see them, you can debate them—and we just love debating them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I ask: what is the government doing to improve social security services for busy families?

—I thank the honourable member for Fraser for his incisive and perceptive question. Honourable members would be well aware of the significant improvements that have been made over the last few years in assistance for families which now, in terms of direct assistance alone, amount to over $12 billion a year. Honourable members would also be aware of the enhancements that this government has provided: for example, the 100 per cent real increase in additional family payments directed to low income families with children up to the age of 13; the 150 per cent real increase during the term of this government for children aged 13 to 15 of low income families; the introduction of the parenting allowance which means an increase of up to $217 per fortnight for low income families with one partner who is actually in the work force; and the maternity allowance which is now $840 and which is to commence from February next year. These and other changes have been introduced to improve the flexibility, responsiveness and simplicity of the system.

PARA.TAB: Today I have pleasure in announcing that the government has determined the sites of the first 15 pilot family service centres. The concept of the family service centres is to provide an integrated centre, either in shopfronts or in Department of Social Security offices, where families will be able to get a comprehensive suite of advice and assistance on family payments and related matters. It will include payments made by the Department of Social Security. It will include child-care assistance and the provision of advice and services in a range of other areas. It will provide referral to services provided by agencies in other tiers of government. In other words, it will be a comprehensive integrated service for families.

This is a new delivery concept in the area of family assistance which all the evidence and all the work that we have done have shown is very much in demand by families. There is a concern about having to go to a range of different agencies and offices to get assistance sorted out. These 15 pilot centres are the first in the establishment of a comprehensive network of such centres. In a number of locations we will be trying out variants on the basic concept to try and identify the one that is most effective and useful. Once we have got through that process it is our intention to implement a network of such centres on a wide scale.

In many cases we will be building on the existing Department of Social Security network, but this is a very important and popular step. It was announced in the budget, but I have pleasure today in indicating that we have determined the locations of those centres. It is a very significant initiative on the part of the government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ronaldson Mr M.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. I refer the minister to the national curriculum which he described in the House on 19 September 1994 as one of his government's `impressive achievements'. The minister is aware of a review conducted into the New South Wales syllabus—the Eltis report—which focused on aspects of the syllabus which incorporated the national profiles. The minister is aware that the report concluded:

QUESTION.PARA: There are doubts about the quality, content, rigour, interpretation and validity of the national profiles, and to some extent the national statements.

Is the minister also aware that the report described the national curriculum as `vague, inconsistent and arbitrary, and orientated towards process rather than understanding'? In light of these damming findings, and given that the two most populous states in Australia have now totally rejected the national curriculum, does the minister still stand by his `impressive achievement' claim?

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I think we should be clear when discussing national curriculum statements and profiles about the terms and their history. The profiles describe the progression of learning during the compulsory years in eight key learning areas. They provide lists of outcome statements which a typical student would be expected to achieve at different levels. They do not, as many people continue to believe, prescribe curriculum content to achieve those outcomes. Under the national approach, curriculum remains—as it always has—in the hands of the states.

PARA.TAB: Let us also be clear about the history of the way in which the national curriculum statements and profiles were developed. They are primarily a states' agenda, arising out of the 1989 Hobart declaration on the common goals of schooling. This is not an exclusive Commonwealth agenda. They were developed as a result of the states' declaration in 1989 with Commonwealth assistance. They were not devised by Commonwealth bureaucrats. The work was done in their development by the curriculum and assessment committee of the then AEC, the Australian Education Council, under the chairmanship of Dr Ken Boston, who was then and is still the New South Wales Director-General.

It is clearly appropriate in the case of New South Wales for a new government to take stock of curriculum within that state. That is entirely consistent with the decision of all ministers at the ministerial council meeting in December 1993, and that was that states are entitled to proceed according to their own timetables and their own priorities. In the wake of the Eltis report in New South Wales, I have advice from the New South Wales minister's office that the decision of the Eltis committee, responded to by the New South Wales minister, is that they are able to proceed in that state within the framework of the national curriculum statements and profiles; that the supporting documents which the Eltis committee recommends to support curriculum in that state are entirely consistent with an outcomes approach. So the Commonwealth is quite satisfied with the approach that was taken in New South Wales. The dissatisfaction in that state was mainly concerned with a cumbersome English syllabus which was devised under the leadership of the previous government in that state.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs—
—Are you an Independent?
—Order! Those on my left!
—Can the minister inform me, as a member of the Parliamentary Labor Party, and the House of the outcome of the South Pacific Forum and the post-forum dialogue meetings?
—Mr Speaker, he is not just a member of the Parliamentary Labor Party; he is the very proud chairman of the caucus.
—Order! Now that we have established credentials, I call the minister.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. The South Pacific Forum, which took place in Madang from 13 to 15 September, was a very successful meeting from the point of view of both the forum countries themselves and Australia. I have talked already about the nuclear testing issue and how that was dealt with by the forum, but that was not the only issue that was covered by the forum. In fact, it was a very businesslike meeting.

PARA.TAB: It paid great attention, for example, to the continuing long-term development and economic concerns of the region. In that respect, it maintained the momentum of last year's Brisbane forum, which focused on the theme of management of the forum's resources. It carried that forward to the theme of securing development beyond 2000, a theme suggested by Papua New Guinea. In so doing, we focused on the three areas of trade, transport and tourism, all of which are of crucial importance to the longer term sustainable development of the region. In that regard, leaders adopted at Madang a plan of action to take those issues forward. We also reviewed progress on economic and development issues in the last year. In that respect there was some good progress—
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is amazing that people opposite are not interested in hearing this.
—Order! The minister will continue his answer.

—We made real progress on streamlining and making more efficient the regional airlines. We made genuine progress on an issue which I think will become increasingly crucial as this century and the next proceed; that was on the implementation of fisheries commitments, the management of fisheries resources in the region.

PARA.TAB: Leaders endorsed a draft code of conduct on logging. That is an issue that I know is very important to the member and his electorate. We committed ourselves to implementing the provisions of that draft code of conduct as part of our own national code. That is a major advance and a major commitment which affects one of the region's most important resources. It is now up to the forest countries to enforce the provisions of that code.

Australia, for its part, will continue to do everything possible to assist regional forest countries to manage their forest resources in a sustainable way and to avoid the rape of the forests which is happening in some countries of the region. We also look to those countries whose companies log in the region or which buy the timber which comes from there, to encourage more responsible logging practices in accordance with the code. I believe, on the whole, that it was a very important meeting of the forum. I believe that the region fights above its weight compared with the rest of the world, not least as a result of this very successful Madang meeting.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Finance. Is the minister aware that the Queensland Farmers Federation farm debt figures released this week indicate that last year's forecast of one in 10 farmers being non-viable has now been revised upward to two in 10? Is the minister aware that since his government took interest rates to over 18 per cent, the nation has lost over one-third of its sheep herd and nearly one-third of its cattle herd—a loss of export earnings of some $4.5 thousand million a year? Is the minister further aware that the much vaunted $150 million in farm aid was totally eroded by the subsequent interest rate increase of 2.75 per cent and the consequent increase in the value of the Australian dollar, which is now costing the farming sector $1.5 thousand million per year?

PARA.TAB: Finally, could the minister advise when Australian farmers are going to be given a level playing field with interest rates the same as our competitors and trading partners—six per cent in the USA and 3.75 per cent in Japan—a move that would pressure down the Australian dollar and increase the cost of imports into Australia; a concrete step in reversing the chronic current account deficit, which was $2,000 million when we were in government, and now is over $26,000 million?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure I got absolutely all of the detail from the honourable gentleman's question, which was very dense, shall we say. In so far as I can recollect all the things that he had to say, I would say these things to him: as I am sure he is well aware from the suffering of his constituents, the statistics he presented in regard to the size of the flock and the size of acreage under cultivation have something to do with the drought in the area in which he finds himself. That in all probability goes to explain a very substantial proportion of it.

PARA.TAB: You did mention interest rates. The interest rate regime which has persisted over the last four or five years under this government has been one of probably the best in a very long period of time experienced by farmers. If they find themselves in the situation of exceptional circumstances, under RAS they get, of course, a 100 per cent interest rate subsidy. No other business receives that type of assistance, and it is appropriate that they should.
Then you made reference to the adequacy or otherwise of our drought policies. All I can say is that when the Prime Minister, as he frequently has, has visited the drought areas—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order—
—This had better be genuine, Bob.
—The Leader of the House might resume his seat.
—Mr Speaker, I specifically never mentioned drought anywhere in that question. Drought has nothing to do with what we are talking about.

—There is no point of order. Resume your seat! The member for Kennedy, I think, asked a very serious question and I think he was expecting a serious answer. The Deputy Prime Minister is, in fact, going to the issues which you have raised. I would hope that he will be given the courtesy of being heard.
—I am a bit surprised that you don't think you are talking about the drought in the various statistics that you mentioned, because of course they are directly related to the drought.
—They predated the drought.
—The member for Kennedy is not to debate it.

—As far as the support that we have put in place, when the Prime Minister, as he frequently has, has had recourse to visit Queensland, he has received nothing but praise from the farmers in that area for the generosity of that policy, as you well know.

PARA.TAB: You go to the issue of the level of our foreign debt. I suppose that takes us back to that fully imported lorry that you have running around outside with the bunch of fabrications that you have turning over on that little wheel to have us believe that that represents your policy. The simple fact of the matter is that, insofar as the consequences of that foreign debt can be sensibly addressed, there is only one policy in play in the Australian electorate, in the Australian community, that deals with that and it deals with it thoroughly. That is the propositions that we have put forward to improve private saving in this country which will secure a level of performance that ought to, over time, put an end to the unacceptable level of dependency that we have on foreign investment in this country.

That is a policy that you oppose, I am afraid to say. Yet the implications of it for the farming community, the implications of it over the long term for interest rates, the implications of it for investment in industries related to the farming community in this country are very substantial. You could do no better service for your constituents and the ones that you have quite understandably referred to, than to start to change the policies of your party towards that. Give people a decent retirement, give people a decent opportunity to save associated with that and lower our level of dependence on foreign debt as a result.

But when it comes to servicing that foreign debt, over the last five years the ratio of our exports that has gone to servicing that has approximately halved, which is a very good outcome indeed because of, among other things, that interest rate regime that you referred to.

So I think that we are looking at as reasonable a performance as any government can put forward as far as the interests of your farmers are concerned. I have no better endorsement of that fact than the few words of the Leader of the Opposition that I manage to find agreement with, that is, his words to the MTIA that he did not actually think that anything in government policy needed any dramatic changes at all. And, as far as he was concerned, when he had a few things to say a bit earlier on to the show up in Nyngan, where again on rural policies, particularly drought policies, he said he did not think anything more than rather minor adjustments were required as far as government policy was concerned. So I will rest easy with that endorsement, and I suggest to you that you have an argument with him—you have had a few before.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. I ask the minister whether he has seen or is aware of recent comments that have been reported from the Premier of Victoria concerning Commonwealth-state relations, particularly as they relate to school education. Would the minister advise me, as a member of the federal Parliamentary Labor Party, what the government's response to those reports is?

—I thank the honourable member for Charlton, a former chairman of the Parliamentary Labor Party, for his question. I did hear what Mr Kennett had to say in his speech on 22 August about the quality of Commonwealth public servants. Mr Kennett, at that time, also said that he had had discussions that morning, and previously, with the Leader of the Opposition about a new direction for Victoria and for Australia. Mr Kennett at the time complained that the roles of the Commonwealth and the states had become too closely entwined in `areas which should be the domain of the states, especially in services like health, education, welfare and housing'.

PARA.TAB: What can parents, teachers and young people expect from the coalition's new direction for education? The answer lies in what the Kennett government has already done for schools in Victoria. It has closed nearly 300 schools and reduced the number of teachers by 8,000. In its most recent budget, Victoria has, once again, reduced its own contribution to school education. Spending on government schools in Victoria has been maintained thanks only to the Commonwealth's payments, which have grown in real terms. Victorian government spending on non-government schools has been cut by a massive 8.1 per cent, even though the number of students attending those schools has actually increased.

Of course the numbers would go up if nearly 300 government schools have been closed. But I would have thought that the savings from closing schools would at least provide some support for schools that have to pick up those students that have been displaced by closure. But apparently that is not the Liberal way.

The Liberal government of South Australia is also slashing education spending. It slashed $40 million from education in its most recent budget. In South Australia, state government support for non-governmental schools fell at the same time as those schools were getting increased enrolments. In South Australia, that support to the non-government sector fell by 16 per cent. Quite simply, without the Commonwealth's growing level of support, schools in Victoria and South Australia would be much worse off.

While those state Liberal governments are reducing their support for school education, Commonwealth expenditure on schools has increased since 1982 by 55 per cent in real terms. The Kennett-Howard proposition, which would hand to the state governments the control of school funding, would be an error of tragic proportions. It would expose Australian children to the Kennett style policies of selling off school sites for short-term gain while impairing the education opportunities of three million Australian students. The effects of that would be felt right throughout the community and the work force long after the cheques from those sales had been spent. Nobody in the Liberal Party, from the Leader of the Opposition down, it seems, is capable of understanding the importance of school education and the utter foolishness of selling off our young people's futures.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. With youth unemployment running as high as 42 per cent in electorates such as mine and with youth homelessness on the increase, can you explain why the highly successful JPET program, the program for the young homeless unemployed, has been closed down? Why have these young battlers, suffering the twin deprivations of homelessness and unemployment, been so wilfully abandoned by your government?

—The JPET program has not been closed down. The JPET program was a pilot program run through the Minister for Housing and Regional Development and it was due to come to conclusion this year. But it is a program that has been continued under Working Nation in an expanded form.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true; it is exactly true.
—Order! Those on my left will not interject and not debate the issue with the minister as he is responding to a question.

—As an indication of that, I attended a function in my electorate a few weeks ago with Bishop Hollingworth which was to recognise the successful completion of the JPET program within the Oakleigh area.
—A bit like the J-curve.
—I warn the member for Parkes.

—At that meeting I indicated that we would work with them to continue the program, and that is currently in train. As for the member for Hinkler's own position, I was in his electorate a little over a week ago and the same issue was raised by people with me there. I pledged my total commitment to the continuation of the JPET program or its equivalent using the working—
—`Or its equivalent'.
—Order! The member for Goldstein.

—Or its equivalent. Is there some problem with that, Mr Speaker? Just because the names and the portfolios are changed, is that tantamount to the program concluding? That is the inanity of this mob. Understand this: the whole purpose of the JPET program is to get young unemployed who are out of work into work. It recognises the fact that they have got additional problems to people who are not homeless and that extra assistance is needed.
—You were embarrassed when you found out it was being wound up.
—Order! I warn the member for Berowra.

—But the fundamental thrust of the initiative is to get them into employment. Is it odd that that happens to come now under the employment portfolio? I think this is another one of the initiatives that the shadow minister over there would say to the Salvation Army and to the Brotherhood of St Laurence, `You look after it. We are going to wash our hands of it.' I tell you this: we are not washing our hands of it.

PARA.TAB: We do recognise that there is a problem not only associated with youth unemployment—which was the point that I responded to earlier—but also associated with homelessness. That is why the special intervention program, which is worth millions of dollars more than was ever available in the JPET program, is available for that very purpose. Through case management and the special intervention program, there is the ability not only to manage people while we have got them in the compact group but also to develop post-program mentoring, follow-up and support for them. That does not exist for other people who are unemployed.

I simply say to the member for Hinkler: understand the potential and opportunity in Working Nation and, at the same time as you start to understand it, put a program together in your own electorate, because I will back it. These are the initiatives that do have to be developed. I think you have missed the boat, because we are already doing it up in your electorate based on the discussions I had with groups up there recently. I would suggest that, rather than knocking that proposal, you actually get behind it and support it.

So far as this government is concerned, we have a commitment to ensuring that young unemployed people—whatever their circumstances are—get the job opportunities and that they get adequate backup to address those extra needs associated in this case with homelessness. Do not run the lie that JPET has been abandoned; it has not. We have got a much more extensive program to deal with the problems of unemployed homeless youth and we will keep that commitment.

The only people who are putting those programs in jeopardy are on your side of politics, because you want the luxury of going around your own electorates saying, as the Deputy Prime Minister has indicated, `Don't worry about it. Whoever gets in, these policies will be the same.' People on your side have been in this same position.

The other day when we addressed the group employment scheme you said that we all support these initiatives, that we support new work opportunities and that we support group employment. There you were welcoming me to your own electorate, saying that you support them. But that is not what the deputy leader of your own party has said. When asked to specify where you in government would find the cuts, the only program that he has mentioned has been Working Nation. That is what you would slash, but Working Nation is the only mechanism by which these sorts of special initiatives can be funded.

We have a commitment as a government to these people. That commitment is not just for the term that we are in office. It is a commitment for the next three years. We have funded that commitment. These programs can be addressed. I simply repeat the point: you would be far better off as members of parliament getting behind the initiatives and supporting the real issues in your electorate rather than coming in here asking questions that are absolute distortions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations advise the House of the significance of the work being carried out by the awards management function within the Department of Industrial Relations?

—Yes, I can inform the House of the work carried out by the awards management branch. I recently received some figures on its work. In 1994-95, awards officers received some 4,000 complaints and completed 3,890 inspections covering over 77,000 employees. They detected over 2,100 employers who breached awards. They covered such matters as underpayment of wages, incorrect payment of overtime or penalty rates and breaches of conditions or classification arrangements. As a result of their good work, employers paid over $3 1/2 million to employees to rectify those award breaches. During the same period, awards officers received over 300,000 inquiries about awards matters. In addition to that, people should understand that the work of the awards management branch is aided and assisted by those other players in the game, namely, employer representatives, who make employers aware of awards, and union representatives, who also help employees and employers become aware of their obligations under the award system.

PARA.TAB: What troubles us greatly is that there is a coalition government in Western Australia which seems to have the support of the coalition federally to wipe out the ability of trade unions, amongst others, to police awards. So much so that, for instance, Mr Keirath, the industrial relations minister in Western Australia, sought to bring before that parliament the following sorts of penalties: they wanted to penalise unions which attempted to switch to the federal system to escape a bastardised program that they want to establish in Western Australia. They also wanted to suspend the pay of union officials when union members went on strike. So much for the notion of freedom of association which the member for Adelaide asked me about earlier. Still on the table are significant concerns that we have and that the coalition ought to have about the treatment of those people who make the system honest, who make the system run.

The following matters are still on the table in Western Australia: postal strike ballots becoming a legal requirement even in the case of a refusal to work for health and safety reasons. So if you are in a dangerous workplace you cannot stop work; you have to have a secret ballot before you can agree to get out of what may be a dangerous workplace. There are restrictions on the union's right of entry to an employer's premises, inhibiting award enforcement and the possibility of recruitment. Fundamental here is the question of the freedom of association—the right of a union to support its membership when it is getting dudded by employers. I hope that the coalition will own up to these views about anti-freedom of association that they seem to carry and the fundamental role of having a number of people policing awards, policing the system, to ensure there is fair payment and treatment of workers under the industrial relations system.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance. In 1983, our foreign debt stood at $23 billion. Today it stands at a whopping $180 billion, after an eight-fold increase under your government. Your own savings adviser, Vincent FitzGerald, has stated that the increase in your own debt—that is, the government debt—is the prime cause of the recent increase in foreign debt. Last year the interest on government debt was close to $10 billion. How can you continue to dishonestly claim that the level of foreign debt is irrelevant when high foreign debt puts more pressure on interest rates, which are paid for by all Australians now and in the future?
—As I recollect, the Commonwealth's share of that debt of $180 billion is about $7 billion.
—Four per cent.

—That is right, four per cent is the Commonwealth government's share. Over 60 per cent of it is owed by our private community. I do not quite know what point you are trying to make. You have this fully imported lorry wandering around the place saying that as the interest bill ticks over you cannot have any more schools, you are going to have to get rid of policemen, you are going to have to do a whole lot of things on the public side, in order to pay off that debt. What a load of absolute nonsense.

PARA.TAB: The basis of your question is fundamentally unsound, but your policy prescription is even worse. As far as accumulating that debt is concerned—that is, by additional international investment in this economy—you have the Leader of the Opposition wandering around today launching the old lorry of lies, the fully imported lorry of lies, and at the same time saying, `This is a terrific place for foreign investment. We want more of it and you ought to be getting solidly stuck into it.'

He is effectively endorsing government policy. But there is one thing he has not endorsed, and one thing you have not endorsed: we have made it absolutely plain that there is a requirement in this country to improve private saving. There is a requirement in this country to lower our dependency on foreign capital. There is only one solution in the marketplace for that, and it is a massive solution. It not only resolves the problem of private saving in this country but also deals with a decent retirement. It produces a set of circumstances in which the foreign debt we must incur is sustainable through all the various cycles that we experience in relation to our current account deficit.

We support that. You do not. You would leave it where it is now. You would not support an addition to it. As far as the employer's contribution is concerned, you do not support the matching position that we have put in place via the last budget process. You have opposed that. Therefore, it ill-becomes you to stand up in this place and ask questions about what the government is intending to do about it when you know you have no solutions, when you know that you basically support the orientation of the government on foreign investment anyway and when you know full well that the government has in place a truly massive program to lift our private saving performance over time.
Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, my question to you relates to matters I raised yesterday after question time. To preface the question, I must say I have been a bit disturbed to receive a copy of a letter today dated 4 April 1995 which was written and signed by Harry Jenkins, Acting Speaker. I refer it to you as a preface to the question because it is directly on the point. I think the House should know that this letter from the Acting Speaker refers to a photograph taken over the shoulder of the Prime Minister with a view to focusing on the reaction of the other side.

—I preface my question by pointing—

—I want the question.

—No, I want the question from the member for Flinders.

—I will ask my question—in fact, there are a couple of questions. Presumably that is not too difficult for you.

—Order! Yesterday I remarked in this House about reflections on the chair. I have asked you, and I have gained the silence of the House to enable you, to ask me a question. I have said to you I want the question. Please ask it now so that I can then respond.

—Given the fact that there was a letter from the Acting Speaker which has endorsed a previous photograph—which has now been used as a basis for a change in the regulations—how is it that the decision was made, given that a previous undertaking obviously has now been broken? Is it your intention for there to be proper consultations? How are we to interpret the actions taken by the Speaker yesterday, given that those actions are a breach of a previous undertaking? Will you now, to bring this matter back into some sort of reasonable handling, give the House an undertaking, or make a statement to the House, that the previous letter, yesterday's letter of 19 September, is now null and void until the matter is properly reviewed and that people can be given a proper opportunity to consult, which was the original undertaking given?

—In respect of the issue which the honourable member has raised and gave me some warning of, I can say to him that the letter to which he referred was a letter from Acting Speaker Jenkins to the parliamentary Press Gallery Committee suggesting that there is a need to discuss the guidelines that have been in place for some time in respect of still photography. There have been some attempts to arrange a mutually convenient time for the Press Gallery Committee, the President and me to discuss that and a number of other issues of concern, issues which have been raised by members from both sides of this place in respect of a number of matters. Regrettably, to date that has not been possible.

PARA.TAB: As a result of further correspondence received today, which I think the honourable member for Flinders has some knowledge of, the opportunity is again being sought now for a meeting between representatives of that committee and me. In a brief consultation with you earlier today, I indicated that it probably would suit the convenience of this place if the Leader of the House or his representative and you, as Manager of Opposition Business, might not participate in those discussions, given that I think the original intention of having guidelines in place for still photographers, as there are for camera operators for television, ensures that this place is covered in the most appropriate way.

The undertaking that I can give you, and will give you now, is that consultation will take place. As I said, there will be an invitation extended to you or your representative to participate in that. With respect to the letter yesterday, it was a clarification of the way in which I believed that particular clause of the guidelines was to be applied in this place. If, after those consultations, it is my view, through the process of consultation involving you and the Leader of the House, that it is considered not appropriate, then that matter will be reviewed. I think that is a fair and reasonable way in which to deal with this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, the reason that I wanted to go to the letter, Mr Speaker, and it is the reason I wanted to preface my question—and yes, it was a long preface but I did not think it was unreasonable—was because a certain undertaking had been given. I raised no question yesterday about your motives—
—I understand that.
—I took it on a perfectly straight-up-and-down basis.
—Sure; that is what I am saying, that I will give you the chance.

—And I was therefore surprised when I found that there was a letter which contradicted the understanding I believed there to be. Finally, I only put it to you, Mr Speaker, that yesterday should be a closed chapter and, when this group meets, they should do so on the basis of reviewing the matter ab initio, that we start again in terms of these things, so that we can come to a comprehensive and sensible agreement.
—I have already indicated to the honourable member that that consultation process hopefully will lead to a set of guidelines which members of this place will be comfortable with.

—My question is definitely a very much easier one than the last one. It relates to the health of members of parliament. Could you advise the House, Mr Speaker, on the status of negotiations between the Joint House Department and the nursing centre in respect of the services they provide to members?
—No photographs of him.

—Order! A question has been asked of me by the member for McPherson. The member for Mayo might not be here much longer. With respect to the question asked by the member for McPherson, I can tell him and other members that this particular matter is before the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, that there has been at least one day of hearing in respect of that dispute, that yesterday there was an inspection by the commissioner hearing that dispute and that this particular matter is listed for continuing discussion by 20 October.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented today by the Sydney Morning Herald.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my left! When members on your side of the House seek to make personal explanations they are required to be heard in silence. This will also apply to the Prime Minister.

—Mr Speaker, it is on the subject that you were asked a question about. There is an article headed, `PM's brush with a cover-up'. Mr Seccombe from the Herald is in the House, I see, at the moment. He writes:

SPEECH.PARA: The fix is in—
about photographers—
The edict came down yesterday from the Serjeant-at-Arms, who works for the Prime Minister—

—He goes on to say that I am sensitive about the way question time comes across, particularly for photographers. Mr Speaker, I did not speak to you about this matter at all—ever.
