—I have been misrepresented in that I have had no brush with this issue at all and I have fixed nothing.
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: the standing orders are quite clear on this. The Prime Minister is required under the standing orders to point out where he has been misrepresented.
—That is exactly what he is doing.
—Let me finish, Mr Speaker. All he has done so far is refer to a headline which he finds objectionable.
—Resume your seat. The Prime Minister is perfectly in order.

—I have not spoken to you, Mr Speaker, about this. My staff have not spoken to your staff about it. No MP has spoken on my behalf about it. Mr Seccombe was told this and still wilfully wrote the story. Mr Seccombe has no respect for accuracy or truth and nor has his editor, who encourages this sort of journalism.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—He is debating it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Prime Minister is showing where he has been personally misrepresented.

—As to the writing of it and the photographs which are of me and about me, though I have made no reference to this issue whatsoever, I just make the point that all, as I understand it, that was being required here was that the photographers obey the existing guidelines. That is all. The television stations cannot take other than approved guideline material, but apparently photographers believe they can.
—Order! I think the Prime Minister has made the point.
—Speaking as a member with hair—
—No.
—He has talked about my hair for two years.

—Mr Speaker, he is debating the issue. He is not explaining where he has been misrepresented.

—I have also been misrepresented by Alan Ramsey, who made a similar reference. In the same newspaper, Alan Ramsey wrote about this issue as though it were a fact that I had spoken to you, Mr Speaker, about it and I was the cause of this change, which, of course, I had not. Mr Ramsey knows about the theatre of the House, having interjected from the press gallery that Prime Minister John Gorton was a liar. He knows what the proprieties of the House are and he knows therefore that he needs to check these stories. He did not.

—Order! The Prime Minister might resume his seat. I think the Prime Minister has concluded showing where he has been misrepresented twice.

—I have a question to you, Mr Speaker. Are you going to allow members of this House to use personal explanations to slander people as the Prime Minister just did? Mr SPEAKER—Order! Resume your seat. There is no point of order.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received letters from the honourable member for Perth (Mr Smith) and the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent) proposing definite matters of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion today. As required by standing order 107, I have selected the matter which, in my opinion, is the most urgent and important—that proposed by the honourable member for Perth, namely:

PARA.TAB: The need to ensure that Commonwealth funds for local authorities are appropriately expended at the local level.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Glimmer!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I would have thought that those on my left would know the standing orders. They continue to ask me to impose penalties on those who disregard them. Might I just say that we will start doing that now.

—The matter of public importance today is the need to ensure that Commonwealth funds for local authorities are appropriately expended at the local level. This is a matter of great importance to the Commonwealth revenue. If one has a look at the financial assistance grants that have been made to local authorities over the last 10 or so years, one finds that in 1983-84, for example, over $460 million was allocated by way of financial assistance grants to local authorities. In the course of the five- and 10-yearly periods since then in the financial year 1988-89 that amount rose to $652 million, in 1993-94 to $1.05 billion, and in the current financial year to $1.15 billion.

PARA.TAB: If one looks at the allocations by way of financial assistance grants in my own state following those same financial year periods, in 1983-84 it was over $43 million, in 1988-89 over $59 million, in 1993-94 over $120 million, and in the current financial year $131 million. This does not include any special allocations of Commonwealth revenue to local authorities to be made under special programs—for example, the local government development program. If we look at the same period, from 1983-84 through to 1994-95, we find allocations anywhere from $2 million to $5 million variously to local authorities.

It is important that these funds are disbursed and appropriated well at the local level. Let us look at some of the funds that have been allocated to particular local authorities in Western Australia. At random I pick a particular local authority in Western Australia. It is not a local authority which is even in my electorate. The city of Wanneroo in the financial year 1983-84 received by way of general purpose grants over $1.5 million from the Commonwealth in the financial year 1988-89, over $2.2 million by way of funds from the Commonwealth in the financial year 1993-94, over $2.26 million by way of general purpose grants, and over $119 million by way of road funding. In the current financial year it received over $2.6 million by way of general purpose grants and $1.5 million by way of road funding. So the city of Wanneroo in the current financial year by way of general purpose and road funding receives over $4 million.

It is very important to make sure that these funds are appropriately allocated. I was particularly concerned at a matter raised yesterday in the House by the Independent member for Moore (Mr Filing)—one of the Liberal members from Western Australia who has been unfairly dismissed by the Liberal Party, and who has not been protected by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) from elements of the Liberal Party in Western Australia. Mr Filing yesterday asked the Minister for Finance and Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Beazley) about remarks that the Deputy Prime Minister had made. Mr Filing referred to so-called federal interests in the matter surrounding corrupt behaviour by gaoled former Wanneroo mayor Dr Wayne Bradshaw and others. My constituents who live in the city of Wanneroo want to know what are these so-called federal interests. The Minister for Finance and Deputy Prime Minister responded by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Actually, Paul, I was after your antagonists.

It is well known that elements of the city of Wanneroo are involved and were involved and instrumental in ensuring that the member for Moore, Mr Filing, lost his pre-selection. In the course of his answer, the Deputy Prime Minister made it clear that the federal interest in this matter is that up to 50 per cent of local authority funds are provided by the Commonwealth. The minister also made the point:

Last time I looked, too, as far as the taxation act was concerned, proceeds from bribery were still subject to taxation. That would also be a matter of some interest so far as the federal government is concerned.

The Minister for Finance went on to make the point that the city of Wanneroo is notorious for corrupt activity and that it is incumbent upon the state government, upon Premier Court, to ensure that a proper inquiry is constituted into the conduct of the city of Wanneroo and into the conduct of people who have been found either in the Kyle report or by the courts as being engaged in corrupt and improper activity.

PARA.TAB: This parliament needs to be confident that funds at the local level which are allocated by Commonwealth to local authorities are properly expended. I have gone through the vast array of funds which are applied and the over $4 million which the city of Wanneroo has received in this financial year. There has been longstanding concern about the city of Wanneroo. In 1992 the then Premier of Western Australia, Dr Carmen Lawrence, established an inquiry known as the Kyle inquiry to look at corruption in the city of Wanneroo.

I will not go through the report at length. It is a weighty tome which exposes corruption in the city of Wanneroo and exposes the links that the Liberal Party has with that corruption in Western Australia. The report contains some very interesting findings by Mr Kyle. Some of the basic issues which are established in the Kyle report include evidence of official corruption in the Wanneroo City Council. Mr Kyle made three specific findings of official corruption involving Dr Wayne Bradshaw. Some of these findings have been confirmed by the outcome of criminal proceedings against a councillor of the city of Wanneroo, Councillor David King. Dr Wayne Bradshaw was also recently convicted of a number of corrupt actions.

The Kyle report, on Mr Kyle's own admission, is inadequate because he was unable to interview or speak to Dr Wayne Bradshaw who had absconded overseas. What is also clear from Mr Kyle's report is that there are clear links between the Liberal Party in Western Australia and the city of Wanneroo. There are several threads in this report which implicate sitting Liberal members in the Western Australian parliament and the Liberal Party's general structure in the northern suburbs in cases of official corruption. Yesterday the Deputy Prime Minister made clear that Mr Kyle is a member of the Liberal Party and is held in some impartial and objective regard. In chapter 5 of his report Mr Kyle had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Between 1986 and 1990 there is little doubt that Bradshaw formed and led a faction that operated as such and whose attitudes were largely dictated by Bradshaw. Largely this group consisted of active Liberal Party people—members of the Moore division of the Liberal Party.

These are the same people who cut the throat of the member for Moore by withdrawing his endorsement, despite weak help from the Leader of the Opposition for the member for Moore to retain his Liberal Party preselection. Mr Kyle found:

Largely this group consisted of active Liberal Party people—members of the Moore division of the Liberal Party. . . the prominence of Liberal Party people on the Council, and Councillors within the Liberal Party organisation itself, and the high profile gained by those people, resulted in some of them being preselected as candidates for the Liberal Party.
That, of course, was a reference to the 1993 state election. In chapter 5 Mr Kyle goes on to say:

The present controlling faction is significantly motivated by party political considerations. Most of the faction are active Liberal Party members and three of them, Mayor Johnson and Councillors Smith and Carstairs, are candidates for the Liberal Party at the next State election.
Johnson and Smith were successful and are now members of the Western Australian parliament. Kyle goes on to say:

Their election expenses were often paid for by Bradshaw. Indeed it was hard to distinguish between the campaign helpers of some candidates for the Council and members of the local Liberal Party organisations.
There we see the web of deceit and corruption that surrounds the city of Wanneroo.

PARA.TAB: A range of people have called for a full and proper judicial inquiry. As I have indicated, Mr Kyle himself has pointed out the inadequacies of his own inquiry because of his inability to speak to Bradshaw. In the West Australian of Friday, 1 September 1995, under the heading `Doctor guilty, but the malady lingers' there is an article by Tony Barrass. Mr Barrass, described as a person `who has been following the Wanneroo Inc. saga for five years, reports that there are still many unanswered questions about the issue which demand an official investigation'. Mr Barrass talks about political commentators and he writes:

SPEECH.PARA: They argue that the position of attorney-general—the State's top law enforcement officer—has been compromised many times. . . by her past association with Bradshaw. They claim her position, more than any other apart from the Premier's, must be beyond reproach.

It is well known that the husband of the Attorney-General, Colin Edwardes, was a councillor of the city of Wanneroo at the appropriate time and is the subject of adverse findings by Kyle in his report. Indeed, Mr Barrass reports:

The Kyle inquiry into the business affairs of Wanneroo council, in the chapter headed Intimidation, said, `The inquiry concludes that Wayde Smith and Colin Edwardes made their allegations to the inquiry at least in part for party political reasons.

PARA.TAB: Wayde Smith was a candidate for the liberal seat of Wanneroo.

SPEECH.PARA: He goes on to say:
`The inquiry does not accept Edwardes' evidence. . . and concludes that Edwardes and Wayde Smith saw an opportunity to make allegations of a very serious nature involving. . . Mrs Watkins'.
Mrs Watkins was a Labor member of parliament. In the course of the article Barrass also says:
Mr Smith lied about his business dealings with Bradshaw not long after a listening device was found in his former house.
He concludes his article by saying:

There have been plenty of inquiries into Wanneroo Inc, but not one of them so far has got to the bottom of the many allegations. And many suspect that there's a handful of people in State Parliament who hope that's the way things will stay.
Where has the Premier of Western Australia been in all of this? The answer is that he has been nowhere.

PARA.TAB: The Premier of Western Australia came to office on promises of full accountability in government. Since that point in time we have seen his failure or refusal to implement the recommendations of the WA Inc. royal commission; his failure or refusal to take appropriate steps to enact legislation with respect to disclosure of donations; his failure or refusal to implement accountability measures particularly in respect of freedom of information; and his failure or refusal to make any commitment so far as the Commission on Government's report is concerned—which the Labor Party in Western Australia has committed itself to implementing.
On 10 August 1994 in the state parliament the Premier of Western Australia, Mr Court, said:

SPEECH.PARA: If there is any evidence of wrongdoing by any member of this side of the House I will be the first to take action. If there is wrongdoing I will be the first to act.
The Premier of Western Australia needs to act in this matter by immediately instituting a proper inquiry into these allegations.

PARA.TAB: These are views which are held by Mr Court's deputy. In an article in the Australian yesterday by Colleen Egan—a journalist who is well known to members of the Liberal Party in Western Australia—there is a reference to Mr Cowan, the leader of the National Party and Deputy Premier of Western Australia. Mr Cowan made the point that Premier Court, having instituted a royal commission into the Easton matter purely for political purposes and to damage the federal Minister for Health, now has in front of him convictions, Kyle's findings on corruption, links with the Liberal Party, and links with those matters going to the Attorney-General and members of the Western Australian parliament. When matters which might properly be the subject of judicial inquiry or royal commission fall into focus, Mr Court will not act. Why? Because he seeks to cover up any activity which might adversely reflect on the Liberal Party in Western Australia!

Let us see what some of those things are. We can take a cursory glance at editions of the West Australian newspaper in the last couple of years and we can see precisely why there has to be an independent, impartial, full and proper inquiry into these matters. The first headline reads, `Liberal MLA hit by police raids'. The article reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The States self-proclaimed crusader against organised crime, Wanneroo MLA Wayde Smith, had his home and electoral office raided by fraud squad detectives yesterday. . . They seized documents. . . it is believed police have been examining the Kyle report on the dealings of the Wanneroo council and are investigating Mr Smith's links with former Wanneroo mayor Wayne Bradshaw.
From another cursory glance at the newspapers we see the headline in the Sunday Times which reads `Lib MP's account probed'. The article reads:
Police are investigating the possibility that allegedly corrupt payments to former Wanneroo mayor Wayne Bradshaw were cashed through bank accounts controlled by Liberal MLA Wayde Smith.
In the Sunday Times again we have the headline `Edwardes, Bradshaw bugged'. The article reads:

Attorney-General Cheryl Edwardes was secretly taped by a police undercover team during confidential discussions with former Wanneroo mayor Dr Wayne Bradshaw. . . the conversation was recorded during a legally sanctioned bugging operation in 1990 as part of police investigations into alleged corruption at the Wanneroo City Council.

PARA.TAB: Former CIB detective and Wanneroo councillor Wayde Smith, now a Liberal backbencher, had his Ocean Reef home bugged in the same undercover operation.

SPEECH.PARA: Still the Premier of Western Australia refuses to act. Why? Because we know that the Attorney-General of Western Australia, Cheryl Edwardes, was instrumental in rounding up the numbers when Richard Court knocked over Barry McKinnon as leader of the Liberal Party in Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: There are a few more vignettes. In the West Australian of 7 June 1994 we have the headline `Edwardes "got donations"'. The article reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Wanted doctor Wayne Bradshaw claims Attorney-General Cheryl Edwardes got $30,000 in political donations, some of which was condemned in a government inquiry on corruption.

The government inquiry, of course, was the Kyle report. At about the same time the heading `WA's Attorney-General pressed to stand aside' appeared in the Australian Financial Review. That article read:
Western Australia's Attorney-General, Mrs Cheryl Edwardes, was being pressed last night to stand aside following allegations that she misled Parliament over the funding of her 1989 election campaign.

PARA.TAB: Mrs Edwardes has told Parliament. . . that she received only $2,000 and the use of a facsimile machine from a friend, Dr Wayne Bradshaw, a former Mayor of Wanneroo who is now practising in the Maldive Islands.

SPEECH.PARA: He subsequently came back. The article continues:
But Dr Bradshaw told Channel Nine News in Perth. . . that he had funded `at least' $30,000 of Mrs Edwardes's campaign expenses.

We find numerous expressions of interest and views indicating that these matters should be the subject of an inquiry. I notice that the Wanneroo Times carries the headline `MPs are split on inquiry'. The article indicates that, whilst the independent member for Moore, Mr Filing, is in favour of an inquiry, the member for Cowan, Mr Richard Evans, who has been placed on probation by way of his preselection in respect of these same people, was unavailable for comment. We know where he stands in respect of these matters.

PARA.TAB: So we have a conclusive, comprehensive case. We have impropriety and convictions for bribery and corruption in a city which is funded by the Commonwealth. There is clear evidence that the Premier of Western Australia needs to take action to stamp out this corruption at the local level. However, he refuses to act. This is the person who came to office pledging accountability in government. He refuses to implement the recommendations of the WA Inc. royal commission; he refuses to implement COG's recommendations; and he will not call an inquiry into the city of Wanneroo where there is clearly corruption and bribery. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) thinks that this blatant and obvious attempt to distract attention from the woes of the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) will rehabilitate him in the eyes of his colleagues, let alone the eyes of the man he once served, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), he will be sadly disappointed. What is most distressing is that the government, in proposing this totally phoney attempt to link the Commonwealth with a local government dispute and allegations of corruption in one municipality in Perth, has deliberately knocked off a very important matter of public importance submitted by the member for Aston (Mr Nugent).

PARA.TAB: The Australian public should choose what matter they would prefer to take up the time of the federal parliament—whether they would want this matter of public importance put forward by the member for Perth, which is only an attempt to dredge over a scandal associated with the Wanneroo council, which is a matter of a police investigation and is entirely within the jurisdiction of that government, or whether they would want their representatives discussing the matter of public importance put forward by the member for Aston. That MPI proposal read, `That this House discuss Australia's growing foreign debt and the lack of a coherent plan by the government to resolve the situation.'
The Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Beazley) canvassed this very issue in the parliament yesterday. In calling for an inquiry then, he admitted:

SPEECH.PARA: Without any question, it should be organised by the state government and/or the state parliament. That is precisely what ought to proceed.

Yet 24 hours later the time of the federal parliament is being taken up by the member for Perth over an issue that his Deputy Prime Minister freely concedes is entirely within the jurisdiction of another government or parliament.

PARA.TAB: The motives of the member for Perth are twofold. First, he is trying to re-establish himself after being caught out over the weekend in plotting and assembling numbers against the Prime Minister. Secondly, he is trying to distract attention from the evidence of the Minister for Human Services and Health at the royal commission last week and her subsequent pathetic, unconvincing performance in this House on Monday and Tuesday. The member for Perth and his inseparable friend the member for Lilley (Mr Swan) are known as the Glimmer twins. The Glimmer twins got caught out over the weekend in stirring up trouble against the Prime Minister, expressing dissent and canvassing his replacement by the Deputy Prime Minister before the next federal election.

The member for Perth has had a long experience in displacing Labor leaders. The first taste of blood was when he was state secretary for the Western Australian ALP. A report of two weeks ago in the Eastern Suburbs Reporter, a newspaper in Perth, states:
The most controversial of events which marked Smith's time as state secretary was when he engineered the end of Peter Dowding's short reign as premier.
Smith has no regrets about the event which, he says, he'd have no qualms repeating, given the same political conditions.

SPEECH.PARA: The report continues:

PARA.TAB: "Peter Dowding had lost the confidence of his colleagues and the community," Smith said.
"In politics, if no-one's listening, you're better to put the cue back in the rack."

SPEECH.PARA: That is parallel with the situation regarding the Prime Minister. No-one is listening to him. People have tuned off. His performance—as highlighted with the most petulant, even bizarre personal explanation, on his rostered day off, in this House a short time ago—proves that he has completely lost the plot. The set of conditions which led the member for Perth to move against the then leader of the Western Australia Labor Party, Peter Dowding, is exactly the same today. Instead of Peter Dowding losing the confidence of his colleagues and the community, Paul Keating has. Instead of no-one listening to Peter Dowding, no-one is listening to Paul Keating. Therefore, he had better put the cue back in the rack once again.

PARA.TAB: The member for Perth was recruited by the Prime Minister in 1990 to join his staff as a political adviser. He then set about mustering the numbers for the then Treasurer. When the then Treasurer botched his first attempt against ex-Prime Minister Bob Hawke, he went to the back bench. The member for Perth was warehoused in the office of the then minister for science and technology. But that did not stop him moving about the press gallery and elsewhere in the Labor Party, undermining the then Treasurer, John Kerin, and the then Prime Minister, Bob Hawke. When Paul Keating came to the prime ministership, the member for Perth returned to his staff. He left before the last federal election and was elected in his own right to the seat of Perth.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Rocher)—Order! The honourable member should try to relate his remarks to the matter of public importance.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposer of this MPI has no credibility on this issue, nor any other. But he is only one half of the Glimmer twins, one half of the duo moving against the Prime Minister. His partner in crime is the member for Lilley. The member for Lilley's political judgment and credentials are in tatters following the disaster for the ALP at the last Queensland election. So, together with Mike Kaiser, Kevin Rudd, Craig Emerson and Wayne Goss, this little group forms the nucleus of the ALP machine in that state. They are the backroom boys. They conducted and planned that state election completely within their cell. Therefore, they can take the blame for the humiliation which the Goss government suffered and which will inevitably shorten its term in government.

PARA.TAB: The member for Lilley engineered such dishonest political campaign techniques as the accusation that the coalition would sell private hospitals—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, my point of order relates to relevance, which you have also raised with the shadow minister. I ask you to bring him back to the matter of public importance under discussion.
—The member must address his remarks to the matter of public importance.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, you will have heard most, if not all, of the contribution of the member for Perth. He covered a great deal of information and mentioned members' names that had no bearing on the matter before the House. The member for Lilley is part and parcel of this push against the Prime Minister.
—Order! The remarks of the honourable member for Perth did go to local government funding.

—The member for Perth seized on one local government body in all of Australia to expand on his contribution before the House. It was totally unconvincing. It was a very shallow and obvious attempt to attack the Liberal Party in that state, and it should be seen for what it is.

PARA.TAB: The Glimmer twins, as they are so fondly known, have been working the corridors. We think their numbers have increased over the last few days, as more and more are prepared to associate themselves with this push against the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who?
—There are quite a few. There is Senator Beahan from WA, Senator Childs from New South Wales, Senator Neal from New South Wales—
—Order! The honourable member will get back to the matter before the chair.

—I was provoked, Mr Deputy Speaker. It is very important that this matter of public importance be debated in the spirit in which the proposer intended. Let us not have from the government this pretence of motives higher than those of the opposition. We intend to meet the government full frontal on this issue. Let us have an inquiry into the Botany council. That was a scandal which involved the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) and which has never been answered. The only reason it was not answered was that his mate from the New South Wales Labor Party—the then Attorney-General of the New South Wales government and the present Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker)—no billed the action against Laurie Brereton.

PARA.TAB: Laurie Brereton escaped prosecution because the Attorney-General of his own government no billed the action. So let us have an inquiry into the Botany council and the allegations—allegations that have never been cleared up—of corruption that surround the Minister for Industrial Relations.

I return to the member for Lilley, whose game plan has been revealed. Two weeks after the state election on 15 July the Courier-Mail, in an article by Peter Charlton, revealed the `Death of a Grand Plan'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. You have asked on at least two occasions for the shadow minister to come back to the matter under discussion in this matter of public importance. Again, the member has moved far from that. I ask you to bring him back to the matter of substance.

—I have asked him to address the matter before the chair. He has referred to an article and a grand plan. I am afraid I don't know what is in the grand plan. It might be something to do with local government; but, if it is not, I suggest the honourable member gets on to local government.

—Whoever occupies the office of Prime Minister in this country vitally affects local government. The reason why the member for Lilley is moving to replace the Prime Minister with the Deputy Prime Minister—for electoral purposes, he thinks—is that the original grand plan, which was to come down to Canberra with Kaiser, Emerson, Rudd and Goss was blown to smithereens with the dismal failure at the last state election.
—All right, you have made your little digression. Get back.

—A great many local councils in my constituency and throughout Australia demand a change in the leadership of this country at the prime ministerial level and at the governmental level. Those councils will be vitally interested in just who is signing up to the Glimmer twins. A list of supporters includes the member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland), the member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), the member for Greenway (Mr Gorman), the member for Chifley (Mr Price), the Speaker and the member for Jagajaga (Mr Staples). Names like Staples, Price, Gorman, Langmore and Haviland are becoming part of the lexicon.

PARA.TAB: The poor old member for Chifley, who is going to second this motion, was stripped of his office of Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister in a very vindictive way by the current Prime Minister because he was loyal to his then Prime Minister Hawke. Nobody has suffered more through the petty attitude and ambitions of people such as the member for Perth and the member for Lilley than this man, the member for Chifley, who for some incomprehensible reason is joining with the member for Perth in proposing this matter of public importance.

But we know the real tactic, other than building again the crumbling status of the member for Perth and, by extension, that of the other half of the Glimmer twins, the member for Lilley; but I get as confused as others as to whether it is Wayne Smith or Stephen Swan—or whether it is interchangeable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! You will refer to honourable members by their correct names.

—But the real tactic is to try to shield the Minister for Human Services and Health. Nothing will do that for she is condemned out of her own mouth. There is nobody in Australia who is going to believe her on anything, let alone on the scare campaign on Medicare that those opposite have joyously foreshadowed for the next election.

PARA.TAB: The minister's credibility no longer exists to the extent that it once did. We know that she gave evidence before the royal commission, evidence she has since contradicted in this parliament. The classic example is her claim before the royal commission that she did not know that section 121 of the Family Law Act decreed that no matters of a family law proceeding could be revealed publicly.

We know from the letters she wrote prior to the tabling of the Easton petition in 1992 that she had corresponded at length on this issue with the Western Australian Council for Civil Liberties. She abused the council yesterday, as if that goes to the issue of whether or not she knew the sanctity of section 121 of the Family Law Act. Of course it did not. She knew very well that she was in breach of that provision when she encouraged and facilitated the tabling of the Easton petition. So those of you opposite can put up any phoney motion any time of the day you wish, but the fact is that the position of the Minister for Human Services and Health is irretrievable politically. Nothing you say or do will restore her credibility, let alone any trust or confidence in her by the Australian people. Your motion is a fraud; and it fails dismally. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price The Hon L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I need to declare an interest in this motion, as a former alderman on Blacktown City Council. I must say I was very pleased to be that and Deputy Mayor of Blacktown City Council. In terms of financial assistance for the two local government areas that I represented, Blacktown received over $8 million and Penrith, $6 million. In roads we received about $1 1/2 million for Blacktown and $1.1 million for Penrith. If people wish to proceed with development applications before Blacktown City Council, they do so. I sometimes interfered grossly in the operations of the council by suggesting that I would like to see improvements to things like libraries.

PARA.TAB: We cooperated on other federal funding; for example, a CEP program as it then was, or the local government capital assistance program. Both Penrith and Blacktown are very keen to get development; but to get development in those local government areas you do not need to bribe anyone—there is no need to bribe the councillors. Blacktown is the largest council in New South Wales; Wanneroo Council is the largest council—as I understand it—in Western Australia. They receive $2.6 million and $1.5 million. In any federal expenditure to any organisation whether it be an NGO operating overseas helping people, whether it be a state government, or whether it be a council, we need to be assured of probity.

It was not I who raised the royal commission into the death of Penny Easton. I do not have to remind the House that Carmen Lawrence is not in the dock because of maladministration, because she accepted a bribe, because her husband works in the same department or because she has developed a cell within a particular federal division. That is not the case in Wanneroo. Indeed, I want to ask the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) whether he supports Hendy Cowan, the Deputy Premier in Western Australia, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Court government's decision to call the Easton royal commission had made it more difficult for it to justify not holding an inquiry into Wanneroo Inc.

You cannot run the argument that the federal Liberal Party or federal Liberal members are not being affected by Wanneroo Inc. For example, does the honourable member for Gippsland support the words of the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing), a former Liberal Party member, who says:

I would only be too happy to see a full judicial inquiry being held into the aspects of the business dealings of the former Mayor, Wayne Bradshaw, now the sitting member for Wanneroo; Wayde Smith MLA and others who are involved, including Councillor Colin Edwards, a former councillor of the city of Wanneroo.

The opposition are always lecturing us about how they want to have honest government, open government, credible government and integrity in government. Has anyone heard the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) make one comment about Wanneroo Inc? He says he supports the honourable member for Moore. Does he support him in his call for an inquiry? As my colleague the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) pointed out, the Kyle report said:
There is little doubt that Bradshaw formed and led a faction. This group consisted of active Liberal Party members of the Moore division of the Liberal Party.

So there is a direct link-up here. Is the Leader of the Opposition, Honest John Howard, happy with this situation? Who is part of this? There was Bradshaw and Wayde Smith—what an interesting character he is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wayne or Wayde?
—Wayde. He is a policeman on a salary of $35,000, but he is able to finance developing mortgages for over a million dollars.

PARA.TAB: I invite the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) to support his colleague the Deputy Premier in New South Wales and have the guts to say he supports a royal commission into the criminal activity in the Liberal Party in the federal division of Moore—Wanneroo Inc.

This policeman was able to fund his development activities while serving on the police force. His repayments on the $1 million loan were at 14 per cent. He had to repay $66,000 a year, or $5,500 a month, or $1,270 a week—around double a sergeant's gross annual pay—at the time the loans were being served.

This Bradshaw character, the former mayor, is in gaol. But when Mr Kyle wanted to investigate him he fled to the Maldives; he would not stay. When John Howard says that the Western Australian industrial relations legislation will be a good template for the Liberal Party federally, is he endorsing this ulcerous, cankerous sore in the Western Australian Liberal Party? Silence! I have not heard him. Yet he has an opportunity to stand up for integrity. Just because Noel Crichton-Browne has been removed, it does not mean that this ulcer has been removed from the federal Liberal Party or from Western Australia.

The husband of the state Attorney-General, Mr Colin Edwardes, a numbers man, had the uncanny knack of always supporting the same candidates as Noel Crichton-Browne. He is tied up with Mr Bradshaw. Indeed, Mr Bradshaw gave a donation, so it was claimed by the state Attorney-General, Mr Edwardes's wife, Sheryl, of $2,000. But this is disputed. In Western Australia, apparently, it is okay if the Attorney-General has a good friend who is found guilty of criminal corruption and fails to cooperate with inquiries. That is apparently okay in the Liberal Party. It does not worry the federal Liberal Party. It does not worry honest John Howard. He cannot stand up like the National Deputy Premier of Western Australia and say, `There ought to be an inquiry.'

The biggest courage the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) can show is to get up and say, `This is a scandal,' but he does not want anything more to be done with it. He does not call for a royal commission. He does not urge his colleagues, `Clean up this cancer. Clean up this sore. Let's exorcise it. Let's go to an election with clean hands.' There is none of that. Of course federal money is involved in councils. And, of course, the federal Liberal Party is involved in this scandal, as the honourable member for Gippsland has called it.

It is absolutely incredible when you have a state Attorney-General admit to election funding of $2,000, yet someone who is in gaol says, `But I actually donated $30,000 to that campaign.' Mr Court—`Mr Clean', the man who instigated with John Howard the Marks royal commission—does not find grounds to call a royal commission into criminality or into the dubious quality of his Attorney-General and her peculiar election funding arrangements. No. They want a royal commission about a petition lodged in parliament.

No wonder there is a lot of doubt within the electorate generally about whether or not the Leader of the Opposition has the courage to stand up in Western Australia and say, `Enough is enough. I have lost two federal members because of Noel Crichton-Browne. I have lost two federal members because of corruption within the Liberal Party. I have lost two federal members because the largest council in Western Australia was totally corrupt.'

Yet there has not been a complete investigation. Mr Kyle, the one that got the old can opener and opened the tin of worms, says, `I wasn't able to interview Mr Bradshaw. I believe that we should reopen the inquiry.' Indeed, this very day there will be moves in the state parliament to have a royal commission. Will honest John Howard stand up for the federal Liberals in Western Australia and say, `We need this commission of inquiry; we've got to clean out this sore, this canker, this ulcer'? (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Mr R.D.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to join this debate because I have a number of issues to talk about regarding Wanneroo—Wanneroo being the very best city of Wanneroo—because, in fact, it falls within my seat. But let me just go to a couple of things from the previous speakers. The member for Chifley (Mr Price) talks about factions. Was Hal Jackson a member of Chifley's faction when he was taking bribes for letting people out of gaol? I wonder whether that then implicates the member for Chifley.

PARA.TAB: In his opening comment, the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) talked about assistance to local councils. Let me quote from Hansard of 17 September 1992 when the member for Moore (Mr Filing) said:

In the seats of Swan, Brand and Perth where sitting Labor members—or, as in the case of Perth, into which WA Inc. player and Keating apparatchik Stephen Smith has been slotted at the expense of the sitting member—$3m, $4m and $3.9m respectively have been earmarked for capital works.

SPEECH.PARA: This was part of the budget in 1992—a bit of pork-barrelling. The quote continues:
One does not have to be a cynic to draw the conclusion that the marginal Labor seats have been targeted. But the counter argument is that in leaving out
the city of Wanneroo—
leaving out the city of Wanneroo in funding—
the seat of Cowan is affected. That, of course, is another marginal electorate which is expected to fall to the Liberal candidate—
a good candidate—

Richard Evans at the next election. However, it has to be said that a large section of the electorate of Cowan does fall without the city of Wanneroo and this would be covered by the generous grants to neighbouring councils.
It is amazing on this day that we were going to be talking about debt that we are actually talking about something like this raised by the member for Perth.

PARA.TAB: We all remember the member for Perth. He was actually the Labor state secretary during those infamous WA Inc. years. So does the argument the member for Chifley has just raised implicating everyone associated with the Liberal Party in Western Australia somehow, with those that are in gaol, implicate the member for Perth as the secretary of the Australian Labor Party during the Burke and Parker years?

Remember Burke? Burke in fact was gaoled for three years for stealing $17,000 of taxpayers' funds. Remember David Parker? He was gaoled for stealing $50,000 of campaign funds. So does that implicate the member for Perth in this whole thing?
The member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) spoke of a comment in the Eastern Suburbs Reporter on 5 September which quoted the member for Perth. It says:

If Labor does not make it across the finishing line at the next election, Smith is certain to throw his hat in the ring for a ministerial portfolio. This is a marked change from his early days in parliament when Smith was reported as saying he was just one of the many in line for a ministerial appointment, but he didn't believe he was one of them, nor should he be.
"If we win the next election, I would have some prospect of becoming a minister", said Smith.

SPEECH.PARA: We are talking about probity, honesty and not playing with the truth. Surely that is an indication from a local newspaper last week that the member for Perth is trying to hide something by bringing this particular MPI on today.

PARA.TAB: There are other people that the `human headline' was associated with. Have you ever noticed that the member for Perth always talks in headlines? He always grabs headlines here and shows them to the cameras—like this one here that says `Smith no longer wanted'. He talks in headlines. He is the human headline. An original word never comes out of him.

But other people are implicated in those WA Inc. years. Remember David Smith? His gambling debts were paid off by the Labor Party. I am not sure whether Julian Grull, another Labor Party member over there, has been charged with something to do with the WA Inc. years.

We are really talking about standards. It is interesting how the Labor Party are on their high horse on this particular issue. It is a real cheek to be talking about standards. Let us talk about the national debt, which we were supposed to be talking about today, and the debt of local councils.
Millions of Australian children will be locked into a cycle of inherited debt by this Labor Party by the time they reach adulthood. This is a grim but true position.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The matter of public importance before the House today deals with government finances to local government bodies. This has absolutely nothing to do with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before question time, when this debate was interrupted, I was speaking to the circulated amendment which the coalition is moving in relation to car parking benefits under the fringe benefits tax legislation. The Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) said, in his concluding remarks to the second reading speech, that he was, in effect, inviting the coalition to come in here and move any amendments which they like that would improve this legislation. When we do come in here and move some amendments to improve this legislation, we find the government saying, `No, we are not going to accept these amendments.'

PARA.TAB: The nature of the amendments themselves indicate quite clearly that this government is not concerned about really reducing the compliance costs on small business so far as the fringe benefits tax is concerned; it is really interested in raising revenue. Take the amendments which we are dealing with at the present time. One of them deals with the statutory number of days; that is, the number of days set out in the fringe benefits tax legislation to which the car parking conditions will apply. This legislation proposes that there be 240 days to which fringe benefits tax would become payable if the car parking provisions are actually in operation.

If you take the number of days in the financial year—365—and you take away the number of weekends for which you would expect that the cars would not be parked in such car parking places, you will find that that brings the number down to 261. If you then take away the average number of public holidays around Australia—namely, 11—and annual holidays of four weeks, which is another 20 days, and if you add two days very conservatively estimated for sick leave, you are reduced to 228 days for which fringe benefits tax ought to be payable.

But what does this legislation provide? It provides for 240 days. The government is saying to small business operators that it is going to charge fringe benefits tax on a total of 240 days rather than 220 days, when you would expect that the business might actually be making use of the car parking provisions. The government is, in effect, ripping an extra 12 days of the year off small business in relation to this provision alone. They come in here and say that they are interested in reducing compliance costs. This is, quite simply, another revenue grab by the government.

What we have also proposed in this amendment is that the $5 figure for parking ought to be indexed. The government obviously is not going to accept this amendment; the Assistant Treasurer has said that he will not do that. So what we have is car parking provisions in areas which may not be subject to fringe benefits tax requirements at the present time. But, without any indexation of that $5, over time that will become subject to FBT. Again, the failure to index the figure of $5 is another example of revenue being raised by bracket creep. Many small businesses at present exempt from this FBT requirement will in future years find themselves caught by it and paying the fringe benefits tax when we are told that this is about reducing compliance. The reality in these two examples alone is that this is about increasing the revenue to the Commonwealth. Very little of it is about an actual reduction in compliance costs.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment relates to taxi travel provided to employees. The proposal in this legislation is that an exemption will be made available for taxi travel between 8 p.m. and 6 a.m. justified on the basis of health and safety reasons. Taxi travel provided to employees may qualify as an expense fringe benefit or as a residual fringe benefit. However, the provision of transport by an employer for an employee between home and work may be an exempt benefit if it qualifies as an exempt minor benefit. A benefit is an exempt minor benefit where the benefit provided is small, and similar benefits are provided irregularly or infrequently.

PARA.TAB: This bill proposes to exempt taxi travel provided to employees for travel directly between work and home between eight in the evening and six in the morning. The exemption covers taxi travel for the entire journey or part of a direct journey home. It exempts taxi travel provided for sick or injured employees to travel from work to their usual place of residence. The exemption extends to taxi travel between work and home via a doctor's surgery or other place of treatment. It also extends to travel from work to a place where the employee can get care; for example, to a relative's home.

This amendment proposes, in effect, to alter those hours for which taxi travel can be provided by an employer to an employee to the hours of 7 p.m. to 7 a.m., rather than from 8 p.m. to 6 a.m. We believe that this broadens the exemption in a way which is consistent with the daylight period for employees to be provided with taxi travel to go home. In this day and age with the increasing part-time and casual work and with the increasing use of all times of the day by many business offices, if you go into the cities you often see employees finishing work at 8 p.m. and 9 p.m. Those companies that have international connections and international business, in order to be able to participate in business with overseas businesses who have different times, obviously require employees to be working at times—often routinely—beyond 7 p.m. and even often beyond 8 p.m. Given that many of these employees are women, the health and safety reason consistent with the daylight hours is one which we urge upon the government in this particular amendment.

As I said before, the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) has offered to accept amendments which come forward in relation to this matter. I suppose this, in a sense, is a test of the attitude of the government in reality as opposed to the rhetoric which has just been expressed by the Assistant Treasurer in relation to amendments. If the government is not prepared to accept an amendment which, in the scheme of things, could be regarded as minor in terms of the fringe benefits scheme and regarded as minor in terms of any forgone revenue to the government, then I think that speaks for itself. It says that this is a whole lot of rhetoric we have heard from the Assistant Treasurer about amendments.

In fact, if we came forward with some substantial amendments, which the whole business community has been crying out for—for example, in relation to trying to align the fringe benefits tax year with the income tax and other taxation years; some substantial amendments which would actually go some way to really reducing the compliance costs of this scheme on business—we know that would be equally rejected. There is really not much purpose in coming forward with them.

I urge the Assistant Treasurer and the government to accept this amendment. With the working women of Australia in particular now being forced because of changed economic and business circumstances in many instances to travel home after the hours of sunset—those hours often being after 7 p.m., and in cities like Melbourne, Hobart and Adelaide it starts to get dark at 5 p.m. in winter—this does seem to me to be a reasonable provision. Accordingly, I urge it upon the government.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ELLIOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to amend the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 to implement decisions made by the government in respect of higher education and to make minor policy and technical changes. The bill's provisions amend section 17 of the Act to adjust funding for operating grants to reflect the major research facilities program and to provide supplementation for 1994, 1995 and 1996 price movements. Supplementation for price movements is also provided for superannuation expenses, teaching hospitals and special capital projects.

PARA.TAB: The various provisions of the bill should be seen in the context of the government's overall policy directions for higher education. In particular, as confirmed in the recent budget, the government remains committed to a large, accessible, diverse and innovative system of publicly funded higher education. This bill underpins that objective by, for example, providing new and additional support for innovations in open learning and educational technology, enhancing the opportunities for universities to offer student places funded jointly with industry, and improving the detailed operations of the higher education contribution scheme.

The bill makes substantial improvements to the open learning initiative. The two main elements of the open learning initiative are the Open Learning Agency of Australia—OLAA—an independent open learning organisation, and the development of an open learning electronic support service—Open Net. In addition to rolling over unused funding from 1994-95 to 1995-96, the amendment to the act will provide for the extension of the open learning initiative.

Open Net provides teaching and learning assistance to enrolled students of OLAA, allowing students to communicate with tutors and other students by E-mail and through bulletin boards, to transfer assignments and access electronic library services and other national and international information resources through the Internet.

Given the immense benefit that Open Net can offer to a range of students, the act will be amended to extend Open Net services to additional nominated client groups, potentially including other higher education, TAFE and school students. The official launch of Open Net in May was an important step in realising the potential benefits of new technologies for Australian higher education.

Open Net is the first step in the establishment of the recently announced Education Network Australia—EdNA—which in itself is part of a broader national strategy to enable Australia to adopt new information and communications services and technologies—the so-called information superhighway. Key objectives of EdNA are to maximise the use of new communications technologies, to improve the quality of learning in the education and training sectors and to maximise industry development of opportunities for Australians. The initiative has the potential to make a major contribution to equity in educational opportunity across the country. the expansion of the coverage of Open Net is an important step in this process.

The role that new technology is playing in the education and training sector is evident in another aspect of the bill. The bill provides the statutory framework and funding arrangements for the cooperative multimedia centres—CMC—program announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in his cultural policy statement Creative Nation. This statement addressed the challenge of creating `a dynamic Australian multimedia industry providing Australian content for Australian and international consumers'. The CMC initiative was announced to address the identified need to build a critical pool of talent with multimedia skills.

The objective of the program is to support the development of a competitive, internationally successful, Australian multimedia industry. It is intended to bring together a wide range of people, organisations and resources in order to meet the challenge of the multimedia industry's skill requirements. The CMCs will catalyse the development of collaborative links between the education and training sectors and the industrial and creative communities. They will support multimedia skill formation while also bringing other benefits to those involved in producing and distributing multimedia.

To foster developments in multimedia, the government will seed the development of up to six CMCs over the next two years and will provide funding for the centres of up to $56.5 million over nine years. The CMCs will be collaborative enterprises between education and training centres, private industry organisations and the arts-cultural communities. The CMCs will also encourage cooperation in many areas including research and development, product distribution, management of intellectual property and sharing of access to equipment and facilities.

An important aspect of the government's higher education policy is to encourage productive interactions between higher education institutions and industry across all fields. To this end the joint Commonwealth-industry funded additional places scheme was established in the 1991 budget as a partnership between the government and industry. The objectives of the scheme are to provide additional places in higher education institutions and to encourage linkages with industry.

Under existing program arrangements the Commonwealth contributes 60 per cent of the cost of a place and industry the remaining 40 per cent. Approximately 20 per cent of the cost is returned to the Commonwealth by way of HECS. In 1994 the program generated an additional uptake of 868 new places; 74 per cent of places under this scheme were filled by students selected by their employers.

The government is keen to build on this success and is revising the program's guidelines to introduce greater flexibility for institutions and industry partners. Part of these changes is to enhance the choices available in relation to HECS charges for students in joint Commonwealth-industry funded places.At present all places under the scheme are HECS liable. Section 35 of the act is amended by this bill to allow a HECS exemption for students occupying places under the scheme.

Under the new arrangements institutions would have the discretion to deem students HECS exempt where employers wish to pay 60 per cent of the cost of a place—that is, including the equivalent of the students' HECS charge. The Commonwealth's contribution will remain at 60 per cent. In such cases the Commonwealth would require institutions to remit the equivalent of the HECS charge. This will not result in an increase in the cost to the Commonwealth and industry will contribute a greater proportion of the cost of the HECS exempt places. As a consequence there will be no net loss of Commonwealth revenue.

This amendment to the scheme will provide greater flexibility to institutions in providing courses at times and under arrangements that are more suited to the needs of industry. In other minor changes, section 3 of the act is amended to rectify an anomaly by removing the reference to TAFE in the definition of a `course of study'.

The bill amends the act to extend the capacity of the secretary to remit a student's HECS debt to cover the period after an appeal has been lodged with the Administrative Appeals Tribunal where additional information has been provided by the applicant. This will provide a more timely service that benefits both the government and the student by reducing the need for AAT hearings.

Finally, the bill makes a number of minor amendments, including an amendment to section 110 of the act, to remove references to obsolete provisions. The bill also makes a minor amendment to section 43 to provide that applications for tax file numbers must be lodged directly with the Australian Taxation Office and can no longer be lodged at institutions. As the Commissioner of Taxation has responsibility for issuing tax file numbers for administrative reasons, it is appropriate for applications for tax file numbers to be made directly to that office.

This bill reflects this government's commitment to an internationally recognised, high quality higher education system which is striving for excellence and innovation in teaching and research—a system which is accessible to all Australians. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Dr D.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Elliott) has made clear in the second reading speech, the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 1) covers quite a wide range of matters. It varies the maximum grant amounts for specified years in relation to the operating grants for universities. It varies the maximum grant limits on total funds available to reflect funding for the major research facilities program and general supplementation of funding. It also varies grants amounts for superannuation expenses, grants to teaching hospitals and grants for special capital projects. Open learning organisations will be able to have unused funds rolled over into the funding provided in subsequent years.

PARA.TAB: Other provisions of the bill enable the Minister for Employment, Education and Training to make a grant to provide teaching and learning assistance to persons other than clients of an open learning organisation as long as the minister is satisfied as to certain matters. New provisions put into the act by this bill seek to allow the minister to make a grant for expenditure by a cooperative multimedia centre, to enable an institution to declare that a student whose place is jointly funded by the Commonwealth and industry is an exempt student and is not liable to pay contributions under the HECS scheme and also to enable the secretary to the department to review decisions reconsidering applications by students for remission of a semester debt in certain circumstances.

Under this bill, it will no longer be possible for an application for a tax file number to be lodged with the appropriate officer of an institution. There are also minor technical and consequential amendments related to these provisions.

The bill provides increases in funding of $272.2 million for the triennium 1994-96 and funding of $8.247 million for 1997-99 for the cooperative multimedia centres program. There is also a reduction of $0.047 million to legislated amounts as a result of adjustments to the higher education cost adjustment factor.

The bill is therefore a wide ranging bill involving the commitment by the government to significant expenditures of taxpayers' money. It is therefore appropriate to make some very broad comments about the nature of the activities on which this money is to be expended and to measure the performance of the government in relation to the activities against the goals stated by the parliamentary secretary in the second reading speech.

Whatever the government's rhetorical commitment to a higher education system of high quality, excellence and innovation accessible to all Australians, it is quite clear that it is not the reality at all. The higher education system is not accessible to all qualified Australians, not by a long shot.

The higher education system in this country at the moment is struggling very greatly to maintain quality and excellence. The system is under strain. The difficulties it is facing as a result of the policies that the government has put in place make a sad mockery of the clever country rhetoric which we used to hear from the former Prime Minister.

Let me just put a few facts on the record. The government's rhetoric says `a system accessible to all Australians'. Nearly 23,000 qualified young Australians were turned away this year from university because the government has failed to provide sufficient funding for those places or establish a system under which those students can get access—and this is after 12 years of this government. The government will say it has seen a very significant expansion in participation in higher education over this decade, and that is quite correct. It would be a shocking thing if that were not so.

The expansion of the higher education system has been a national goal of this country for several decades, in fact from the time the Liberal-National coalition government under Sir Robert Menzies led to the establishment of a large number of new universities. Since that time, there has been a consensus in this country that there must be a substantial expansion of the higher education system. For the government to say that it has simply continued the expansion of that system is no real credit to it other than to say that it has done what everyone expected it would do and should do, and that any government would do and must continue to do.

But what is patently obvious is that there has been, and remains, a massive gap between the rhetoric of the government that it is going to provide a higher education system which will provide a firm foundation for the so-called clever country. At the same time, it maintains a policy which has excluded year after year tens of thousands of qualified young Australians who are therefore unable to obtain a place within the university.

This does not apply solely to undergraduate students. Let me put another key fact on the record about the current operation of the higher education system. Two-thirds of the qualified students who applied for postgraduate awards this year were turned away. Of the 6,700 eligible students who applied for a postgraduate research award at the beginning of the year, 4,000 missed out.

This is an appalling situation, and it was highlighted by Mr Frank Hambly, the Executive Director of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee. He said that many of the 4,000 qualified students whom the government refused to fund were among the best and the brightest of the young Australians seeking to build on their abilities and build a base for making a substantial contribution to this country through pursuing postgraduate education.

Support for postgraduate education, Mr Hambly said, is critical to Australia and to Australia's economic and social development. We are talking here about our future scientists, our future researchers, our future academics and other senior professionals, yet the government simply says, `We can do without the commitment of 4,000 highly talented young people. We will fund only one-third of the applicants.' This is a country which is desperate for skilled and educated people to compete in an increasingly competitive world, yet we hear this hollow, shallow rhetoric that this is a system accessible to all Australians.

A generation of the most talented young Australians is being sacrificed at the moment by the higher education policies of this government. For that small proportion who get in to pursue their higher education work in the postgraduate research area, the research infrastructure with which they have to deal is in crisis. It remains grossly underfunded. This is a result of a decade of declining resources per student, a decade of clever schemes to claw back funding from the operating grants of the universities, which has led to a significant run down in the discretionary funds available—both to bring on the young postgraduate trainees and to foster, build up and keep up to date the research infrastructure of the universities.

Over the life of this government, funding per student has declined some 15 per cent. The result of this has been that the students who do get in face huge class sizes, declining quality of library services and overcrowded tutorial rooms. It means that university staff are faced with increasing pressures as they try to cope with these declining resources per student. They try to do the best possible job they can by the students who are crowding into their lecture theatres and tutorial rooms.

The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) quoted—I can only assume out of context, but I have yet to see the full context—Alan Gilbert, the current Vice-Chancellor of the University of Tasmania and the Vice-Chancellor to be of the University of Melbourne. It may be also useful to put on the record in this House other comments by Professor Gilbert, who said that he was very concerned about the current state of Australian universities. In an address to the Menzies Research Centre, in a seminar only a couple of months ago, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The essential truth—and I cannot emphasise this too strongly—is that all Australian universities are precariously placed and precariously funded. The weakest need resources to improve infrastructure, recruit better staff, add greater educational value to the students they enrol. The very best of Australia's universities are under pressures to improve quality that are at least as great.
He went on to say—and this is a sobering comment from someone who has extremely wide respect through the university system:

Where does our best university rank among the world's higher education institutions. Perhaps it scrapes into the first 50—perhaps, perhaps not. Dare we let our best slip even from that precarious level. Dare we risk negotiating the 21st century without even a place at the table of world class intellectual, scientific and cultural discourse?
In another part of that address, Professor Gilbert said:

Higher education quality is under threat. Indeed, perhaps the main reason for the recent emphasis on quality assurance in Australian higher education is academic and public concern that the coming of mass higher education has lowered standards in the universities.
He went on to say:

Mediocre higher education is the `Banana Republic' option. For an ill-educated, knowledge-poor Australia would not simply become internationally marginalised and economically deprived; it would also have little chance surviving as a stable, liberal democracy.

We cannot afford anything less than world-class universities, world-class higher education. It is quite clear that this government has failed the test. The higher education system, with its quality, is under enormous pressure and is under threat.

PARA.TAB: The current state of the universities results from eight years of upheaval, constant reorganisation, amalgamations—some of which have already broken down—and attempts to impose on these universities a centralised system of supervision and control following the famous Dawkins white paper of 1988, which said that in future the universities would be administered by the Department of Employment, Education and Training. There has been an effort to impose on the university system an ideology of managerialism, of crude notions of efficiency, which have been immensely disruptive and which have resulted—

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with efficiency?

—There is nothing wrong at all with efficiency properly understood. But there is everything wrong with the highly centralised way in which the government has gone about attempting to reorganise the universities of this country to suit its own financial and fiscal agenda at the expense of maintaining and building on the quality of that system.

PARA.TAB: The profiles process that is the government's main supervisory mechanism over the universities enthrones ignorance without rationality. There is no way whatever in which the Department of Employment, Education and Training is able to say what is or is not the appropriate development to take place within the university system. The consequence of this has been to press again and again the universities towards uniformity. Uniformity means something less than excellence. It means a great deal less than meeting the great variety of needs which students bring.

I need quote no-one else in support of this proposition than Professor Fay Gale, the President of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee. She made the point in an interview in the Australian higher education supplement of 2 August that the present system the government has in place is simply a system which presses towards, and presses down towards, uniformity. She said:
We have seen the big growth of business courses—everyone has a graduate school of management—and the growth in law schools . . . all that kind of movement points to uniformity.

SPEECH.PARA: She also said that she was upset by the cost of the accountability that accompanied the government's centralised system. She continued:

PARA.TAB: It is not so much that they set those precise guidelines or that we should be accountable, but the fact that every university is facing great costs in terms of compliance—which means that money which should be going to teaching and research is going into administration.
I think greater autonomy for universities—more trust [is warranted]. I believe we are good managers. Maybe in the past we have been a bit slack, but it certainly is not the case now.
Universities today are very accountable. Meetings of the AVCC show a bunch of people who are incredibly hard working and dedicated . . .

SPEECH.PARA: There are huge pressures within the system, and people have sought very hard, I believe, to comply with and improve the system, despite the great difficulties that have been placed on them by the government.

PARA.TAB: As an illustration of the problems that this system faces and the difficulties that Australia's universities are labouring under, let me refer to the launch in June this year of the review of higher education management—a review which was established by the government without proper consultation with the universities. The minister's announcement of this review speaks of the higher education system as part of the public sector. In a literal sense that may be true, but what is not true is that it is not part of the public service. I would like to quote the then president of the AVCC, who commented:

SPEECH.PARA: In order to fulfil their missions, universities operate at arms length from Government and with a high degree of independence. The Government must be aware that it is this very autonomy which makes universities so valuable to the nation as a whole and to the Government itself.

It would be tragic if this Review resulted in government intruding into the minute workings of universities. Universities are not Government agencies, and they are very different from the private sector, if only in the fact that they do not have the usual pricing mechanisms available to them.

This review was set up without any consultation with the universities. Some of its terms of reference seem to show an amazing lack of recognition of how the system is currently operating. One of the terms of reference was that the review should ensure that services are provided to overseas students on a full cost recovery basis.

PARA.TAB: If it were not for the profits which universities are currently deriving from this system, the conditions within the universities would be far worse than they currently are. The government is unaware of this, as is evidenced through the framing of this term of reference. It goes to show how out of touch it is with the real world of higher education. The education section of the Department of Employment, Education and Training is not the same as the Australian higher education section. Regrettably, there is a very substantial gulf between the two.

Through all of this, the central concept of what universities are about—that is, centres in the society where there is the capacity to pursue critically the analysis of social issues, to pursue high quality basic research and to be a source of ideas in society—is constantly being threatened by the government's approach of trying to push more and more students through the system with diminishing resources. The spirit of inquiry is being dulled and is under threat from this very framework. Until the universities have a much greater level of independence and autonomy these threats are going to continue. The system desperately needs a higher level of recognition. Universities need autonomy. Only autonomy is going to guarantee diversity and the quality that comes with diversity.

The notion that somehow or other quality can be assured by some quality assurance system, such as the government has put in place, is absurd. The system has been conceptually misconceived. You cannot secure quality by a committee. You certainly cannot make sensible quality judgments about institutions as a whole, given the very wide variety of courses, clients and students to which these universities must cater.

One of the sad consequences of this procedure, which the government has put in place, is that in the markets in Asian countries the ranking and quality of universities have been damned, as a result of this quality assurance system, in the eyes of many people in Asia who might come to Australia. They have been relegated to the lowest categories in the quality assurance system.

The only reason we have this system is the government has been hugely embarrassed by the ongoing debate about the damage which its administrative system—originating in the White Paper of 1988; the Dawkins system—has done to higher education and by the constant effort to squeeze the system to get more and more funds out of it and to force it to operate at cheaper and cheaper levels. As a consequence, tens of thousands of Australian students have been excluded when tens of thousands of overseas students have been admitted. The research infrastructure of the system has been significantly damaged. The opportunities for talented young Australians to pursue postgraduate work have been squeezed and in general the whole quality of the system has been placed at risk.

The government, in its efforts to raise more and more money from students themselves, has been extraordinarily hypocritical in its public claims about student fees. It has tried to claim that it has a no fees policy. This policy has got narrower and narrower as it has introduced more fees—fees for postgraduate courses and backdoor fees for undergraduates. The government knows that is happening. Students on Australian campuses know that there are students who are getting credit for courses, which they have undertaken for fees, which allow them go on and pursue undergraduate degrees.

The system that the government has tried to put in place is simply breaking down. The students around this country know about and have protested with increasing vigour against the lies and the hypocrisy coming from this government that it is pursuing a no fees policy. It was precisely such a demonstration that led to the famous episode when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said to a large number of students making their views known, `Go and get a job.' They have to go and get a job at a time when the government has been unable to provide sufficient paid employment for around two million Australians and when some 50 per cent of university graduates have full-time jobs a year after they have graduated.
