They cannot find full-time work and the Prime Minister says to these students, `Go and get a job.'

This is a government which is so grossly out of touch with what people in this country want and has lost sight so much of the basic objectives that we should be aiming at if we are at all serious about trying to produce a clever country that it has become an object of ridicule in the wider community. That is why tens of thousands of the government's traditional supporters are turning against them. No-one in its traditional base, those working class students for which the government proposes such rhetorical concern, can see other than the fact that government is squeezing them harder and harder as it tries to keep its ramshackle administrative system for Australian universities going.

In the remaining moments, let me comment on the cooperative multimedia centres element in this legislation. The proposed definition of cooperative multimedia centres stipulates that the purpose of such centres is the provision of services relating to education and training and undertaking other activities which will assist in the development of that industry. There is no reference in the definition to research and development. The coalition would like to see this included in that definition. I foreshadow that I will be moving an amendment, on behalf of the coalition, to include a reference to research and development.

Two major concerns have been raised in relation to the cooperative multimedia centres. The first is that they would be better placed within an area relating to information technology rather than under the umbrella of education and under the control of DEET. The second issue of concern is that the eastern states, and most particularly Sydney, will be favoured over the other states in the allocation of funding for the centres. The cooperative multimedia centres were announced as part of the government's Creative Nation statement. It stated that the courses provided by tertiary institutions, while they included first rate computing and media courses, were not well tailored to multimedia. The government's reaction to this has been to seed the development of six cooperative multimedia centres over the next two years.

As with all this government's policies in higher education, this one `hit a pothole' to quote Guy Healey in the higher education supplement which appeared in the Australian on Wednesday 30 August of this year. Only two of the 18 consortiums which have put in bids to run cooperative multimedia centres have succeeded. Accordingly, a second bidding round is to begin immediately to try to choose four more consortiums to be funded.

The government is currently under fire from many sectors of the community for its conduct of policies in this area. It is just typical of the way in which it has constantly struck problems by its ill thought out approach to initiatives and its unwillingness to consult with the higher education sector. That is why it has run into difficulties in this area, as it has in so many others.

TALK.START.PARA: —I really found that was a ripper of a speech. This is from somebody who could not provide an example from between 1975 and 1983, when the coalition was in power, and who comes from Victoria, a state that is not known for any attitude towards education, higher or any other level.
—You must be joking. It has one of the best education records in the country.

—Eight thousand teachers sacked. Three hundred schools closed. That is a very good record! The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill amends the Higher Education Act 1988, which seems to be the one that has got up the nose of the shadow minister. Modern communications technology is playing a rapidly expanding role in the education and training sector. The amendments in this bill are aimed mainly at ensuring that the new technologies enhance the government's main objectives for the higher education system. These objectives, as outlined by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Elliott), are to build a large, accessible, diverse and innovative higher education system in which the new technologies enhance the learning experience and open new opportunities for participation in it by more and more Australians.

PARA.TAB: The bill does this principally by expanding the open learning initiative and providing for the new cooperative multimedia centres. It also enhances provision for universities to offer student places funded jointly with industry—I notice that was not mentioned by the shadow minister—improves the operation of the HECS scheme and makes additional minor policy and technical amendments changes.

The two main elements of the open learning initiative are the Open Learning Agency of Australia and the open learning electronic support service, Open Net. Students of the Open Learning Agency of Australia can utilise the teaching and learning assistance provided by Open Net. This allows students to communicate with tutors and other students in new and innovative ways. For example, they can use E-mail and bulletin boards and access electronic library services and information resources through the Internet. In these ways, the Open Net service benefits students and enhances the accessibility of educational services. I note that the shadow minister did not mention anything about that.

This bill extends the Open Net service to new bodies including TAFEs and schools, thereby extending access to the new national education network of Australia. EdNA provides a service link to link schools, TAFEs, universities and other education and training providers. It has the potential to promote equity in educational opportunity. It is part of a broader national strategy to adopt new information and communications services and technologies, the so-called information superhighway. It will stimulate the use of electronic networks by students and teachers and it will assist in the development of an internationally competitive education and training services industry. The expansion of the coverage of Open Net means that the benefits of the new technology are available to more and more Australians.

But while the federal government is expanding the education system and creating opportunities for Australians to participate, what is this opposition actually doing? So far, it is simply refusing to put their policies up for public scrutiny, refusing to tell the nation what they have in mind. But we on this side of the House all have a fair idea of what their general approach would be from looking at the record of their counterparts in the states. That shows that, while the federal government is creating opportunity, state Liberal governments all over this nation are quashing opportunity.

We need look no further, for example, than our own home state of South Australia and the actions of the Brown Liberal government. That government's assault—it is an assault—on resources allocated for education has continued this year with further drastic funding cuts. Hundreds of teachers and school service officers have been lost. Our once excellent student-teacher ratio has been attacked and retention rates have fallen from 93 per cent in 1993 to 76 per cent in 1994. That is a pretty dramatic and damaging decline. This year, a further 4,000 students have left the education system.

This is a pretty clear demonstration of the Liberals' lack of commitment to education. This is a pretty clear demonstration of the Liberals' failure to grasp the link between a strong education system and the building of a modern, efficient economy. I am sure that later in this debate my colleagues the member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) and the member for Corinella (Mr Griffin) will certainly emphasise the situation in Victoria.

It is not only the schools which have suffered. Despite the fact that full-time jobs for school leavers are in decline as a result of the revolution that has occurred in the economy and the labour market, the Brown Liberal government in South Australia has abandoned the youth strategy project. I find that amazing in light of the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) asking the question he did in question time today. Youth programs delivered by TAFE in South Australia have been savaged. Especially revealing was the abolition of a number of positions for Aboriginal people in DETAFE project officers who were able to cater for the particular needs of young, unemployed Aborigines.

Across the country, retention rates have risen from three in 10 in 1983 to eight in 10 today. This is in itself very clear evidence of the commitment of successive federal and state Labor governments to creating an accessible education system. This is important not only for the sake of students. The foundation of a successful world economy is a successful, world class education system which provides the economy with the skills base it needs. This is particularly important in these times of rapid technological change. It is a point that ought to be taken by some people in our universities.

The bill also provides a statutory framework for the cooperative multimedia centres. Up to six cooperative multimedia centres will be funded over the next two years. The cooperative multimedia centre program was announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in the cultural policy statement Creative Nation in October last year. The main aim of the cooperative multimedia centre is to foster the development of a competitive and internationally successful Australian multimedia industry that will serve to link the education and training sectors and the industrial and creative communities and encourage cooperation in research and development, product distribution, management of intellectual property and sharing of access to equipment and facilities.

These centres will support multimedia skill development, assist in the production and distribution of multimedia products for domestic consumption and for export, and accelerate the uptake of multimedia within education and training centres. They will complement the government's new open learning electronic support service in providing a national electronic infrastructure for the delivery of education and training services to students in their homes, their workplaces and community based facilities.

Interactive multimedia is a very new force in education, art, culture and service. It has the potential to become the biggest information business in the world. With the establishment of cooperative multimedia centres, we can create a dynamic Australian multimedia industry which produces Australian content for both Australian and international consumers. This bill, therefore, provides a tremendous boost to our arts and technological industries, to people with ideas and offers the opportunity for those ideas to be actually realised. The cooperative multimedia centres will enable the education and training sector to do its own job better and more cost effectively, while also providing an important platform for the development of a major new export industry.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I am sure you will agree with me that we hope that one of the six new cooperative multimedia centres will be in Adelaide. I have previously written to the government requesting that Adelaide be seriously considered as a site. It is particularly needed, given that the Brown Liberal government is in the process of closing the state down.

South Australians are now subject to the worst unemployment and the worst economic growth figures in the nation. It is an absolute disgrace. Between the December 1993 election and June 1995 the rate of job growth was one-third of what was achieved nationally. In June this year there were 3,000 fewer South Australians in work, compared with an increase of 52,000 on a national basis. Yet, Mr Deputy Speaker—and I know you are holding your eyes down—despite running the state down, and despite creating this misery, the Liberal government in South Australia has attacked the education system. South Australia, as you and I both know—
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—The member for Port Adelaide should not in any sense suggest that the Deputy Speaker is participating in the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw that. I know you are very interested in education. South Australia once had the best education system in the nation. You and I would both agree on that. Today, after two years of the Brown government, we have become one of the worst resourced education systems in Australia. The education minister, Mr Lucas, who, in the election campaign, promised increased funds for schools and training, will have chopped $100 million out of the education budget by 1996. The TAFE system is being similarly gutted, despite the desperate need for educational and training facilities in the most depressed state in the country. Locating a cooperative multimedia centre in Adelaide will go some way towards counteracting the damage that the Brown Liberal state government is inflicting on South Australia.

PARA.TAB: Another important aspect of this bill is that it provides for greater flexibility to institutions of higher education to fit in with the needs of industry—a point that seems to be grossly overlooked by the shadow minister. It is consistent with the government's overall strategy of encouraging a productive liaison between the two sectors in order to create a modern work force for a modern economy. To encourage this, the joint Commonwealth/industry funded additional places scheme was established in the 1991 budget as a partnership between the government and industry to provide additional places in higher education. This scheme has undoubtedly been a great success.

This bill also includes an amendment with respect to HECS fees to provide for greater flexibility for institutions and industry partners. The aim is to give institutions discretion in deciding whether places offered will be HECS liable or not—and that was a point that the shadow minister did not emphasise—without any loss to HECS revenue. The end result will be that institutions will have greater flexibility in providing courses at times and under arrangements that are more suited to the needs of industry. Again, that point was certainly not mentioned by the shadow minister. In fact, when we come down to it, there were not too many valid points offered at all.

The federal government's record on education is proven. It has demonstrated a commitment to a higher education system that ensures that all Australians have the opportunity to participate. Since 1983, it has increased funding from $3 billion to $5 billion—a 65 per cent increase. Student numbers have increased from 350,000 to 600,000. That is remarkable growth in anybody's language. It is a pity that it is not acknowledged by many on the other side of this chamber. It is interesting to note that only the shadow minister is speaking on behalf of the opposition in this debate.

The government will also create an additional 40,000 places in TAFE each year—funding which is additional to, not at the expense of, higher education sector funding. Mr Deputy Speaker, I am sure that both you and I realise that TAFE has a very important part to play in providing the skills and the job readiness for our young people.

The government has made a substantial investment in the higher education sector because it recognises the central role that universities play in the intellectual, economic and social development of the nation. It is Labor's commitment to education that has doubled the probability of a student completing year 12 and going on to higher education. It is Labor that created a decade of expansion of education opportunity, thereby increasing opportunity for individuals, lifting our economic performance and providing the skills and the flexibility needed in our modern emerging economy.

By stark contrast, the opposition has demonstrated no such commitment to education. When the opposition left government in 1983, seven out of 10 young Australians left the education system without completing high school. It was a neglect—almost a criminal neglect—which left too many people vulnerable to the changing needs of the economy as it modernised. Now the opposition's colleagues in state governments are repeating the same policies; they are quashing opportunity rather than enhancing opportunity—Brown in South Australia, Kennett in Victoria, Court in Western Australia, Groom in Tasmania, Stone in the Northern Territory and formerly Fahey in New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —Goss in Queensland.

—I am glad you mentioned Queensland. Good on you. Good one. The Labor government in Queensland is the only government in this country that has increased funding to education other than the Commonwealth.
—And retention rates are falling.

—You simply fail to grasp that education is a very critical aspect in the development of a modern, efficient economy. We have plenty of examples on the other side of the House. When anything to do with education and young people arises in question time or debate it is met with a derisive yawn; it is taken as an opportunity to turn around and have a yarn to the person next to you. Those opposite have no interest in these matters whatsoever. There are a few splendid examples, but not enough.

PARA.TAB: At the last election the federal opposition had a policy on fees and vouchers for funding universities, arguing that if we allow overseas students to pay for places, we should let Australian students pay for places. This time around, however, the opposition claims that it will not charge up-front fees to undergraduate students. But is the opposition against fees on the principled grounds of equity or access? No way! That would not surprise anyone on this side of the House. The opposition is not on about access and equity. The opposition has espoused no philosophical objection to up-front fees, but instead is arguing quite consistently that fees cannot be justified at the moment because of the stabilisation in the number of students. That is an interesting comment, isn't it, particularly when the shadow minister made the point about 23,000 students who cannot get into university—most of whom would choose TAFE, or deferment, or a whole range of other options. How very convenient!

Knowledge, as we all know, comes out of the head and not the mouth. But when it comes to intellect on that side of the House; when it comes to education, and particularly higher education, we can expect shallowness, we can expect lack of substance, we can expect lack of courage and we can expect a blank intellectual nadir.

All that proves is that the opposition will say anything in the lead-up to the next poll to mask its true policy positions. That is not new. That is exactly what the Liberals did in South Australia in the lead-up to the last state poll. The Liberals promised to increase spending on education. Two years later, the Liberals have savaged spending on education. A similar about-face on up-front fees can be expected of the federal opposition should it unfortunately win the next poll. The opposition has not given any real commitments to the higher education area. It is promising nothing to the future students of this country. It does not support equitable access to education and it does not support growth in the higher education sector.

Judging by the record of the Liberal Party in the states, it still fails to grasp the link between education and the nation's economic performance. It does not support student organisations either, a fact amply demonstrated by the recent actions of Liberal state governments in seeking to interfere with the ability of institutions to receive financial assistance for student organisations—actions, by the way, which were to the detriment of higher education services generally.

An opposition victory at the next federal poll would result in a dismantling of educational values and set back the modernising and reskilling of Australia's work force. They would make the same savage cuts to the education and training sectors as have been made by their counterparts in the states. They would chop opportunity rather than expand it, and they would turn students out of the education system rather than fund the future.

I believe Australians deserve better. People on this side of the House believe all Australians deserve better. That is why this bill is important. It is important because it promotes the use of leading edge technologies in the education and training sectors. It provides additional flexibility in the already closer relationship between institutions of higher education and industry. I commend the bill to the House. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffin Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are tonight debating the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1995, which provides for policy, technical and transitional amendments to the Higher Education Funding Act 1988. The bill makes amendments to the act to adjust funding for operating grants to reflect the major research facilities program and to provide supplementation of grants for price movements in respect of superannuation expenses, teaching hospitals and special capital projects; to amend funding amounts in section 22A to reflect the rollover of funding for the Open Learning initiative from 1994 and 1995 into 1995 and 1996 respectively; and to provide for the extension of the Open Learning initiative. Under the extension of the Open Learning initiative, new bodies which could be funded include TAFEs and schools. This new provision is conditional on the new bodies providing teaching and learning assistance which accords with national tertiary education priorities.

PARA.TAB: The bill will also provide a statutory framework for the cooperative multimedia centres program and introduce funding amounts. The cooperative multimedia centres—CMC—program was announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in his cultural policy statement Creative Nation on 18 October 1994. To foster developments in multimedia, the government will see the development of up to six CMCs over the next two years. The CMCs will be collaborative enterprises between the education and training centres and other public and private organisations. They will facilitate the provision of multimedia education and training. They will also encourage cooperation in areas such as research and development, product distribution and management of intellectual property and sharing of access to physical infrastructure.

The bill will also provide HECS exemption for students occupying places under the joint Commonwealth-industry funded additional places scheme. At present all JCFAP places are HECS liable. The HECS census dates place some restrictions on institutions' ability to run programs using JCFAP places. The amendment will give institutions the discretion to decide whether places offered would be HECS liable or not.

Under existing program arrangements, the Commonwealth contributes 60 per cent of the cost of a place and industry the remaining 40 per cent. Approximately 20 per cent of the cost is returned to the Commonwealth by way of HECS. Under the new arrangements, institutions would have the discretion to deem students HECS exempt where employers pay 60 per cent of the cost of the place. In such cases the Commonwealth would require institutions to remit the equivalent of the HECS charge. As a consequence there would be no net loss of HECS revenue.

The bill also removes references to `appropriate officer of the institutions' from subsection 43(3). This amendment gives effect to an Australian Taxation Office policy decision so that it will no longer be possible for an application for a tax file number by a student to be lodged with an officer of an institution.

The bill will also change the reference to TAFE in the definition of `course of study'—section 3. The definition of `course of study' has been amended to remove the need for a declaration by the minister that the course is a course of technical and further education. This amendment is required as higher education institutions which deliver TAFE award courses appear to be in breach of the conditions of their funding under the act in the charging of fees.

The bill also will enable a secretary or delegate to alter or vary a decision in relation to remission of HECS debt once an appeal has been lodged with the AAT. In recent appeals to the AAT, applicants have provided additional documentation supporting their claim for remission which was not available at the time a decision was made by the secretary.Had the documentation been made available, the applicant's debt would have been remitted. Advice from the Office of the Australian Government Solicitor, New South Wales, acting for DEET in relation to a case before the AAT, indicated that the secretary has no power under the act to issue a further decision once the matter is before the AAT. This amendment allows the secretary to alter or vary a decision on remission of HECS debt once an appeal has been lodged with the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
Lastly, the bill provides a technical amendment to section 110 and various consequential and transitional provisions related to the amendments.

As is often the case in this place, it is once again a matter of altering and updating legislation to ensure that it takes into account current circumstances and that the system continues to improve. The legislation supports that improvement.

There are two particular issues about the bill that I would like to touch on briefly: open learning and cooperative multimedia centres. The first stage of an education information superhighway—a $1.4 million pilot program of the federal government's Open Learning Electronic Support Service—was launched in Adelaide by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) on 14 September. The press release on that day states:

SPEECH.PARA: Around 140 Open Learning students will participate in the OLESS pilot project, using personal computers in their homes or visiting local access points at Open Learning Centres across Australia. The number of students is expected to rise to over 300 with the pilot's second stage in December.

"The Federal Government is prepared to commit up to $10 million for the full implementation of OLESS. Once OLESS is fully operational in March, Open Learning students will be able to dial into the network from home or office using a wide range of personal computers. In the future these services will be extended into the school and vocational education sectors."

OLESS will not be a direct supplier of services but will act as a broker. In that way it will be able to take advantage of both market forces and technological changes to put together the best possible package of services and support for students.
That system is now being called Open Net, which I think is a more appropriate title for it.

PARA.TAB: With respect to cooperative multimedia centres, which the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) and the shadow minister, the member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), touched on earlier, two of the six proposed cooperative multimedia centres have been announced and a process is under way for the consideration of further applications for an additional four. The hope is that that assessment process will be reporting back by December and that we will have an announcement from the government about the additional four sites. One in Western Australia and one in New South Wales have been okayed. I am certainly keen to see Victoria be successful in the next round of applications. I am confident that the Victorian bids will be in a position to be successful by that time, and I hope that will be the result of the consideration of the assessment panel. The university facilities and the range of companies in that area in Victoria are very well placed to take action on this matter and to make the initiative successful.

Both initiatives are also part of the development which is occurring on a continuing basis in higher education. I started at the Australian National University, just down the road, some 15 years ago. When I go to universities now to look around, I see that things have changed a lot. For one thing, the number of students going through the institutions is significantly higher than it was in my day; that was under the Fraser government. The level of technology required to maximise the capacity for the population to learn has also changed dramatically in that time with the use of computers and the Internet. A whole range of modern technological services is now available.

It is very important that the government is active in ensuring that we are at the cutting edge of these new technologies and that we maximise the benefits. These technologies also open up a range of other opportunities in terms of distance education which were not around in years gone by. Over time, that will ensure that access to higher education services is greatly expanded. This government has also been committed to expansion through the higher education sector in more conventional terms.

In my local area just over 12 months ago I was happy to represent the government at the opening of the proposal for the Berwick campus of Monash University—the day my seat was abolished. On that occasion, it was very pleasing to speak to people like the Vice-Chancellor of Monash University about the plans that were held for that site, the hope that we would be seeing through that development the expansion of higher education services into the south-eastern growth corridor. The scope of possibilities for developments at that site was practically endless. I know that opportunities for similar developments were also being investigated regarding Cranbourne, which is in my electorate. Again, this new technology can allow, through computer terminals and other facilities, the development of services in areas that, on questions of economies of scale, would not be able to adequately justify major capital works expenditure.

I think that has been one of the successes of the government over the last 12 years. In education, as in many other areas, we have been able to identify the challenges of the future and address them. We have not always got it right, but we have certainly always endeavoured to get it right. We have been more successful than most, and certainly more successful than our predecessors, with respect to identifying the trends of the future in order to ensure that we address those needs as time goes by.

Since this government has come to power, we have doubled the number of students going through from year 12 to university—from some 15 per cent to 30 per cent. Also, we have expanded by 65 per cent in real terms the amount of money put into universities—from $3 billion to $5 billion in constant prices—and student numbers have increased from 350,000 to 600,000. So I do not think we can accept the argument that we are not addressing the issue of higher education. The amount of change that has occurred in the sector has been quite dramatic, and those circumstances have been difficult for the university sector to cope with. But they certainly have approached it with some rigour and with some innovation.

As a former union official in the tertiary education sector back in the mid-1980s, I know that there needed to be changes. There was enormous scope for improvements and productivity increases within the higher education sector and in the university sector. Something certainly needed to be done. Although I do not agree with all of the so-called Dawkins reforms in some respects, I do think that they were and are heading in the right direction. They are leading to a capacity to handle greater numbers of students, which is the situation that we face today. Those circumstances are not likely to go away. The fact is that, with new technology in terms of employment and with increased access to education, people will want to take up those opportunities and they will want their children to take up those opportunities.

This government has not just worked on the question of the higher education sector in the narrow sense of the university sector. In terms of TAFE and the university sector, we have endeavoured to develop a more vocational orientation regarding higher education services. We have put massive investment into those areas. We have endeavoured to do so more and more often in consultation with the sector and industry. In doing that, we have maximised our bang for our buck. We maximised the results in terms of the skills acquired, and we maximised the opportunity for people who go through those courses to gain employment at the end of the day.

When we look at this issue, we have to look at our opposition. We heard earlier from the member for Goldstein the problems that he saw with this bill and with the development of the higher education sector. Once again, it was fairly long on criticism but not much in terms of constructive criticism. It was mainly the usual complaints that the government is not doing enough. It did not address what a Liberal opposition would do if it were to gain government. It could be an academic exercise for some higher education institution to look at the opposition's lack of policies, where they are hiding them and what they would do if they were in government.

When we look at the last election, the Liberals went to the campaign on a policy of fees and vouchers for funding universities. The justification then was, `If we allow overseas students to pay for places, why do we not let our own students pay for places?' I do not see the point to that. Maybe that was a while ago, and maybe things have changed, but you still have to wonder.
The policies announced by the Liberal Party do not tell us very much at all. In the Australian of 23 February this year, the situation was summed up as follows:
The Liberal Party, however, has been without a semblance of a higher education policy since the sinking of the voucher scheme . . .

SPEECH.PARA: I also note that between 1976 and 1981, when the coalition was in government, the total resources available to higher education institutions fell every year. So you have to question whether they are fair dinkum when they say that they are going to address the problems that they see in the system if they get into government.

PARA.TAB: When the shadow minister says that more needs to be done, you have to wonder how he will actually do it. If it is not full fees and not a voucher system, how will he do it? From some of the scant detail that we have heard with respect to coalition policies, we know that they are about cutting government expenditure. We know that the only area they have nominated with respect to that issue has been that of Working Nation. But I am not aware of any commitments with respect to increased funding for higher education. We have not heard them saying that they will address this issue with funds that are required.

Again, we have to look at their policies in the past. They have consisted of fees and vouchers. We have to look at their performance in government. That basically consisted of cuts on a regular basis in terms of funding provided to the university sector. We have to ask why they are not coming clean with their policies and when they will do so. We also have to look at the circumstances with respect to a number of state education systems at the moment and the actions of conservative governments. As a member from Victoria, I can say to the House that the Kennett government's actions on education have been quite horrific. I can also say that we did not know about that before the election. The Victorian public was not told what was going to happen.

The Kennett government has now closed over 200 schools throughout the state. To be fair, they have not worried about where they have closed the schools in terms of their constituencies; they have closed them all over the place. They have closed rural schools and metropolitan schools. They have closed them in safe conservative suburbs and in safe Labor areas. They have closed them in more established areas, and in newer areas they have not opened anywhere near the amount that is required.

We also have to look at class sizes in schools. Class sizes in Victoria are going up. The justification for that was that we had a better than national average position. Maybe that explains why we have a better than national average rate of retention, a better than national average pick-up of students entering the university sector. Class sizes have gone up, and that is having an impact on education levels. Support services have also been affected. A range of programs has been cut, which has meant that support services to kids who may have a particular need are disappearing, and they are not being replaced. Similarly, where student organisations have had an organised focus for dissent, the Victorian government has endeavoured to stop it and to cut the funding.

So under the previous conservative government, funding was cut. They have not really got a policy now. The last policy they had was for full fees and voucher systems. In Victoria, in South Australia—as mentioned by the member for Port Adelaide—in Western Australia and in Tasmania, conservative governments have clamped down on education expenditure generally and have degraded the value of their education system and therefore the result that has on their students. We have to wonder how seriously we can take what has been said by the opposition and the shadow minister with respect to what they will do in the area of education. We have to wonder how serious they are when they shed crocodile tears about what they see with respect to access and people missing out. We have to wonder about their actions in the Senate in relation to the proposed changes in legislation by the government which, if blocked, will lead to a loss of places across Australia. We have to wonder what that really means.

This government has a proud record in terms of higher education expenditure. We have delivered on a range of promises that we have made over a number of years in that field. We have increased student numbers, built new universities and increased expenditure on a regular basis throughout our term in government. And the result has been a better education system.

It is an education system which still needs to improve because the circumstances we face in 1995 versus those in 1975 or 1980 are very different. They are circumstances that need innovative developments such as those mentioned earlier in terms of open learning and the cooperative multimedia centres. We need to maximise the use of that technology in circumstances which make it available to the people who need it. We need to ensure there is equity in placement in higher education places and that universities continue to grow and develop their acts around improving their position in terms of providing the services that are urgently needed by the young of this country. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Connor Mr G.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me a great deal of pleasure to support the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1995. I would like at this stage to pay tribute to the contributions of the honourable member for Corinella (Mr Griffin) and the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford). Both those members on this side of the House have had a long-standing interest in educational issues and affairs. It is good to see the quality of their contribution to this debate.

PARA.TAB: This bill is important in several respects. It builds upon the broad and continuing commitment of the government to higher education in Australia. It does that by providing additional resources to ensure that higher educational institutions in Australia are equipped to provide quality tertiary education to all Australians who seek it.

It also provides resources to mount new initiatives in the education and technology areas. I do not think there would be any member in this House who does not agree with the proposition that Australia must enter this zone very quickly, and with resources and skills, if we are to maintain our position in global terms as a nation which puts a very high priority on the education of its citizens and a society that acknowledges the central position of education to its long-term competitiveness.

I commend the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) for the measures that have been introduced by the government. We know of the minister's long-standing commitment to education and training. That is being matched by the resources that the government has provided to these areas.

Rather than canvassing all the elements of the bill—they are covered in the second reading speech—I would like to refer to a couple of initiatives that relate to the use, further development and application of new technologies in tertiary education in Australia. The information society is really upon us. I think we all acknowledge that. We are in the middle of a revolution but I am not quite sure all of us fully understand.

I can recall from my younger days my father expressing some exasperation at the new technologies he had to come to terms with as a dairy farmer in the western district of Victoria. It was not only in the area of earning his income; it was in his household and in his daily life. He used to muse very much about where society was heading with the introduction of these new technologies. I can recall in my very formative years milking the cows by hand. Then came the economic decision for the family to introduce milking machines to the farm enterprise. Our farm was not large enough to sustain the capital expenditure that was required and we were restructured out of that industry, you might say.

I can recall even in the home the new technologies that were being introduced. We never had television. I used to wait with breathless anticipation before the big radio screens that we had in those days. They were rather large radio consoles. My father explained television to me, saying there would be moving pictures coming upon the screen. I used to gaze at the radio console, waiting for the images to appear—they never did. My father had a problem coming to terms with the technology that changed the way he went about earning his living and changed his lifestyle. In a sense, I am in that same position today, as are all members of this House and all members of society. The information and technology revolution is proceeding at a pace which is changing the way that we earn our living and is changing the way that we live our lives.

As I said at the beginning of my remarks, I am not quite sure that we fully understand the momentous changes that are upon us. Yet, we have the means to understand those momentous changes. The means are here in a sophisticated educational infrastructure and in the technologies that are at our disposal now as Australians. One of the great tasks in our modern industrial economy is to bring together those two aspects of education and the use of technologies to ensure that our children do have a well developed understanding of the changes that are taking place around them. Indeed, it is a hard race to run. My son tears his hair out at his father's incapacity to come to terms with what he regards as the very simplest of technologies; but I do try and I am learning all the time.

It is very important that governments appreciate the depth of the struggle that ordinary Australians are having in coming to terms with the new technologies and that they ensure that adequate resources are made available to the whole community to ensure that nobody downs tools and nobody loses heart in the quest to get on top of these new technologies. The information society presents us with great challenges as a society. I have mentioned the economic challenge. The use of new technologies in industry is going to be one means by which we retain and improve our international competitiveness. Technology may be easy to adapt in many workplaces, but we have to understand not only its economic significance but also its social and cultural significance.

Great social questions are raised by the information age and the advances in new technology. It is those social questions that the government seeks to answer by providing the resources that it does in this bill and in the programs that this government funds. There is the all important question of equity and access to these new information technologies. How do we live and organise our lives? Will we really understand and be able to manipulate these new technologies to our benefit?

As a government, we have a responsibility to ensure that we redistribute income in this country, as best we can, to give everybody a shot at this title. I am sad to say that, at some levels of government, that understanding is not there. The equity argument is not understood and does not make its way into the programs of certain state governments that have been referred to here by the member for Port Adelaide and the member for Corinella. There are also cultural questions which are raised by the advent of the information society. How do we preserve our national identity? How do we ensure that the particular quirks of our language are retained?
These are very important considerations. Of course, the more our young people understand these technologies the more they will be able to forge a national identity of their own over time.

The new technology poses significant challenges to our national identity. We see that amongst our young people today in the computer games that they play, the language used in those particular games and the way in which our young people mimic the fashion trends that originate elsewhere. As a community we face the challenge of really providing the resources to our young people to understand these technologies and their applications and in some way preserve that great national identity that we have been able to forge here since Federation.

The greatest legacy we can leave our children and our young people is to resource the infrastructure necessary for them to make their way in the new information age. The greatest gift we can give them is the skill and confidence to utilise these new technologies and the expansion of the information base, and to ensure that they exert some measure of control and dominance over these extraordinary developments that are now shaping their lives. That is what this bill is about, essentially. It is about governments stepping into this ring and guiding that understanding, making sure that adequate resources are provided so that Australians can access the new technologies.

The key to this, of course, is education. This government has done more than any other government in our postwar history to provide a program focus and resources to ensure that Australians have that education and that access to new technologies and will be able through that to exert control over these technologies. In a very real sense, the measures contained in this bill are designed to do this.

As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Elliott) mentioned in his speech, the bill will provide for an extension of the Open Learning initiative. It is through this particular initiative that we are overcoming the tyranny of distance. Our past economic performance very much depended on the way in which we moved goods around this nation in an efficient manner. We are still coming to terms with creating better efficiencies in those areas. But to overcome the tyranny of the new technology and the tyranny of distance, it is most important that national governments play a very constructive role in opening up access for its population to the new technologies. We are doing this through the Open Learning initiative.

One important element of the Open Learning initiative is the Open Learning electronic support service—Open Net—which will provide technical and learning assistance to students enrolled under this Open Learning initiative. Open Net will assist students by allowing them to communicate with other students across the length and breadth of Australia. It will allow them to communicate directly with their tutors by E-mail through the transfer of assignments, bulletin boards, accessing electronic library services and accessing other information resources such as the Internet. It is the government's intention that Open Net will be expanded into a broader educational network.

When you pin it all down, this particular initiative, Open Net, has very simple objectives: to maximise the use of new technologies in education to open up their access to all Australians and, most importantly, to provide affordable access. I do not think we ponder enough on this particular point. It is no use providing resources in this area unless they are affordable and accessible to all Australians. Of course, another primary objective of the Open Net is to increase the quality of learning experiences to Australians.

Other provisions in this bill provide funding in a statutory framework for the cooperative multimedia centres. These came out of the Creative Nation document which acknowledged the need to create a dynamic multimedia industry in this country.

I had a very interesting experience shortly after I was elected as a member of Corio. I got a call from a man who operated a small business in a suburb called Norlane in my electorate. He said that he was developing some new initiatives utilising the multimedia technology and asked me whether I would come out and see it. I said, `I will come out but I will go one better. I will bring the minister for small business, Chris Schacht, out to see you as well'—I had the minister visiting the electorate.

It was a most interesting experience because the enterprise that we visited was contained in two houses side by side that the owner had converted to this purpose. I did not know a lot about multimedia technology at that time. We went inside where about five young people were working on a project to produce electronic multimedia games for the international market. It was most intriguing to observe the skills that they were bringing to bear on this task. They did the whole graphic presentation of the game and the musical score and they produced a whole lot of ancillary materials associated with this game. They were seeking a very small amount of money to fund the production on this game on a commercial basis and launch it on the domestic and international markets.

Unfortunately, Creative Nation was not in place some 18 months or two years ago, or else this enterprise, I am sure, would have been up and running and would have been at the leading edge of these developments. When we sat down and analysed the assistance that we could bring to bear on the task, we found that we were unable to help from a government point of view. So we put these entrepreneurs in touch with private developers who said, `It is too risky.'

Some 18 months later, I spoke to the entrepreneur and asked him how he went with developing the game. He said, `I had to unload it to a British firm for $120,000 to pay our debts.' I said, `I guess something is better than nothing.' He said, `Well, it all had a street value of $1.2 million and that's what we missed.' This highlights the fact that this government has seized the times in providing resources to develop these technologies. All right, this one did not get up, but others will.

In my own electorate Deakin University is at the forefront of the utilisation of the new technologies in the information age and in education. In 1995, Deakin University was declared the university of the year. It is quite a unique university. It operates three campuses in Melbourne and two in regional areas located in Geelong and Warrnambool. With the assistance of better cities money provided by the federal government, the university will be shortly moving into a new developed campus in the Deakin wool stores in the centre of Geelong.

Deakin University won this title as the 1995 University of the Year against the intense competition of some 38 universities. The award acknowledges Deakin's national leadership in enhancing undergraduate education through imaginative and innovative uses of new information and communication technologies. When the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) presented the award, he said this about the university:

SPEECH.PARA: Deakin is an unconventional university, but a good one.

When the student can't come to the university, Deakin takes the University to the student. Deakin students work from mines and factories and offices, as well as from classrooms and lecture theatres, but through the use of computers and e-mail and faxes and printed materials, they engage in the dialogue that is the hallmark of the traditional university education.
I am proud to say that a university in my electorate leads the way in the use of the new technologies in higher education in Australia. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I start by drawing the attention of the House to an error contained in the 1995 limit of funds available for schemes listed in section 23C of the Higher Education Funding Act 1988, which is amended by item 10 of the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1995. The correct limit of total funds available for certain grants for the year 1995 should be $441,397,000 as contained in the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995, which will be debated later this week.

PARA.TAB: I need only comment on the contribution of the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp). To start, I should put the bill in its broader perspective, which is to meet the objectives of the government's higher education policy. In that regard, the objectives are the government's commitment to an accessible, diverse, innovative and publicly funded system of higher education. To the extent that those objectives are there, this bill seeks to address them in four ways. Those four ways are the cooperative multimedia centres, Open Learning Australia, improvements to the joint Commonwealth-industry funded additional places, and the major national facilities fund.

The honourable member for Goldstein obviously likes the provisions of the bill because he did not seek to speak about them at any length. He sought to criticise government policy generally. He has that luxury, because there is a government policy on education. This government is very proud that it is a government that has policies. We have Working Nation, Creative Nation and our education policies.

The opposition have no policies. They are so devoid of policy in the area of education that even their friends in the media have seen fit to run editorials criticising them for their complete lack of policy. No opposition in the world would have the courage to not have a policy, but we have found one in this country. This opposition have been so scared by their previous electoral experiences that they now wish to run in an election without telling the Australian people any details of their policies. They are making general, nice cooing noises about what they might do or not do. They will not be allowed to get away with that.

The honourable member for Goldstein will eventually be brought to the bar of the House and forced to disgorge what policies, if any, the opposition has. In the meantime, he wants the luxury of criticising what the government does without ever being prepared to put anything constructive before the Australian people.

He has chosen to criticise the government for its successful policy. He referred, quite rightly, to the massive increases in funding under this government in the area of education. It does not hurt to remind the House and the Australian people of those increases. The total number of students in higher education has increased from 348,000 in 1983 to 585,000 in 1995. That is something like a 68 per cent increase. That is a very significant figure and something of which Australians can be proud. As I travel overseas, I find that other countries are amazed by our performance in this regard.

The honourable member for Goldstein referred to the 23,000 students that were unable to gain a place in higher education this year. They are, of course, his figures. He has totally ignored and does not want to even admit the government's initiatives in addressing the problems of unmet demand. A further 11,000 places were announced in the recent budget. Those places are unfortunately in jeopardy because of the actions of the honourable member for Goldstein and his friends in another place who are seeking to amend the budget legislation that is to be debated tomorrow. Because of this opposition ineptitude and their failures in the democratic process, the budget bill is in danger of losing $20 million per year, which means that 2,000 young Australians who would otherwise get places in higher education will not do so if this is the case. I only hope that the Australian Democrats and the Greens can see what the opposition are doing in this regard.

The shadow spokesman, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill), is on record as saying that the opposition will not be proceeding with up-front fees. He does not have any policy. They used to have a policy of forcing university students to pay fees up front.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is untrue. That was never our policy.

—The honourable member for Goldstein, like many members of the opposition, having announced a policy and having publicly debated it, now wishes to deny the past. They want to deny the past and say, `That does not exist. We are nice guys now. We used to be the bad guys. We used to terrify the nation with our policies, but it's okay now. We are nice guys. This did not really happen. It was not us. It was somebody else.' But the fact is that they did have such a policy. They are now walking away from it. They are walking away from all policy initiatives.

PARA.TAB: The opposition's problem is that they have a number of spokespersons saying different things. Senator Hill says one thing and the honourable member for Goldstein says another. The honourable member for Goldstein criticises the government, for example, in the number of postgraduate awards available to students. These awards are competitive. It should be recognised that the number of higher degree students has grown under Labor by 172 per cent from 25,000 in 1987 to 68,000. Commonwealth expenditure in higher education has increased by 36 per cent from $3.1 billion in 1983 to $5.1 billion in 1995. All these things are happening and yet the carping critics are still there criticising away.

I should say a few words about the cooperative multimedia centres. The government has also announced a second round of these centres. The other submissions in their present form did not meet the guidelines laid down by the government. If we had funded them, we would have been in trouble with the Auditor-General about it. But we do have a policy of developing these centres. I think it is an excellent idea.

Open learning has increased the opportunities of Australians in rural and regional Australia. It has increased the opportunities of people at home. It has given people a taste of higher education in Australia. It has opened up all those opportunities for them and made higher education accessible. Under this government, we have a high quality, diverse higher education system of which all Australians can be proud. We have been able to export it as a product, so well regarded is that system throughout the world.

This system is taking advantage of innovative ideas and using technology to overcome the tyrannies of distance that we have always suffered in this country. We are using technology to overcome disadvantage and other barriers of access, disability, geographical location and work at home commitments that students might have. It is a system which has significantly extended opportunities for all Australians. It is an expansion which is being achieved without introducing fees for undergraduates. Australian undergraduate students do not pay for their education until they reach average weekly earnings. They do not pay up front, as was proposed by the opposition. If demand rises, it does not mean that—
Dr Kemp interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition, of course, has its agenda. We will not hesitate to tell the Australian people about its past agendas and allow them to infer what the opposition is going to be doing in the future. I think students need to be asking the opposition to identify their policies and to make them come clean—to come out and tell the Australian public what they are really proposing.

PARA.TAB: This is a small but very important bill. It shows that both the government and Australia are at the leading edge of higher education in the world. The bill contains a few measures that I think will go a long way towards improving higher education in this country, giving Australian students a much better deal and giving Australian technology a much needed boost as we compete in international economies. For all those reasons, I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.
Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Dr D.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Schedule, page 3, item 2, after paragraph (b) of the definition of co-operative multimedia centre, insert "and (c) research and development;".

SPEECH.PARA: I will not detain the House by speaking at length on this amendment. It is a commonsense amendment, which probably incorporates the intention of the government in its definition of cooperative multimedia centres. These bodies are established to relate to the multimedia industry for a whole variety of purposes, including arranging for and providing services relating to education and training. It did seem to us that, because the aim of these activities is to assist in the development of that industry, it would be a commonsense addition to the definition to insert as paragraph (c) the words `research and development'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment is indeed within the spirit and intent of the concept of cooperative multimedia centres. It is a commonsense addition, and the government supports it.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill (on motion by Mr Walker)—by leave—read a third time.
Motion (by Mr Walker) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —We often hear comments in this place about extreme organisations—in particular, the League of Rights and some of the groups of that type. I say to those opposite that, in the last few days, we on this side of the House have been beginning to wonder whether some members opposite really want to own up to being members of the ALP. To exemplify that, I noticed in the Toowoomba Chronicle—my local newspaper—only last week an ad which showed the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell). It was not an ALP ad; it was a League of Rights ad. I wonder once again whether the honourable member for Kalgoorlie is a member of the ALP in this government or, indeed, whether he is reinforcing his association with the League of Rights.

PARA.TAB: Tonight I quickly wanted to refer to another group. Yesterday, I got a statement from Craig Isherwood, who is the National Secretary of the Citizens Electoral Councils of Australia. I think this is just rubbishy, extreme stuff, but I think it is worth reading part of the statement into the Hansard record to show the degree to which some people will misrepresent information that is not correct. Mr Isherwood says in part:
I support the French nuclear tests as a matter of Australian National Sovereignty—

SPEECH.PARA: in itself a non sequitur. He goes on:

PARA.TAB: Given the sustained, almost infantile whingeing against the French nuclear tests by Prime Minister Paul Keating, and by many other influential voices in Australia, it is necessary that someone of authority in this country states some plain, if painful, truths on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I assume by that he means Craig Isherwood. He goes on:

PARA.TAB: Number one. The tests are indeed urgent to maintain French national security, in part given the unpredictable developments among nuclear-armed states of the former USSR.

SPEECH.PARA: What a load of rubbish! He has not understood that those tests could be done through computer simulation—a point that both the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) and the shadow foreign minister, the member for Mayo (Mr Downer), have been making for many weeks. He goes on:

PARA.TAB: Number two. The tests "pose no danger to humans and the environment" . . .

SPEECH.PARA: I just wonder whether he should reaffirm that to those people who live in the South Pacific. He continues:

PARA.TAB: Number three.

SPEECH.PARA: Here it comes:

The opposition to these tests is organised solely, and directly, by the British Crown, through Prince Philip's World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF), and its de facto subsidiaries, such as Greenpeace, and others grouped around the WWF of Australia and the Australian Conservation Foundation (ACF) . . . At issue is not only the nuclear tests, but Chirac's support for the American-led bombing campaign against Britain's Serbian clients in Bosnia.

PARA.TAB: Number four. The orchestrated hysteria around nuclear weapons, is used to argue against nuclear power for economic development. Without widespread, increasing use of nuclear power, much of this world is condemned to misery and death.

SPEECH.PARA: Towards the end of the statement he says:

PARA.TAB: The old Labor Party, under Curtin, Chifley, and even, despite some problematic social policies, Gough Whitlam, until he was dismissed by Queen Elizabeth II in 1975 for trying to "buy back the farm," were committed to a grand vision of economic development for Australia. A limitless future lay before all of her citizens, whether native-born, or from whatever war-torn corners of Europe and Asia they came.

SPEECH.PARA: He finishes off by saying:

PARA.TAB: But without high technology-driven economic development, there is no sovereignty. Thus, Australia finds herself today with the largest foreign debt per capita in the world—

SPEECH.PARA: I would tend to agree with that—
with little industry, a devastated rural sector, and with her vast raw materials deposits almost entirely owned by foreigners.
Another touchy point as far as a lot of people see it. He goes on:

PARA.TAB: So, when Jacques Chirac, the president of the world's oldest nation-state, speaks about sovereignty, Prime Minister Keating, Foreign Minister Evans, et al. would do well to stop flapping their jaws for a moment, and listen.
They might learn something of lasting benefit to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: He finishes his statement by saying:

The Citizens Electoral Councils (CEC) was founded in the state of Queensland in 1988. It is the fastest growing political party in the nation, and is allied to the international "peace through economic development" coalition associated with the American statesman, Lyndon H. LaRouche.
All I can say is what a load of rubbish. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree entirely with the comments of the member for Groom (Mr Taylor), only I do not think I would have bothered to give credibility to the statement by even referring to it. It really is a load of nonsense. We have heard a lot in this House in the last few days about opposition policy and where this country is going in policy terms. I come from the state of Victoria where, of course, a Liberal Party is in government. It is very easy in Victoria to find out exactly what the Liberal Party stands for. One has only to look at what Jeffrey Gibb Kennett and his colleagues are doing in Victoria, and we know exactly what we would get from a Liberal government led by Mr Howard.

PARA.TAB: Tonight I want to draw attention to the state of the Country Fire Authority in Victoria. No-one would argue that country fire authorities are very important in rural Australia. Indeed, many urban rural fire brigades are the sole fire protection authorities for many growing parts of metropolitan Melbourne. They are also staffed by volunteers and are a branch of the CFA in Victoria.

The Country Fire Authority, as we all know, both at the urban and CFA level is staffed primarily by volunteers. I do not think any Australian would say that there is a finer body of people—men and women—who do quite astonishing things when this country is ravaged by one of its common foes, fire. In New South Wales more recently than in Victoria, unfortunately, we saw the effect of fire and the enormous human cost both to property and life and the environment generally that these fires cause.

So these authorities are fundamentally important. As a Victorian I am awfully proud of the efforts that CFA has made in my electorate over a number of years. In their basic structure, the CFA have full-time professional officers, but the vast bulk of their organisation comes from volunteers. Without the full-time professional officers it is much more difficult to organise the volunteer fire fighters.

The economic rationalists of the Liberal Party—the sort we have here in Canberra—who are now in government in Victoria are cutting funds right across Victoria. There is no policy about what they do. They simply say, `In budget terms we take this money out of the system and then you people deliver the service. We don't care what you have to do but you must deliver the service.' There has been no discussion on policy and no consultation. They have simply taken the money away. They are taking money away from the Country Fire Authority and the authority's response to that is to start to make redundant—the usual Liberal Party term for sacking people: making them out of work—the full-time officers of the CFA.

So in Victoria we are going to have a situation where in urban fire brigades which currently have full-time fully paid officers who operate on a quick response time, who are the training officers and who maintain the equipment on a full-time basis, the officers will no longer be there. That immediately increases the response time. For example, Ernst and Whinney, one of the four major chartered accountants in Australia, indicated in a major study that that would cause an increase in the average response of four minutes to call-out. The average response would be 12 minutes. The increase would cost an enormous amount of money in terms of damage to a burning house. It would also endanger the occupants of that house. The risk of damage to people in a burning building would increase dramatically.

You have to wonder at the morality of a political party which would do this to such a major volunteer organisation. This is only one example of the sorts of things we are seeing in Victoria from the economic rationalists in the Liberal Party, driven not by social need or caring for the community but by the bottom line—the dollar. They are always driven by economic outcomes. They do not care if rural communities in Victoria are going to suffer increased damage by fire and increased costs to the community because of paltry savings of just over $1 million in relation to the CFA. When the Liberals and the National Party here talk about policy, we know what they stand for. We know what they will do. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I would like to express my outrage at the decision today by the Premier of Western Australia, Richard Court, to sell 100 per cent of the State Bank of Western Australia—Bankwest or the old R&I—to the Bank of Scotland. On a day when we see John Howard telling foreign investors at an MTIA seminar that they should continue to invest in Australia and then subsequently doing a stunt on foreign debt, Richard Court sells the R&I Bank, or Bankwest, to Edinburgh. Howard says that the Western Australian state government's policies are his model. This means that he will sell Telecom to any overseas telecommunication company.

PARA.TAB: I regard the sale of Bankwest to the Bank of Scotland as a great lost opportunity. It is a lost opportunity for Western Australia because it means the prospect, or the chance, of having a strong Western Australian regional bank is lost. That is as a result of the inability of the Premier of Western Australia, or his refusal, to achieve the best model for a regional bank in Western Australia—namely, to have effected a merger between Challenge Bank and Bankwest.

The failure to effect this best result for Western Australia is clearly the personal responsibility of Richard Court. It is unquestionably the case that a merger between Challenge and Bankwest has been opposed for whatever reason by management of Bankwest, particularly the former chairman, Mr Ross Garnaut, and the chief executive officer, Warwick Kent. But any premier worth his salt would have been able to override these management blinkered views and achieve a best result for Western Australia.

What we have now is the danger of having no effective Western Australian regional bank at all. That is a direct result of the lack of capacity of the Premier and the government of Western Australia to effect a merger between Bankwest and Challenge which has resulted in a proposed takeover by Challenge Bank of Westpac, which is subject to TPC consideration, and now the sale of Bankwest, or the old R&I, effectively to Edinburgh Castle.

It is interesting to draw attention to what some commentators and indeed the Premier himself have had to say. Today, when announcing the sale to the Bank of Scotland, the Premier of Western Australia said:

We are receiving a very good price for the bank but more than that we are going to end up with a strengthened financial institution in WA and not just being a branch operation of an eastern states' bank. . . .

SPEECH.PARA: It will end up being a post box for Edinburgh Castle. This stands in stark contrast to his comments to the Western Australian parliament on 3 May this year when he assured the state parliament, and I quote from the Hansard:
. . . no way would we want 100 percent overseas control of BankWest. We want the maximum level of Western Australian ownership.

The score is 100 Scotland: zero Western Australia. Previously commentators, when referring to the possible merger between Bankwest and Challenge, have spoken in the following terms: Stephen Bartholomeusz from the Age has said that the Challenge proposal ought to be `irresistible'. Ivor Ries from the Financial Review has said that the case for merging Challenge Bank and Bankwest was `compelling'. Brian Frith from the Australian has written that the bank merger would be a `beautiful fit'. Stephen Bartholomeusz said again in the Age that the merger of the two banks would produce substantial synergies but would minimise the risk of loss of market share that normally occurs in bank mergers. He stated:

It would create a $12 billion bank—about three times the size of Challenge—and would ensure that there weren't two WA institutions of modest size competing for the limited pool of funding and assets available.

The fact that this is a personal decision of Richard Court has been made clear by some of the writers on this matter. In the Australian Nigel Wilson has referred to the Western Australian Premier, Mr Court, as having personal control of Bankwest's destiny. In another article in the Australian he referred to Premier Court assuming responsibility for the bank privatisation process. In an article in the Financial Review recently, Ivor Ries wrote as follows:
. . . BankWest's management was cool on any association with Challenge. And WA Premier Richard Court refused to show any sense of commitment, forcing Challenge to find an alternative.
Mr Ries concluded by saying:
As Court has just discovered, the commercial world sometimes just can't wait for politicians to get up off their hands and do something.

I have never been able to understand the ideologically blinkered view of Dr Garnaut in his refusal to countenance a proper examination of a merger in this matter in the face of overwhelming evidence that it was in both the public interest and the state interest to do so. But it is almost criminal negligence on the part of the Premier of Western Australia to allow the set of circumstances to occur where there will be no effective regional bank for Western Australia and the old R&I will be sold to the Bank of Scotland. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Speaker, for giving me the call, particularly at a time when my children—Nicholas, aged eight, and Alexandra, aged six—are in the gallery along with my wife, Lyn. They are in Canberra during the Queensland school holidays. Yesterday I mentioned that this year once again I hosted the Fisher electorate essay competition. I read into the Hansard the winning essay from Fayleen Scherger, who won the secondary section. She is a year 11 student at the Abundant Life Christian School at Kingaroy.

PARA.TAB: Because of time constraints, it was not possible to read into the Hansard the winning primary essay. The winner was Amanda Watson-Brown of the Nanango State School. She is in year 7. The topic for the primary section was the same as the secondary section—that is, `How should governments treat families?' I would like to read the essay into the Hansard for the permanent record. She wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: Governments should be of the people, by the people and for the people. The question has been asked how should governments treat families. The answer should be treat them as you would treat your own family.

Society today accepts many definitions of what makes a family. As a member of an ordinary family, the problems we face would be the same as those faced by the majority of families. I think governments should give more help to small businesses and encourage people to be self sufficient. The average family has both parents working or attempting to work. Governments should be concerned with families as they are the backbone of society.

Bob Hawke, when he was in power said "no child would be living in poverty by the year 1990". This has not happened and many families are still struggling. No matter what party is in power and what promises they make children are the most important part of the family as they are this countries future citizen. Many children are still leaving home and living on the streets. Australia has the largest youth suicide rate in the world. Governments should give youth some hope for the future. Many times young people search and search for work. If there was more co-operation between employers, government and school, families would be happier.

John Howard (C.M. 7 June) stated that if he was elected his government would provide "A national child immunisation programme to achieve as close as possible to 100% immunisation." This would ensure that our children would be protected from preventable diseases. The hospitals in all states are overcrowded. We often hear of people not being able to get treatment at the big hospitals. If families had the choice of paying into a health care fund or paying the medicare levy, some of the problems would be solved. Many church groups are providing services that governments could provide from taxes collected.
