I have read a book called "Waiting for May" by Thyrza Davey. In this the problem arises when an elderly man wants to stay on his houseboat rather than go into a home. The social worker is trying to force him to go. Governments should provide the elderly with as much help as possible so they can stay in their own homes as long as is possible. Sometimes pensioners feel they would be better off not owning a home as they could get lots more help. Governments would make the elderly more happy if they thought of them and gave living assistance to all pensioners.

Many members of parliament get to know the people in their electorate. This makes people happy as they feel that the person they voted for is really working for them. That's the most important way governments should treat families. They should be treated with respect, care and consideration and that is a good way of building up people's confidence in government.

When the two essay winners were down in Canberra, as I mentioned last night, they had the opportunity of visiting Parliament House, and seeing the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Costello). They visited question time in both houses of parliament and had the opportunity of visiting a range of other major attractions in Canberra including Questacon, the National Gallery and the High Court.

PARA.TAB: When in Canberra, they were hosted and chaperoned by Mrs Judy McArdle, from my office. I would like to take this opportunity to place on the record my thanks to her for the way in which she made sure these two young people had an understanding of the way a nation is governed and also making their visit to Canberra a great enjoyment. I thank the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak this evening about a new railway station that is going to be opened next month in the lower Hunter. It is a railway station that will service the Newcastle university campus. It is going to be of enormous value to university students in the electorate of Paterson although the station itself will not be in the electorate of Paterson.

PARA.TAB: I would like to trace the history of this railway station because I find it very interesting. This railway station has come about by a study that was carried out in the late 1980s and early 1990s and funding was made available by the then Minister for Land Transport, my colleague the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown). He saw the need for this railway station, university students had approached him directly, and $3 1/2 million of federal funding was made available in 1992 to it. Whether it was indifference, sloth or simply lack of will by the former Fahey government in New South Wales, this railway station was put on hold despite its obvious need, its obvious value, to people in the area surrounding urban Newcastle.

What this railway station will mean to students in the electorate of Paterson is that they will be able to live at home and have access to the university campus daily, and their parents will not have to buy them a car or rent them a flat. Students from the electorate of my colleague the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) will also be able to utilise this facility.

The amazing thing about the delay is that during the three years the Fahey government had the funding available for this, it fast tracked a railway station in urban Maitland—a railway station that was never planned for a suburb that is yet to be built—claiming that it was the first railway station to be built in New South Wales since, I think, the Second World War. It refused steadfastly to construct the Warrabrook station.

The shameful thing about that delay is that it was by a party that claims concern for Australia's youth, for Australian families. The value of the Warrabrook station is that it will directly serve the youth of the Hunter. It will directly serve families of the Hunter by ensuring that families will be able to stay together, have reduced cost and parents will have the added knowledge that their children are travelling to university safely and efficiently and that they could be home every night if they so desired. Their lives will change because of this railway station.

I would like to compliment the honourable member for Charlton for his action back in 1992. It was something that was carried out in support of a call by the university students at Newcastle at that time. It will be a great day next month when this station is opened. It is a shame it has taken so long. I can assure members of this House that I will be there when it is opened. I will acclaim it. I look forward to many university students from the electorate of Paterson using it regularly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to acknowledge the presence tonight in the gallery of the three winners of the Menzies electorate Australia Remembers essay competition: Naxhija Agushi, who is in year 8 at Ivanhoe Girls Grammar School; Elizabeth Chen, who is in year 9 at Templestowe College; and Kathryn Young, who is a year 10 student at Ivanhoe Girls Grammar School. I wish to briefly read some excerpts of their winning essays.

PARA.TAB: Naxhija wrote about the experience of people in Macedonia during the war, the difficulties and depravations which were faced particularly by families in captivity. Her essay is dedicated to the memory of her grandfather, Estref, who as a boy, as she says in her essay, lived the story above. I will just read her opening paragraph:

The year is 1944 and the Germans have taken over our country, Macedonia. The men, young and old, have run off into the hills and forests to fight the Germans with the partisans. We are all prisoners in our own country. There is a field—a field of ruins, bones and bodies. Innocent adults and children try to escape but do not succeed and now we have to live behind the wire. All the adults living here are women. Their husbands, sons and lovers all dead or escaped to fight the invaders with the resistance, the partisans. Some children have lost one or both of their parents and are being cared for by a relative or just by a kind hearted stranger.

SPEECH.PARA: In her essay, Elizabeth Chen also wrote about the impact of the Second World War on families, especially on a couple then recently married and then parted by the consequences of war. She wrote partly from the perspective of women at home. I would like to quote one paragraph:

The work was exhausting and boring. I worked 11 hours a day and seven days a week. The factory is cold and we often work dressed in coats and scarves. But the thought of how we were helping to win the war and maybe save some lives really warmed me up. Some of my girlfriends joined the services as WACS and WAAFS and others went to work on the land as farmers to take the place of farm workers who had joined up.
In her essay, Kathryn Young wrote:

1939 meant the commencement of World War II which inevitably affected every Australian. The courageous young men who defended our country, the determined women who were left behind to enter the work force and maintain the Australian economy and supplies for the soldiers, the sweethearts and families of the boys sent away, the families of young soldiers who died in the line of

duty experienced pain and heartache that we, the youth of today, can only imagine. In our world, living in the 1990s, young people have never experienced rationing of food supply, preparing for bomb raids or losing loved ones in a war spanning almost six years. Our lives are immensely diverse in comparison to those of the generations preceding ourselves. War is particularly cruel to the families of the soldiers. Before this year, I could never have really wanted to know what involvement my family had in World War II. However, this year, due to the 50th anniversary, I became quite fascinated with my family's experience. I asked my grandmother about her experiences in the war and discovered many things I would never have imagined could have happened to my average family.
Kathryn finished on this note:

The youth of today need to be informed about the terrible severity of war and some of the ghastly things which occurred during the war periods. In 20 years time, there will be no living survivors to talk first hand about experiences which happened during the war, so information will be excavated from history books. First hand primary sources are much more reliable than secondary sources, because when all the remaining war veterans who hold knowledge of war having been part of it and have in time all passed on, who will be around to inform young people of their past which will inevitably help them achieve a brighter future?

These essays illustrate one of the great benefits of this Australia Remembers year—that young people such as Naxhija, Elizabeth, Kathryn and many others, not only in my electorate but all throughout this land, have learned something in a real way about the history of this country and have learned a lot about the experiences which their own parents and their generation had. I am proud to host these young people here. I am grateful to you, Mr Speaker, for spending some time with them this afternoon, as other colleagues have done. I hope that this experience enriches their lives and, through them, this nation.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Rocher) took the chair at 10.00 a.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the absence of a quorum, the chair will be resumed in two minutes.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 10.00 a.m. to 10.03 a.m.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 22 August, on motion by Mr Beazley:
That the House take note of the paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opportunity to discuss this report on enterprise bargaining is certainly welcome. I am very pleased to see, as has been the practice in recent times, this chamber being made available for the discussion of reports of this nature. As we all know, when there was only one chamber, the motion to take note of a paper was really almost farcical inasmuch as we may as well have added `and be consigned to the garbage bin', because in fact papers never were aired.

PARA.TAB: Of course, the papers represent substantial work. This one was done mainly by the department but many are done by committees which put in extremely large amounts of work on hearings and reports. They are designed as an essential part of our democratic process whereby people in the community are given the opportunity to express a view through parliamentary committees of various natures. Those reports are of considerable value and the more exposure they get in this place the better, whatever the subject matter. I would just like to put on the record my approval of this process that is now available and I hope that my support for that is evidenced by my presence here today.

I also have an ongoing interest in industrial relations and remind the House that my maiden speech was on that very subject. I am pleased to say that I even kept the then member for Wills, Mr Hawke, in the chamber for the entire speech. You, sir, might remember it. I thought it was very good. Nevertheless, one has to push one's own points from time to time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I interrupt the debate at this point to remind honourable members that it is out of order to read newspapers in the chamber.

—Anybody who goes back to that speech will find substantial pleas for an industrial relations system that contained a bit of flexibility; in fact, you could read into it the argument for enterprise bargaining. I made those arguments from long experience—close to 25 years—of employing people in a large range of industries, including the transport sector. It is interesting to note that enterprise bargaining is as old as the process of employment. When we did not have unions and awards, enterprise bargaining was the only arrangement available.

PARA.TAB: I have lived in a business environment of award structures, and I found that those people whom I wanted to employ usually wanted an enterprise bargain. I never found that the truck driver on line haul wanted to be paid the award. If they walked into your place looking for the vacancy that you had advertised and you said, `I pay the award', they would say, `Thanks very much' and turn round and walk out again. They did not want the award. They did not want the restrictions that it placed upon them; they wanted an enterprise bargain.

Strangely enough—and I know it is anathema to many union bureaucrats—the simple fact was that in the transport sector on line haul the truck drivers mostly wanted trip money. They wanted trip money because it allowed them some flexibility in getting from A to B—some might argue more quickly than they were allowed. It allowed them to meet their commitments and to earn good money if they could fit in an extra trip. In most freight situations you find that there is a load in one direction but not necessarily in the other: it is known as back loading. The drivers were very happy if they got an incentive for back loading and—surprise, surprise—they usually found a back load. If they were under the award, the truck came back empty.

The union in that industry is held up to the community as being both powerful and influential, but out there on the ground the fellow who drives a truck in those sorts of situations was always anxious to strike an enterprise bargain. That was even more notable in our more remote areas. The people who chose to go there were of a more enterprising nature. Naturally they were not looking for an enterprise bargain that reduced their opportunity to earn money; they wanted an enterprise bargain that allowed them to earn more money.

More importantly, they were able to get it. As I said in relation to back loading, in every case the deal recognised that the guy who owned the truck needed to make a profit to stay in business and create jobs. These fellows all understood that; they were the salt of the earth. I never could work out why people so loved driving a truck. In later years I was able to say to two or three of them, `Would you like to own this truck?' They said, `How could I do that, I haven't got any money?' I said, `I'm quite happy to advance you in business, I'll guarantee your loan.' I did so on a number of occasions—being one of those villainous bosses who extract everything from the worker.

I put four or five fellows, who had given me good service for three or four years, into a truck and let them subcontract to the business with which I was associated. As it was a cooperative, I was a director and not an owner. To the best of my knowledge, a number of them are still doing extremely well. One fellow was a Maori, and he and his wife were two of the hardest working people I have ever met. She could drive the truck better than he could—and did.

These were the sorts of people whom I saw through five or six years of their business until they could stand on their own two feet. Not one of them let me down. They were the people who were willing to go into enterprise agreements, and willing to grasp the first opportunity to be an owner of a truck—even though this generally reduced their disposable income. They had to meet the payments on the truck, fuel tax and sales tax, and everything else associated with running one of those businesses. Prior to the last election we worked out that those costs were about $2,000 a week.

There has never been a time when enterprise agreements were not in fashion; they just were not formalised. We now have a report on enterprise agreements in their formalised sense and I wish to make a few remarks about that.

I want to repeat something I say from time to time—I have referred to it a little already—that is, this business of villainous, grasping bosses, which is the only sort of rhetoric which our trade union bureaucracy uses to defend their existence, to defend their salary structures and to defend their right to a living. They say, `We have to protect you from those villainous employers.'

As we know, we have 800,000 or 900,000 small businesses in Australia. It is argued that, if they took on one extra employee each, they would wipe out the unemployment pool. We know that is easier said than done. I would say 95 per cent of that group could never be categorised as villainous or grasping. They are frequently, and on most occasions, one of the workers. You can go into many of these workplaces around Australia and have some difficulty identifying the boss, because he looks awfully like everybody else in the workshop. If he is in shorts and long white socks, he is not the boss; he is the visiting salesman.

These people are employers of a huge percentage of the Australian work force. They are on equal terms with them and frequently, as I just mentioned with the owner-driver truckie, have less disposable income than many of the people they employ. They also have a huge appreciation of the value of good employees, the ones who turn up to work regularly, are innovative and are committed to the work ethic. For the only reason that they do not want to lose them, they tend to pay them over the award. In other words, they have an enterprise agreement and it reflects those people's good performance. Every time we hear about this unfair dismissal law, it presupposes the bosses get to work every morning, particularly this group of small employers, and say, `Who can I sack today? Ha, ha, ha.' Scrooge!

TALK.START.PARA: —You do it very well.

—During the recession we had to have I talked with people in certain small businesses which had to retrench staff in large numbers. I talked to one bloke who cried about that situation, not just because he was asking people who had worked with him for many years to leave, but because he saw them as his major asset which he was obliged to dissipate. He saw it as having to sell the land on which his factory stood. He was more concerned how, if he survived the recession we had to have, he would recover this wonderful asset. He knew as he let them go that they were not going to go on the dole. They were the people who would find another job because they were good at their job and he was paying them over the award. He had an enterprise agreement with them going back decades and he shed a tear for those people and for himself because he knew what he was losing.

PARA.TAB: These are the points I make when I hear this mythology that every employer is there to rob you, exploit you, and you therefore need a trade union involvement and an enterprise agreement. That is a lot of rubbish. The truckies never said, `I want to apply for a job with you, Mr Tuckey. I want trip money. I want an enterprise agreement and, by the way, can I call up Billy Smith to come and hold my hand while I deal with you?' They were all about six feet tall. Their feet were nearly as wide as their shoulders. They did not need any help. If they had been dissatisfied with the way I was running the business, they would have given me a bit of advice on that too.

There are thousands of these workers around the place. They have always got a job. They change them from time to time and they do not need anybody's help. They know their value, they know the market and they know what they want. They do not need any of this help. Consequently, they get to the point where, in terms of enterprise agreements, they find it all a bit of a joke.

It is worse than that because on 20 March 1995 Deakin University put out the results of some interesting surveys done by a masters student, Glennis Hanley, under the supervision of Associate Professor Alan Hope in the School of Economics. I do not think Deakin would be considered a right-wing university. They pointed out some very interesting things which I would have thought was a great message to the trade union movement.

The research found that, while the union members tended to be satisfied with traditional union issues, an important factor affecting a unionist's satisfaction related to relationship or communication issues, such as never seeing the trade union representative anymore. These issues included listening to members' concerns, keeping members informed about union affairs and giving members a say in how the union is run. `The importance placed by unionists on relationship issues suggests that, with the larger union structures following amalgamation, rank and file members feel distant, even remote, from union hierarchy,' commented Ms Hanley.

Another important finding of the research was that 40 per cent of members claimed that they joined the union because of either a perception of compulsion or actual compulsion. Of the remainder, only a small group, around 13 per cent, could be described as union `idealogues' committed to the values of trade unionism. The research also revealed that, given trade union membership has fallen from 51 per cent of the employed work force in 1976 to around 35 per cent today, a significant proportion of union members, 40 per cent in this study, may be described as reluctant conscripts. A more realistic estimate of committed union members may be, in effect, about 25 per cent of the employed work force.

Everything involved with this report, and the government's legislation, in terms of the value of that operation, is guaranteeing that group—the union bureaucracy—a place in doing deals for a very cynical work force. And, as we can see, most of them thought they joined the union to buy a job. I think that is one of the more disgraceful aspects of Australia today—the fact that people are still obliged to buy a job. In fact, coming back to those truckies, I have seen them come back to the industry four and five years later and be obliged to get a union ticket in order to pick up a load. They are then told that they owe five years of union dues, because when they were last in the union they did not write a letter withdrawing from the union. I think that too is outrageous. They had to buy a job at a price of $1,500 to $2,000. I think that that is an issue that might be the subject of a parliamentary inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Henzell Ms M.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As usual, you could drive a truck through the comments made by the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). The only example he could use of people who might be affected by workplace reform was that of the six-foot muscle bound truckie. The report we are talking about—Enterprise bargaining in Australia—summarises the issue up to December 1994 and it has some important findings for the new industrial relations measures that are being brought in by this government. I would like to refer to the report that we are debating today. I think some of the gains made are important.

PARA.TAB: Overall, the findings of the report suggest that the period covered by the first report was characterised by a significant growth in enterprise and workplace agreements, particularly in the federal industrial relations system and in the service sector, with bargaining spreading across a large number of industries to cover a majority of employees in the federal system. Workplaces with new federal agreements were distinguished from other forms of agreement, because they were likely to deal with more issues, more likely to reward employees for putting in extra effort and hours, less likely to exclude groups of employees from their agreement, more likely to result in consistent wage increases for all employees, more likely to be seen by women and part-timers as giving them a fair chance to have a say in bargaining and more likely to be seen by women and part-timers as making them better off.
This was in comparison, of course, with formal agreements in state industrial relations systems; the new federal agreements have advantages. To quote from the summary report, the federal agreements:

SPEECH.PARA: . had greater coverage, and more effective representation of male and female employees
. were perceived as showing generally better outcomes in terms of productivity, product quality and reliability, performance against external standards, operating costs and profitability
. were less likely to record a deterioration in management/union cooperation as perceived by employees
. were more likely to provide pay increases for employees, especially female and part-time employees
. were less likely to be perceived by employees as having made them worse off.

However, the report also notes some general dissatisfaction with workplace change. This was referred to in comments made by Mark Davis, in an article in the Financial Review, in response to the report. In spite of some of the very positive gains that the report mentions, to quote Mark Davis's report:
The outcome of workplace change is often viewed negatively by employees, particularly in places where management fails to consult with its workforce.
That is, obviously, a key issue of enterprise bargaining. There has to be effective consultation between management and workers. He goes on, in his review of the report, to say this:

PARA.TAB: While collective agreements are estimated to cover 69 per cent of employees under the federal system, they cover only 21 per cent of the entire workforce because of the lower penetration of bargaining in workplaces regulated by State industrial systems.
The report found that the most common workplace changes introduced last year were new technology, changes in work organisation, new training opportunities and employee performance appraisal.

The report says negative perceptions amongst employees reflect an "intensification" of work and higher levels of pressure on workers, with most employees saying they were putting more effort into their jobs than in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that that is a key issue. Certainly, we recognise that the really quite radical changes made to the workplace—through enterprise bargaining and, in many workplaces, through structural changes—have resulted in a rise in concern, not only about future job satisfaction, but also about security of employment. That has also come out of the recession. To quote, again, from the summary report:
A particular area of concern arose from evidence of employee dissatisfaction on several issues across all types of workplaces, whether or not they had agreements

. there was a significant decline in satisfaction with management, perceptions of weakening job security, widespread increases in stress and growing dissatisfaction with employees' ability to balance work and family life
. employees were almost as likely to think that workplace changes had made them worse off, as better off—
so it is about fifty-fifty on that—

. attitudes to workplace bargaining were more positive than attitudes to workplace change more generally, with employees in workplaces with new federal agreements substantially more likely to report they were better off than worse off because of workplace bargaining.

While there is obviously this background of widespread concern about the changes that are happening in the culture of many workplaces—with many entrenched attitudes having to change and with concern about the future and job security—the evidence would indicate that, in fact, the enterprise bargaining arrangements that we have put in place have had a significant effect on the confidence of workers to feel that they can actually negotiate more effective arrangements with employers.

PARA.TAB: But that involves the ability to handle the arrangements. Certainly, one of the key factors, as I have said in speeches before, is the ability of management to consult effectively, because we now have much more on-line, face-to-face arrangements in workplaces. We should remind ourselves that our Industrial Relations Act now covers certified agreements—negotiated between employers and unions representing employees—and enterprise flexibility agreements, or EFAs, made directly between an employer and employees, provided that the majority of employees approve.

It is very important and very significant for workers to remember that the major difference between ourselves and the opposition is that underpinning these quite radical changes is a commitment to an award safety net provision. It is important for us to remind ourselves of what those particular award safety net conditions are. They include minimum weekly wage rates; overtime and penalty rates; relevant leave loadings, for example casual leave loadings; four weeks annual leave; parental leave at test case standards; cumulative sick leave; two to three days bereavement leave; jury leave; the 38-hour week; termination, change and redundancy at test case standards; superannuation; public holidays; union right of entry; dispute settlement procedures; equal pay; and industry appropriate standards which vary from industry to industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —And occupational health and safety.

—Thank you. My colleague reminds me of occupational health and safety. On the other side of the ledger, what are the opposition offering in comparison? We are not too sure now, because they keep changing their particular goal posts. We are not sure that the real agenda about Jobsback has ever really changed, and I believe that the ideological commitment of the current Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has not changed. From what we can understand from their public comments, what is left of Jobsback is rigid and will be seen not to have changed. But we can specify that the only part of the award that the opposition is prepared to support is a single unspecified minimum hourly wage rate for adults, and another for juniors; four weeks annual leave; 12 months unpaid leave for natural mothers; and 10 days non-cumulative sick leave. There is no recognition of industry standards.
—And occupational health and safety.

—And occupational health and safety. We will include that, and I thank my colleague from the opposition benches. There is a major difference between the government and the opposition. What we have delivered under the Accord is a commitment to the no-disadvantage test so that, when workers go into a bargaining situation, they know that they will have access to advice from their union delegates and they know that, while they are negotiating increased productivity trade-offs for increases in wages and conditions, there will be a bottom line that will not be affected. And the evidence indicates, from those that have been registered in the federal system, that they simply have not been add-ons to the award provisions, but have been genuinely striven-for improvements to the awards; and we have actually had increases in productivity.

PARA.TAB: Looking at the general situation, workers have to be very clear that, if they are to be seduced by the generalised and insubstantial rhetoric from the opposition, they will be cutting away their award conditions and the safety net. That is very important. I gather that the opposition spokesperson, Mr Reith, has suggested that the coalition will introduce a no-disadvantage test. But we are not really sure what it will mean. It will not be a safeguard on award conditions but, as the minister said, a trapdoor to lower wages and employment conditions.

I am afraid to say that I do not feel reassured by the shadow spokesperson on industrial relations. He is the architect of Jobsback, the GST and other things, and I do not believe the Australian work force, at the end of the day, will be prepared to jettison what has been built up over a 12-year period: an Accord that has delivered wage security, low-inflation and sustained economic growth, and which has delivered two million jobs in the last 12 years and a substantial improvement to our whole economy. That is what is going to make the difference for workers and their families.

It is important to indicate that our industrial relations policy has delivered the lowest level of industrial disputes in 50 years, even under collective bargaining with a sanction-free bargaining period. We have 60 per cent of federal award workers now covered by enterprise agreements with productivity offsets and four to five per cent annual wage increases. Under the Industrial Relations Reform Act and the Accord we have been able to decentralise the wage system while maintaining fairness in the process. Part of that is to make Australia a more productive, cooperative and competitive society. That is what is going to deliver advantages to families. All the rhetoric in the headland speeches will not change that.

In talking with some of my coalmining constituents recently on a visit out west, the following point was made to me. I think it is pretty telling. A comrade said, `Look, in the 1970s and the early part of the 1980s, I spent more time out on the grass than down the pit because we were forever battling with management. In the lifetime of the Labor government I've been able to get on with the job at my workplace. We've negotiated massive workplace reform without the necessity for prolonged disputes.' Honourable members may remember that the current Leader of the Opposition was the architect of the housing dispute that saw coal workers out on the grass for weeks on end.

As I have often said, the coalminers of Blackwater have not forgotten the fact that John Howard precipitated a riot. They have not forgotten it; they have very long memories. The coalminer that I was talking to said, `I don't want to spend the next five to 10 years out on the grass. I would like to complete my working life and then retire and have the benefits of the wages and conditions that my union, the CFMEU, the mining division, have been able to negotiate for me with management.' Coal workers have provided huge changes and made major differences to the productivity of that industry.

We are still working on the AMH dispute. It is at least something to say that we have an industrial relations commission providing the backing for those workers and ultimately, I believe, the rights of the workers will prevail against a multinational.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to recognise in the chamber today our South Australian colleagues the members for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans) and Makin (Mr Duncan), particularly, in this instance, the member for Bonython who, prior to his life in the federal parliament, served in the South Australian government as the Minister for Health. Both members will be familiar with what is a popular view in South Australia right now, that is, that the current Minister for Health, Dr Armitage and, I suspect, his counterpart, the Minister for Education and Children's Services, Mr Lucas, go home at the end of the day rubbing their hands in glee because another hospital or school has been closed or spending on health and education has been constrained in some way. I think that is a lot of nonsense, that both of those ministers find themselves reluctantly participating in this sort of reform and wish that the sort of pressure that they are obliged to put on the taxpayers' dollar was not necessary.

PARA.TAB: I open my remarks in this manner because the member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell) suggested that there was some sort of glee on this side every time workers are, in some way, restricted in their wage demands, or are obliged to put in more effort for less return. Just as I suspect my state colleagues do not go home gleeful when they find themselves obliged to exercise government restraint, so I want to reassure the Main Committee that the objectives that the government has for employee and employer relationships are largely reflected by the opposition. Sometimes I suspect the opposition is wrongly seen as simply reflecting the view of employers. In fact, it is made up of a group of people who want good employment relationships and good employment conditions for employees in Australia.

At the great risk of boring you, since I suspect you heard this remark from me in the House of Representatives chamber earlier this week, I would point out to the Main Committee that what the government and the opposition have in common when it comes to enterprise bargaining and employer-employee relationships is one very significant factor: not that the government represents employees and the opposition represents employers—which is nonsense—but that we all happen to be parents of children who are seeking employment in Australia. I no more want my children caught up in an exploitative time frame and exploitative work conditions than anyone in the government wants theirs in that position. I have vested an interest in continuing good employee-employer relationships in Australia.

The member for Capricornia has suggested, as government members sometimes do, that the government has some sort of monopoly on enterprise bargaining and employer-employee relationships. I pick up the comments by the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). I suspect that the whole concept of enterprise bargaining was in existence long before the present agreements were in place. The whole concept of enterprise bargaining is, frankly, something that suits the Australian workplace and the Australian work ethic.

In my own experience in rural industries, shearers have always been a part of some form of enterprise bargaining. They choose to work on a contract rather than at an hourly rate because of the opportunities for remuneration that that offers them. I know that is particularly true in the transport area, as alluded to by the member for O'Connor. Transport drivers deliberately choose to enter into a trip rate rather than an hourly rate arrangement. They deliberately choose transport operators who will pay them above the award. And they deliberately choose to enter into some form of loose enterprise bargaining so they can negotiate such things as back loading in order to maximise their return. The operator is pleased to entertain them because he wants that truck loaded and because, frankly, enterprising employees are the very people he wants to employ.

I am not one who suggests that out there in the workplace there are not some trucking operators who would be exploitative, given half a chance. Of course, there are. Sadly, that is part of human nature. But they are in the minority. Furthermore, I have witnessed—I could not say first-hand because I have never been a truck operator but I had produce on the truck that was affected—the retaliation of employees who have felt that a particular truck operator was in some way being exploitative. I well recall getting a phone message to the effect that the tomatoes that I had produced and that I thought were on a truck destined for the Melbourne market were bound for Hobart, across the ocean, and were about to be left in Hobart. The truck driver had chosen in his own retaliatory way, having got to Melbourne and feeling that he was being exploited by the truck operator, to put that truck on the Empress of Tasmania and leave it there. That did not please me and it did not please the transport operator, and I guess it is a very poor illustration of enterprise bargaining, but I applauded the determination shown by that particular employee to hold an exploitative employer to ransom.

There is not, on this side of the House—as is popularly imagined—some sort of desperate anti-union feeling. I suspect that most of the members of the opposition have themselves been the members of a union of one form or another.

TALK.START.PARA: —I still am.

—As the member for Cowper indicates, he still is, and I guess I could say I am too, if belonging to the South Australian Farmers Federation constitutes belonging to a union. It certainly does inasmuch as I see that the opportunity for cooperative and collective bargaining strengthens my hand. I am comfortable with that and I welcome the existence of unions because of what they do for the bargaining power of employees.

PARA.TAB: It seems not to suit the government to recognise that on this side of the House there is widespread recognition of the value of unions. All that we are saying, in reflecting on this report, is that the concept of enterprise bargaining is not of itself something new. In fact, particularly in rural industries, enterprise bargaining has been a fact of life for years. As someone who came out of a labour intensive rural industry, I can indicate to the Main Committee that as a business we always paid above the award because we wanted to, because we wanted to keep in place our valued employees who were making a real contribution to the business.

Furthermore, while the member for Capricornia suggested that the member for O'Connor had only been successfully involved in enterprise bargaining because the truck drivers with whom he was negotiating were six feet tall and three feet across, that is not quite fair of the member for Capricornia. The reality is that I have been engaged in enterprise bargaining with grape pickers who were as petite as the member for Capricornia and were still successful bargaining operators because they knew that I had a crop that I wanted to pick, and I knew that they had the capacity to be cheerful employees and I would happily pay above the award in order to achieve that sort of cooperation.

That was an unstructured form of enterprise bargaining. The concept of enterprise bargaining, far from being something on which the government has a monopoly, is something with which the opposition is entirely comfortable. It is wrong to create the impression of a them and us mentality about enterprise bargaining. The opposition is not anti-union and, frankly, we are anxious to enter into the sort of cooperation with employees keen to work that enables the total enterprise in Australia to be enhanced.

Current enterprise bargaining agreements in Australia tend to take two forms: either certified agreements between the unions and the employers, or enterprise flexibility arrangements which are entered into between the employers and the employees. The significance of the secondary one is not that unions are excluded but that there is an opportunity for employers and employees to enter into independent negotiations if they so choose.

The opposition does not seek to exclude employees from any of these arrangements. In fact, as I interjected to assist the member for Capricornia, the opposition seeks to ensure that existing minimum wage arrangements are retained, that occupational health and safety arrangements are retained. We have never walked away from the obligation that all employers should have to pay overtime, leave loading, annual leave and sick leave, and never has the opposition suggested that the superannuation arrangements currently being negotiated should in some way be abandoned if the opposition were to come to power.

We are comfortable with the concept of enterprise bargaining and with the arrangements that have been entered into and we welcome the opportunity for employees to choose whether they enter into an arrangement assisted and represented by their union or whether they enter into an arrangement in their own right. Furthermore, one of the things that ought to be celebrated by all Australians is the fact that in this nation, under the present government, we have a safety net that ensures that exploitation, while it can still occur—Blind Freddy would agree with that—at least is minimised because society at large says that everyone should be entitled to some form of safety net if employment is not available to them. No-one in the opposition has ever suggested that that safety net should be pruned.

For too long it has been too easy for government members to suggest that opposition members simply sit here seeking a chance to be exploitative in the way they deal with employees. Frankly, in my own experience and in the experience of those colleagues with whom I have spoken on both sides of the House, I think that is a quite unfair misrepresentation of what it is that motivates the opposition.

I have but one desperate plea as a member of the parliament and as someone involved in the debate on industrial relations, and that is to ensure that we do not put in place those requirements that are a deliberate disincentive to employers to employ people, because I consider the exploitation of unemployment is also something that every Australian should be conscious of. In unintentionally making it more difficult to employ people, we instantly ensure that those people live lives that therefore are less purposeful than would be the case if they were in employment. The member for O'Connor has made the point that there are 800,000 small businesses in Australia and that if in fact they were able to employ more people that would mean a more competitive and productive economy, and there would be a real impact made on the existing levels of unemployment.

In my concluding remarks, I will quote briefly from the report. In the conclusion to the summary of the report, reflecting on what the public servants dealing with enterprise bargaining in Australia have achieved, it says:

SPEECH.PARA: Many of the changes that were observed, for better or worse, in Australian workplaces were changes that would have occurred anyway—
and I think that is significant—
But it also appeared that there were some patterns that distinguished Part VIB agreements from other types of agreements, and these comparisons were summarised in the conclusion.

PARA.TAB: Part VIB workplaces, compared to other non-VIB agreement workplaces, were:

SPEECH.PARA: .more likely to reward employees for putting in extra effort or hours;
.less likely to exclude groups of employees from the agreement; and
.less likely to provide for different rates of pay rises for employees covered by agreements.

Those objectives are ones which both opposition and government would laud. The concept of enterprise bargaining is not of itself a unique panacea. Rather, it reflects the way in which Australians generally would like to enter into agreements between employers and employees in order to maximise the productivity of the workplace. That additional productivity augurs well for the future of the balance of payments figure in Australia and for the opportunity to have a more competitive and more lucrative Australia in which all Australians will want to live.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are here today to talk about the report entitled Enterprise bargaining in Australia, but first I would like to take up some of the points that have been made by those opposite. On occasion, on both sides of this chamber we resort to rhetoric in respect to the positions of our opponents and also we possibly laud our own positions; however, there are a few issues I would like to take up.

PARA.TAB: As the member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) is still here, I would like to address some of his comments. I do not think that, generally, on this side of the House there is a view that the opposition—in terms of the views of individual members of the coalition—is totally anti-worker, or that it wants to drive down working conditions. I have friends who are members of the coalition whom I respect in terms of their commitment to the views that they hold and their basic wishes for this society. However, the question really gets down to the results of policies. The question also gets down to just what the policies are. In terms of the Liberal Party, and of the coalition as a whole, we have to look at what its policy has been in the past and what its policy is now.

Elements of that policy are now being dragged out—and it is almost like pulling teeth—with respect to industrial relations. They have made a commitment to the no-disadvantage clause, although to an extent it is rather vague in comparison to the existing government's position. Historically, in terms of Jobsback, the coalition also has a position on things like the basic reduction and erosion of award conditions, with, for example, the $3 an hour award wage proposed by the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard).

Conservative coalition governments in various state jurisdictions are also doing some fairly extreme things. Their intention may not be for those actions to have extreme results but, coming from Victoria, and not wishing to labour the point about the Premier, the fact is that when you look at what is occurring in Victoria with respect to ordinary workers, and the conditions they face when they go to work every day, there has been a real impact. People come into my office every day of the week, as they do to the offices of members opposite. I do not know whether only people associated with the Labor Party come to my office and only people associated with the coalition go to their offices, but we seem to be hearing very different stories.

Quite often, people come to my office who are in a situation where they have been subjected to a form of abuse with respect to their working position because of changes in the state award system which have severely impacted upon them and their families—even with respect to their take-home pay. Certainly, when I speak about the question of the coalition's policies with respect to these issues and their result, I bear no ill will to the members opposite in personal terms. What I worry about is the actual result of those policies. No matter how well founded they may be in terms of theory and no matter how well founded they may be in terms of the members' personal views and their ideology, the fact is that, as we see happening in states like Victoria and Western Australia, those policies are just not working.

I would take up another comment by the member for Wakefield with respect to his example about the truck being left on the boat. I can also quote some examples of personal experiences when I was working on a station in New South Wales, longer ago than I care to remember. The circumstances were that I was driving a tractor and I was getting three bucks an hour. I found out subsequently, about six months later, that every other worker on every other farm in the surrounding districts was getting five bucks an hour. The only way I was able to address that issue was to pull on my own personal little strike at the time we were about to plant the wheat, and that was quite effective. I guess it could be called enterprise bargaining; I guess that at the time I saw it as being militant industrial action on an individual basis. In those circumstances it did work, and in those circumstances it was necessary.

The person I was employed by was not a bad fellow, but the view he had related to his circumstances and the position that he held with respect to the business. The circumstance with many employers is not that they are bad—and I do not think that they are—but that they have a very clear and abiding commitment to their business and to what they are doing. That tends to give them a perspective which relates to their position and that is understandable—it is totally understandable. However, the question is: does that in the end mean a result which can be worse for workers than it should be? The answer there, I think, is yes.

Also when we look at the question of what is seen as a fair and reasonable claim, whether it be through enterprise bargaining or through other forms of action or negotiation, the fact is that it is always better to look back, and see what was fair or unfair historically—to see how unfair it really was—rather than looking forward. Historical claims are always easier to understand and to accept.

I have had numerous occasions where, in years gone by, as a union official dealing with employers, I have had the argument put to me, `But we can't afford this.' That is often the case: no argument, that is often the case. But on quite a few occasions, in circumstances where we have reached an agreement on the basis of what the employer said was something that was not sustainable, I have gone back to that workplace 12 months later or whatever, and the fact is that it has been affordable and it has been achievable. The employer often is prepared to agree that was in fact the case, but then give you the same answer about any future claim you may make. Again, that is understandable from their position.

With respect to the circumstances of the individual truck driver and the boat, I guess that enterprise bargaining in the more formal sense, as this agreement discusses, is about avoiding those sorts of circumstances. It is about having a situation where, if an employer and an employee do negotiate on a formal basis, we know what the ground rules are, we know where we stand. The circumstances are then that we do not have forms of industrial action of that nature taking place, or, if they are taking place, certainly they are on a much reduced level. That is one of the successes of the government's industrial relations reforms over the years—and they have evolved in various ways—that there has been a major decrease, a historical low in industrial action.

I know that there are other issues relating to that. There is also the question of the overall impact of the recessionary period; there is also the impact of job losses in particular industries. That has all, I suppose, created additional fear in people's minds about maintaining their jobs, and about their willingness perhaps to take action. It has also meant that areas of the work force that are traditionally not heavily unionised have grown while others have decreased.

We are seeing a situation, over the last three years or so as the recovery has occurred, and as employment has improved in many of those industries, where industrial action is still at a historical low. I do not think you can say it is one or the other totally, but I think that there has to be some recognition given to the fact that the government's accord process, the negotiations and the reforms within industrial relations have had an impact.

Both the member for Wakefield and the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) commented that enterprise bargaining has always occurred. Agreed. No doubt about that. I guess I would say that much of what we do in this place—and I think it is the intention of both sides in terms of their beliefs—is regulate, to an extent, the operation of the economy. There are arguments about how far that regulation goes, and there are also circumstances where different variations on the theme occur. But the fact of the matter is that we are partly about trying to regulate the operation of society, and the circumstances of enterprise bargaining are such that there has to be a situation where there are more formalised approaches taken in general.

The real issue is not the question of the six-foot truck drivers, or the very articulate smaller people who are, in fact, able to use their skills to good effect with reasonable or sometimes unreasonable employers. A work force is a very varied and different area, and people often require those sorts of regulations and rules in there to assist with the processes of agreements with employers.

As a former union official and, I suppose, someone who has followed the classic sort of hack development that is often pointed out by the coalition with respect to Labor Party politicians—not that is has done me that much good—I have often dealt with employees whose real problem has been a lack of knowledge with respect to their rights and a lack of understanding about how they work. I am sure that has been the experience of those opposite also. In those circumstances there is a need to articulate those views.

In a situation such as the one in Victoria, where basically the guts of the rule book have been thrown out, the end result is that employees feel even more exposed, more unsure of what they are entitled to and more able to be taken advantage of, often by people who, I stress, are not seeking to take advantage of them. The employees are merely in the competitive environment of industrial relations, which has existed for an awful long time. They are endeavouring to maximise their own benefits from an involvement in the productive process while employers are about trying to maximise the benefit to them and their business with respect to profits and therefore income. That is understandable, but it does require regulations for the process.

The Enterprise bargaining in Australia report is the first comprehensive review of developments in bargaining at the enterprise and workplace level. It covers a nine-month period from 30 March to 31 December 1994. The report was prepared by the Department of Industrial Relations and draws on several sources of information, including the department's formalised federal workplace agreements database, which contains information on federal enterprise agreements formalised by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, which commenced operation in the period under review. The workplace bargaining survey 1994, which is the largest work based survey of both managers and employees undertaken in Australia to date, conducted nationally at 1,060 Australian workplaces with 10 or more employees, was another source of information.

Research was conducted within and outside the department, including an analysis of transcripts and decisions from Australian Industrial Relations Commission hearings. Consultations were conducted for the report with a broad range of organisations with an interest in enterprise bargaining, including employer organisations, the ACTU and unions, groups representing women and ethnic communities, other community organisations and relevant government agencies. There was also consultation with the sex discrimination commission and the Affirmative Action Agency.

The report reviews developments under part VIB of the federal IR Act which has two types of enterprise agreements: certified agreements negotiated between employers and unions and enterprise flexibility agreements made directly between an employer and his or her employees, provided a majority of employees approve. The report concentrates on developments in the federal sphere but does provide some comparative data on workplaces in the formal state systems and workplaces with unregistered agreements.

A number of messages come out of the report. I will be brief, given that I have probably spent too much time discussing the comments of previous speakers. The first message is that overall the extra protections for employees introduced through our legislation are having a positive effect. Bargaining under our federal system is fairer for employees. The comparative data within the report shows that, compared with other forms of agreement, new federal agreements are more likely to result in wage increases for all employees, and that women and part-timers have seen it as giving them a fairer chance to have a say within the process. More employees in workplaces with new federal agreements, some 63 per cent, had received a wage increase in the previous 12 months than had employees in other types of workplaces.

The second message from the report is that the federal system not only is fairer but also is delivering better coverage. We have seen a significant increase in agreement making in the federal IR system and, through that process, by protecting employees, the government's reforms are helping to boost employee participation in and confidence in bargaining. That will have a result with respect to the quality of work and industry undertaken through business, and that will have a better result for the economy as a whole.

The system is delivering good economic results, with 96 per cent of agreements including at least one provision to improve productivity at the workplace and provisions relating to hours of work, training and work organisation found in the majority of agreements. Compared with unregistered agreements, new formal federal agreements were more likely to have received wage increases based on productivity, and nearly 80 per cent of workplaces with new federal agreements reported an increase in productivity in the previous 12 months. It is starting to show results, and I think results which go past the anecdotal discussions of, say, the member for O'Connor earlier today.

The report also shows that a number of people who were critical of these reforms at the time have in fact been proved to be wrong. In the lead up to the Industrial Relations Reform Act, some employer groups and conservative commentators said that giving employers the right to strike when negotiating a certified agreement through a sanction-free bargaining period, taking the secondary boycott provisions out of the Trade Practices Act and dealing with secondary boycotts through the Industrial Relations Act would lead to a massive increase in industrial disputation. That just has not happened.

Another argument, which was put by the ACCI and others, was that the federal agreements were just meaningless, that they would be add-ons to awards and in that way, clearly, are wrong. But, again, a review of the agreements that have been reached show that, arguably, only a small number appear to be simply add-ons. The circumstances were that agreements from the perspective of workplace managers were seen to have represented a complete settlement of the package of pay and conditions that ought to apply in a workplace or enterprise.

Many of those agreements involved an overall restructuring of someone's award conditions but often the agreement addressed particular issues that were a particular problem with respect to that business. I had the experience, as an official in years gone by, where often the argument from an employer would be, `It's this issue I want to fix. The rest I can live with. It's okay.' That is what has been addressed through this process. Overall, the report is a handy document with respect to the changes that have occurred. It shows that the reforms are moving in the right direction. I commend it to the House. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to make a few remarks about the 1994 annual report on enterprise bargaining in Australia. It is interesting listening to members opposite speaking on the topic of industrial relations. The accusation of course comes out, as it inevitably did then, that some members on our side are inherently anti-worker. We would of course strongly dispute that. What we are in fact is pro-Australia. It is quite clear that the industrial regime is absolutely critical to the future of Australia. The reason why we in Australia have dragged the chain so much in terms of the restructuring of our economy is simply that the government of the last 12 years has been hamstrung to a very large extent by its relations with the unions.

PARA.TAB: We do not need to look any further than that as one of the major reasons why the restructuring of the Australian economy has been so slow—although there has been an increasing realisation on the other side of politics that it needs to be done. To their credit, I think some of the leadership of the Labor Party do know what needs to be done. I notice that the president of the Labor Party, the member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones), is here this morning. Certainly, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), I think, understands what needs to be done, as do some of his ministers. However, it has been made quite clear time and time again that they have been unable to deliver because they can go only as far as the union movement—the union leadership in particular—allows them to go. There is a fundamental conflict of interest within the Australian Labor Party and because of that they will never be able to deliver the structural reform of the Australian economy that the times demand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think there was a faster rate of change under the Fraser government?

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Vaile)—Order! The member for McPherson has the call.

TALK.START.PARA: —We could talk about the Fraser government. The caravan has moved on so far since 1983. I accept the criticism of many aspects of the Fraser government, but the fact is that in the last 10 years, when there needed to be an accelerated rate of change, the Labor Party has not been anywhere up to delivering that rate of change, in a world where there has been a realisation that there has been a rapid rate of change. Let us look at our Asian neighbours. In Singapore, for instance, the standard of living has doubled—however that is measured—every 10 years since the 1960s.

PARA.TAB: The New Zealand economy—our government wanted to be critical of the process of change which was going on there at one stage—is now bearing the fruit from the in-depth accelerated structural change that has occurred, while we have been largely sitting on our hands. The Labor Party knew the directions that had to be taken. However, it has not been able to deliver and this report indicates that quite clearly.

The report talks about the quantity of change. That was my impression in reading through it. On that measure, on the quantity of change, it looks very good. It is able to report, as the minister has reported in the parliament, about the extent of the coverage of the work force by enterprise agreements. When it gets down to the actual facts, it talks about quantity rather than quality of change. It has been at that level that the government has been incapable of delivering.

The debate on these issues is largely stifled by the fact that the government has been hamstrung in its relations with the union movement. In the debate on industrial relations in the main chamber yesterday, I pointed to the cosy relationship that exists between the Labor Party and the union movement. Actually, it is more than cosy; it is quite incestuous. The extent of financial support given by the government to the unions is remarkable. In the last 12 years, between $130 million and $140 million of taxpayers' money has effectively been given to the unions by virtue of direct grants and tax concessions. All legally—

TALK.START.PARA: —For training.
—You can call it training but, if you read down the list, it is very—
—But there are no direct grants to the unions.

—I have not got those facts in front of me; I am just recalling them from yesterday. Government patronage of the union movement exists to that extent. The other side of the picture is more alarming because it is actually a two-way street. Prior to the 1993 election, the ACTU received grants of $1.3 million from the government for a whole range of purposes. It does not really matter whether or not it is called training—a lot of it is fairly specious. At least, on the face of it, it is not illegal.

PARA.TAB: At the same time, the ACTU put $1.2 million into its campaign against the coalition at the 1993 election. Almost all the money it received in grants from the government was used against the coalition. The extent of the patronage that exists between the Labor Party and the trade union movement is such that, at that level, it is really a matter of the one who pays the piper calling the tune. That is why this country has been largely hamstrung in the area of industrial relations over the last 12 years. We are accused of being anti-worker but the government has operated in the interests of a small sector of the Australian community, the trade union leadership and some of their apparatchiks, to the great detriment of the majority of Australia and Australians, and that is the great pity of it. The government has been unable to deliver, other than in some quantitative sense, what was necessary.

I would like to back up a bit here and say that, quite remarkably, in about 1991, the government came to a realisation that it had missed the boat in terms of industrial relation reform. Let us remember that, up to that point, it was totally intransigent on enterprise bargaining. It was something that we had talked about on our side of politics for many years, although, as the member for Lalor observed, the timing was not right and nothing was done prior to 1983. That is when the whole process of change in our part of the world, in particular, accelerated, although it had been happening in parts of Asia prior to that.

The facts are that the government was finally dragged screaming to the realisation that there had to be a move into this new era of industrial relations. Prior to that, we were totally locked into the colonial system and the whole shebang, the whole box and dice, of arbitration and centralised wage fixing. The union movement realised too late that there had to be a change and the government was actually allowed—that is what it boiled down to—to go down that track.

As I say, I believe some of them knew that that was the way to go, and I pay credit to those who were smart enough to know it. I suspect that many others were smart enough to know it too, but their factions tell them—I do not know which faction the honourable member for Corinella (Mr Griffin) is in, but no doubt he is also told—how far to go down those tracks. The leadership of the trade union movement slowly woke up to the fact that they had to get with it and that they had no choice. So we have entered into this process of what amounts ultimately to a Claytons form of enterprise bargaining, because it has so many restrictions placed upon it—both legislative and otherwise—that it really is still failing today to deliver the pace of reform that the circumstances actually call for.

The rhetoric of the member for Corinella, who spoke before me about `Up the workers!' and all that sort of rhetoric that we still hear from members in the Labor Party, is really quite passe. In my view, it is something out of a bygone era. Ultimately, we have to come to a point where we must decide what is best for Australia and not what is best for a few trade union officials, particularly those who are in parliament. The member for Corinella admitted, and he is quite right, that Labor party members are so dominated because the government is comprised of former union officials. In my dealings with them, I learned this business at the coalface, in employing large numbers of people who were members of trade unions. I learned at a fairly young age what their real motivation actually was, but I also came to understand that trade union officials do not understand—not that they are incapable of it, but they choose not to understand—what the real world is actually about and what business is all about.

But even all of that has changed in recent years, because I think we are operating in a much more enlightened environment than we were when those sorts of conflicts actually were going on. There is now a much greater appreciation—by management in particular, but also by workers by and large—that ultimately everybody is better off and the cake actually becomes bigger through an appreciation of what our profits and sales are actually all about.

The recent report which showed that Australia was, in some senses, the wealthiest nation on earth should probably give us some comfort, but what it actually does is demonstrate, more clearly than anything else we have seen in recent times, the great gap that there is in this country between its potential and its actual performance. By almost every measure, our performance in economic terms is very poor. Ultimately, of course, our international competitiveness is the major problem that we are faced with in this country, in terms of making our way in the world with the ongoing balance of payments problems that we continue to have.

The aims and objectives of the industrial relations legislation have been expressed as being to enable the spread of enterprise bargaining and the protection of employees' interests through the maintenance and strengthening of the award safety net. We come to an impasse in these sorts of debates when we talk about the status quo. The starting point for all of the negotiations, from the government's point of view and from the unions' point of view, has always been the status quo. It has always been assumed that, in some ways, that was the point to start at; whereas, quite clearly, in many respects it was not the point to start at. In fact, the safety net, as somebody observed the other day, rather than being a safety net had become a hammock for many employees.

There is a need, of course, as we recognise on this side of the House, for a balance between what might be a free-for-all in enterprise bargaining in terms of a laissez-faire approach. But the emphasis on protection of employee interests has been very largely at the expense of employer interests and, ultimately, it is the employers who actually provide the jobs. You can only go on for so long biting the hand that feeds you before you realise that that will not work and that, indeed, it is not working.

The fact that it is not working is reflected in the high levels of unemployment that we have had in recent years. Despite the very best attempts of the government to disguise that fact, clearly unemployment is on the rise again, even though the government has thrown millions of dollars at the problem by putting people onto all sorts of training schemes and giving them these new work opportunities, and so on. These are basically for the short term, to get them into a situation where they are at least not ostensibly unemployed. But the level of unemployment and underemployment in this country is huge. Realistically, taking the total level of unemployment and underemployment, we are probably looking at a figure closer to 15, 16 or even 20 per cent of the Australian work force, rather than the eight or so per cent that the official figures actually divulge.

The unfair dismissal legislation which we dealt with in the parliament yesterday—which the minister claimed was an improvement on a good system but which, in fact, was only a minor improvement on a very bad system—really does not help us at all to overcome these problems. In the end, employers will take the attitude, as they have the right to do, that if you cannot fire them, why would you be motivated to hire them? That effort alone has been another example of the incapacity of the Labor Party to handle the situation that exists.

There is a lot more that could be said about this report. But the bottom line, in my view, is that it demonstrates a success in quantitative terms and not qualitative terms. I really fear that this government, as it has demonstrated over the past 12 years, has a total incapacity to move Australia as the times demand. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —If there is one issue, one policy area, in this parliament that you can always rely on to provoke the opposition into getting excited, it is industrial relations. In fairness, I guess that could be said of both sides as most of us on both sides of the House certainly have views on matters to do with industrial relations. But you always get this from the opposition; you get people coming in one after the other and doomsaying about how dreadful our economy is and how dreadful our industrial relations system is.

PARA.TAB: We have had people protesting this morning that they are not anti-worker. I guess some of them might not be anti-worker and there might be some goodwill, but they are certainly anti-union. And how dare we have unions in this country! These are unions which are democratically elected, hopefully; are not perfect, necessarily—but nobody is perfect; but, certainly, are organisations elected to represent working people. And what a dreadful thing that we have unions in this country that actually play a part in industrial relations!

You can see from the Accord, which first came in in 1983, and we are now up to Accord Mark VIII, how effective that has been in ensuring effective industrial relations in this country. It has not always been the workers who have been terribly pleased with various decisions or agreements arising out of the Accord. Some workers might think that wages have been kept too low, or whatever. But, if you look at it objectively, you can certainly see that what we have in this country is an industrial relations system which does work, where there is consensus, where there are benefits for both employers and employees, for unions and business alike, and where, most obviously of all, there is a huge decrease in the number of industrial disputes. With one exception, I cannot recall a major federal industrial dispute—a significant one, one that has brought the country to a halt—since 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had the recession.

—We have not been in a recession since 1983, and apart from the pilots' dispute in about 1989, or whenever it was, I cannot recall a major federal industrial dispute. During the previous speaker's address, the member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) pointed out the comparison with the Fraser years. The Fraser years are years that I remember very well, as I was a fairly young new trade unionist in those days in the public sector. There were years of confrontation and division and ongoing industrial disputation in the public and private sectors under the Fraser government.
—There was very little economic structural change.

—And fairly poor economic circumstances, as we are reminded of quite frequently in the House during question time. If you compare the economy in those years with the economy now, it certainly speaks volumes.

PARA.TAB: We also heard about the cosy relationship between the Labor Party and the trade union movement. We do not hear much from the other side about the cosy relationship between business and the Liberal Party. Where do they get their funds from at election times? We have only got to look at health policy, where one of the most predatory and greedy trade unions—if I can stretch the term—the AMA, virtually write the coalition's health policy.

Enterprise bargaining in Australia discusses progress in enterprise bargaining. Our enterprise bargaining system has a legislative background. The Industrial Relations Reform Act came into effect on 30 March last year. The act was designed to encourage enterprise bargaining, while providing guarantees to ensure that employees are treated fairly and cannot be disadvantaged by bargaining. That is in direct contrast with the opposition policies. We keep hearing that there are too many restrictions, legislative and otherwise, on enterprise bargaining. Those restrictions are there for a very good reason: to protect workers and ensure that people are not disadvantaged by bargains which are struck.

In relation to the award system, the main elements of the legislation are: employees are protected by awards that set fair and enforceable minimum wages and conditions of employment that are maintained at a relevant level; the award safety net is strengthened by guaranteeing access for all workers to minimum entitlements relating to minimum wages; there is equal remuneration of work for equal value; there are conditions relating to termination of employment, including unfair dismissal—we hear a lot about that from the opposition—and there is the right to 12 months unpaid parental leave.

I do not think that any employer in this country has anything to fear. Any fair, sincere employer who follows due process has nothing to fear from unfair dismissal legislation. We have had so much hype and nonsense from the opposition, clearly for electoral reasons. Their scaremongering over this legislation seeks to alarm employers and to deter them from employing people. It is one of the most disgraceful disinformation campaigns I have seen.
