That used to be the system under which everyone had the same opportunity to save but women hardly had it at all and ordinary workers did not have it at all. We have changed that. I just hope that the ordinary people of Australia understand that, while our system of industrial relations has meant that they have had to make many changes, for which I thank them, and many sacrifices, for which I thank them, these things are under jeopardy at the next election.

Do not assume for one moment that the Liberal Party will somehow abandon this fixation of wanting to see workers unrepresented. We had the member for Fisher saying, `Well, of course, we're going to dis-amalgamate unions, we are going to allow them to dis-amalgamate,' when all the management theory says about organisations that you need to have a customer focus, that is, union members; you need to provide services, that is, services for union members; and the greater your revenue stream, that is, the larger the union, the greater potential you have to provide these services.

This is somehow excommunicate anathema to opposition members. What they want to see is thousands of small unions. In fact, they would love to see an enterprise with 50 members have its own union. Well, I just do not understand it. I just do not understand why they want to attack ordinary people and their conditions of work this way. It doesn't make sense in management terms or organisational terms and it is a vicious attack on ordinary people.

I was saying that workers have made a lot of sacrifices. I believe they have. They have seen a whole revolution occur in the workplace. As I have said, they have seen the demarcations go which used to provide them a measure of security, if you like, a measure of employment—not something that I would justify. They have seen multiskilling come in. They have had to go back and get extra skills—be trained and re-trained. They have seen downsizing. They have seen massive productivity increases. This is again a difference between a Labor government and a Liberal government: we believe that through work organisation, through new ways and better ways of doing it, through capital equipment, you can dramatically increase productivity, as we have.

The other way we can increase productivity is to make labour cheaper. That is the conservative way. We reject that. We have seen lots of organisations downsize. Before I came to this place, I worked for Telecom. There have been massive changes and downsizing there and changes at a rate and pace that have almost been dysfunctional. That is not unique. It has been occurring right throughout Australia. People have adapted and coped and I congratulate them for that. I congratulate them for their positive approach. They have responded well to these changes.

As this report suggests, enterprise bargaining is here to stay under a Labor government. Its reach will be increased dramatically. Ordinary men and women of Australia are not going to be disadvantaged in the process and we will not attack worker organisations. The enterprise bargaining report is a good report. As many people as possible should get hold of a copy of the report and they will find that the government has done well. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Mr Lindsay) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia: Permanent Residency Applications

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 28 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many citizens of the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (FYROM) have applied for permanent entry into Australia.
(2) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to diplomatic difficulties being experienced by Australian residents of FYROM in dealing with the FYROM Government.
(3) Will FYROM establish a diplomatic mission in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: I am advised that:

(1) Statistics on the citizenship of people who apply for permanent entry into Australia are not kept but statistics are available on the number of applicants by place of birth. In the period from the beginning of March 1994 (the first full month following formal recognition by Australia of the FYROM) to the end of May 1995 (the latest month for which statistics are available) 591 applications for permanent entry into Australia, representing 1194 persons who were born in the FYROM, were lodged.

(2) It is presumed that the question relates to the lack of access to a full range of consular services by members of the FYROM community in Australia. The Government is indeed aware of, and sympathetic to, the inconvenience that lack of access to consular services is causing Australians of FYROM origin in areas such as issue of passports and personal legal matters. That lack of access was one of the reasons for Australia's recognition of FYROM in February 1994 for it laid the ground for the establishment of formal relations between the two countries. Ways in which access to consular services by people of FYROM origin in Australia can best be accommodated are being examined.

(3) The Australian Government has made it clear that the establishment of a consular or diplomatic mission in Australia could only be on the conditions laid down in Senator Evans' ministerial statement of 14 March 1994. It would have to be appropriately described as the mission "of the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia" and would be unable to display any contentious flag or other symbols.

Discussions have taken place as to ways in which, consistent with these conditions, the interests of FYROM and residents from FYROM might be accommodated, but the matter remains unresolved at this time.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 30 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did she claim in an answer to a question without notice (Hansard, 26 June 1995, page 2277) that the Port Macquarie hospital was costing the NSW Government 30 per cent more to run than public hospitals; if so, will she provide full details to support the claim.

(2) Has her attention been drawn to a statement by the chief executive officer of the Port Macquarie Base Hospital that (a) cost overruns had not been mentioned in meetings with the Department of Health and (b) under the hospital's contract all cost overruns over the agreed budget must be met by Health Care of Australia and not the NSW Government; if so, what is her response.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. My statement was made on the basis of information available to me, including that published in the media (Sun Herald 25 June 1995).

(2) No. I do not doubt, however, that Health Care of Australia may carry the risks if the cost of providing services exceeds the contract price. My point is that the contract price is some 30% in excess of what it costs the NSW Government to provide comparable services through public hospitals.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 22 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the General-Secretary of the Vietnamese Communist Party, Mr Do Muoi, been invited to visit Australia; if so, (a) in what capacity has Mr Muoi been invited to visit, (b) what will the visit cost the Commonwealth, (c) what is the purpose of the visit, (d) who will Mr Muoi meet in Australia, (e) will representatives of the Vietnamese community be able to meet Mr Muoi during the visit, (f) will he and the Minister for Foreign Affairs meet representatives of the Vietnamese community before the visit and (g) will consultative meetings be organised for Australian Government officials with representatives of the Vietnamese community as occurred before the visit of the Vietnamese Prime Minister in May 1993.
(2) What sum has the Government spent on repatriation programs of Vietnamese refugees in South-East Asia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I invited the General Secretary of the Vietnamese Communist Party, Mr Do Muoi, to Australia when we met in Vietnam in April 1994. The General Secretary visited Australia from 29 July to 4 August 1995. (a) He was invited in his General Secretary capacity. He was given Head of Government status, commensurate with his stature in the Vietnamese political system and previous practice in this area. (b) The cost to the Commonwealth of the visit was $267 341. (c) The purpose of the visit was to continue the development of a partnership between Vietnam and Australia, based on shared interests in the region, substantial commercial ties, assistance in development, and growing people-to-people contacts. (d) During his visit, in addition to his meeting with me, the General Secretary met the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Premier of New South Wales, the Premier of Victoria, the Queensland Minister for Minerals and Energy, and senior members of the business community including representatives of Telstra, BHP, ANZ Bank, Transfield, Pacific Power, Draytons and Queensland Alumina Limited. (e) Representatives of the Vietnamese community did not seek a meeting with the General Secretary. (f) Before the General Secretary's arrival in Australia, I had a productive meeting with the leaders of the Vietnamese community to discuss the visit. (g) Consultations between the Vietnamese community and representatives of my Department, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs were held in Sydney and Melbourne before the visit.

(2) Since 1989, Australia has provided $9.7 million towards the Comprehensive Plan of Action for Indo-chinese refugees, including $1.5 million in 1994-95. These funds have assisted the UNHCR in the maintenance of asylum seekers in camps and their repatriation. Of the funds provided since 1989, $2 055 900 has been directly earmarked for the repatriation of screened-out Vietnamese asylum seekers. In 1994-95, $1 million was spent on the Vietnamese repatriation program.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Human Services and Health: Medically Qualified Consultants

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 22 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Have (a) her Department, (b) the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) and (c) the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare engaged consultants since 1993 who are practising medical practitioners; if so, have the consultants had access to patient servicing or provider data held by the HIC.
(2) What procedures or protocols are in effect to ensure that a practising practitioner does not obtain private advantage through access to data which may be related to other registered providers.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) Yes, the Department of Human Services and Health has engaged consultants who are practising medical practitioners. The consultants have not had access to patient servicing or provider data held by the Health Insurance Commission (HIC).
(b) Yes, the HIC has engaged consultants since 1993 who are registered medical practitioners and such consultants do have access to patient servicing and provider data held by the HIC.

(c) Yes, the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare has engaged consultants who are practising medical practitioners in the specified period but neither the Institute nor consultants employed by the Institute have access to patient servicing or provider data held by the HIC.

(2) The appointment of consultants by the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) is made by resolution of the Commission and each consultant is required to enter into a formal contract with the HIC. This contract requires the consultant to give the following:

(i) an acknowledgment that he or she understands the secrecy provisions in Section 130 of the Health Insurance Act 1973 and Section 135A of the National Health Act 1953 and will not make use of such information otherwise than for the purpose of his/her duties under the Acts.
(ii) an acknowledgment that all information will be protected against loss or unauthorised access.
(iii) at the conclusion of each consultancy all information held by the consultant will be returned to the Commission.
(iv) an acknowledgment that he/she will advise the Commission of any conflict or risk of conflict of interest.

The HIC is able to monitor computer access should the need arise. This is done in cases of suspected misuse of data. The HIC is also developing an artificial neural network to detect improper access to data.

(1) The major classification system for research is the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) Field of Research Classification (FORC). The FORC is a broad, discipline-based classification system. Research on renewable energy cannot be identified from FORC and would be subsumed in several disciplines including General Engineering, Biological Sciences and the Social Sciences. Renewable energy is, however, specifically categorised within the ABS set of Socio-economic Objectives (SEO). SEO was first collected for all Large Research Grants lodged in March 1994 and for those Large Research Grants which commenced in January 1995. For Collaborative Research Grants which were lodged in May 1995, the successful ones will commence in January 1996. Hence, information provided is limited to such grants.

(2) Applications lodged in the 1994-95 financial year are still being processed. In general, applications for grants are lodged in the latter half of each financial year and, if funded, commence at the beginning of the next calendar year.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 23 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the existence of commercial and community based bartering systems operating in Australia in which participants earn points by providing services which can be used to purchase other services and which in some schemes can be redeemed for cash.

(2) Does his Department, as part of means or assets tests, ask (a) applicants for and (b) recipients of benefits if they are members of either commercial or community based bartering schemes; if not, will his Department introduce the question into means and assets tests.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes

(2) The Department does not ask people when they are receiving or applying for payments if they are members of commercial or community based bartering systems. This is not necessary as `barter points' or `trade dollars' earned through approved exchange trading schemes are exempt from the income test. To be exempt, a scheme must not be run for profit and must be primarily aimed to help participants maintain their labour market skills. However, cash earned or assets accrued through such schemes is subject to the income and assets test, respectively, and must be notified to the Department.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Recognition of Educational Qualifications in Europe

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 28 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the answer provided by the Minister for Foreign Affairs to my question No. 2113 (Hansard, 23 August 1995, page 349).
(2) What steps has his Department taken to assist Unesco and the Council of Europe in drafting a joint convention on academic mobility and recogni

QUESTION.PARA: tion of studies and qualifications in higher education for submission to the Executive Board of Unesco at its 147th session in Paris on 3 October 1995.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) A working group was established by UNESCO and the Council of Europe to make progress with the joint Convention. While Australia is not on the working group, we fully support the proposal. My Department has helped in drafting the joint Convention by active participation in UNESCO/Council of Europe meetings in Malta (1994), Budapest (1994) and Ljubljana (1995), where the joint Convention has been on the agenda.

As the report on the draft joint Convention will be submitted to the Executive Board of UNESCO in Paris on 3 October 1995, as in previous years my Department is contributing to the briefing that is being prepared for your attendance at the meeting.

Following the Executive Board meeting and the subsequent General Conference of UNESCO in November 1995, I understand that Australia and other signatory countries to the UNESCO Convention will be formally consulted on the joint Convention. My Department will coordinate the Government's response.
